赞美经理人的道路

Praise for The Manager’s Path

经理之路提供了工程管理职业的大局观。卡米尔为每个职业阶段提供了非常有策略的建议。并且因为工程经理对他们的报告负有很大的责任来学习如何管理好，所以你应该阅读这本书并了解它是如何完成的。
这本书是理解和追求工程管理事业的实用指南。
Liz Crawford，Gen​​acast Ventures 的常驻企业家；Birchbox 前首席技术官
正如卡米尔在第 5 章中所说，“这本书是为工程经理准备的。这不是一本通用的管理书籍。” 我毫不犹豫地向所有从事软件工程或围绕软件工程工作的人推荐这本书，无论你是否认为管理适合你。
在软件工程中，我们经常将管理视为一种介于要避免的命运、障碍和成为房间里最响亮的人的奖励之间的东西。我们大多数人都经历过糟糕的管理，并且作为一个行业，我们努力将管理人员提升到比无用还差一点的水平，这是否令人惊讶？卡米尔的书教我们如何以相当大的优势清除这个障碍。她从我们所有人开始的地方开始，作为一个被管理的人，并从那个共同点向上工作。Camille 是我们行业中最伟大的工程领导者之一。她的建议既实用又深刻。虽然我希望我在职业生涯的早期就拥有这本书，但我很感激现在能拥有它。
Kellan Elliot-McCrea，Blink Health 工程高级副总裁；Etsy 前首席技术官
我从卡米尔那里学到的工程领导力比几乎任何人都多。她的写作对新手和经验丰富的经理都有很大的帮助，不仅要思考如何完成工作，还要思考如何为企业和员工找到最佳方法。这将是我在未来几年向所有管理者推荐的一本书。
Skyliner 首席执行官 Marc Hedlund；Stripe 和 Etsy 前工程副总裁

经理人之路

The Manager’s Path

引领增长和变革的技术领导者指南

A Guide for Tech Leaders Navigating Growth and Change

卡米尔·福尼耶

Camille Fournier

奉献精神

Dedication

至CK

To CK

致谢

Acknowledgments

特别感谢我的编辑 Laurel Ruma 和 Ashley Brown，他们帮助这位第一次写作的作者在没有太多眼泪的情况下完成了她的书。

Special thanks go out to my editors, Laurel Ruma and Ashley Brown, who helped this first-time author get through her book without too many tears.

感谢 Michael Marçal、Caitie McCaffrey、James Turnbull、Cate Huston、Marc Hedlund、Pete Miron、bethanye Blount 和 Lara Hogan 提供有关领导力的轶事与我们的读者分享。

Thank you to Michael Marçal, Caitie McCaffrey, James Turnbull, Cate Huston, Marc Hedlund, Pete Miron, bethanye Blount, and Lara Hogan for providing anecdotes on leadership to share with our readers.

感谢在写作过程中给我宝贵反馈的所有人，包括 Timothy Danford、Rod Begbie、Liz Crawford、Cate Huston、James Turnbull、Julie Steele、Marilyn Cole、Katherine Styer 和 Adrian Howard。

Thanks to everyone who gave me valuable feedback during the writing process, including Timothy Danford, Rod Begbie, Liz Crawford, Cate Huston, James Turnbull, Julie Steele, Marilyn Cole, Katherine Styer, and Adrian Howard.

特别感谢我的合作者，Kellan Elliott-McCrea，感谢他在管理方面的许多智慧，也感谢我所有的 CTO 晚宴朋友多年来的建议，其中大部分都写进了这份手稿。

Special thanks to my collaborator, Kellan Elliott-McCrea, for his numerous bits of management wisdom, and to all of my CTO Dinner friends for your advice over the years, much of which made it into this manuscript.

感谢我的长期教练 Dani Rukin，感谢您帮助我摆脱困境，并鼓励我始终保持好奇心。

To my long-time coach, Dani Rukin, thank you for helping me get out of my head, and for encouraging me to always stay curious.

最后但并非最不重要的一点是，感谢我的丈夫克里斯，因为许多餐桌上的辩论塑造了一些最棘手的写作。他的见解和编辑帮助我成为了今天的作家。

Last but not least, thanks to my husband, Chris, for the many dinner-table debates that shaped some of the trickiest writing. His insights and edits have helped me become the writer I am today.

介绍

Introduction

在2011年，我加入了一家名为 Rent the Runway 的小型创业公司。从在大公司从事大型分布式系统工作到与专注于提供出色客户体验的小型工程团队合作，这对我来说是一个根本性的转变。我这样做是因为我认为这项业务非常出色，并且我想要一个领导的机会。我相信只要有一点运气和一些努力，我就能获得我渴望拥有的领导经验。

In 2011, I joined a small startup called Rent the Runway. It was a radical departure for me to go from working on large distributed systems at a big company to working with a tiny engineering team with a focus on delivering a great customer experience. I did it because I thought the business was brilliant, and I wanted a chance to lead. I believed that with a little luck and some hard work, I could get that leadership experience that I was so eager to have.

我不知道自己在做什么。我加入了 Rent the Runway，担任没有团队的经理，名义上是工程总监，在实践中更接近技术主管。就像创业生活中经常出现的情况一样，我被聘用是为了让大事发生，我必须自己弄清楚那会是什么样子。

I had no idea what I was getting myself into. I joined Rent the Runway as a manager without a team, a director of engineering in name and something closer to a tech lead in practice. As is often the case with startup life, I was hired to make big things happen, and had to figure out myself what that might look like.

在接下来的四年里，我的角色从管理一个小团队发展到以 CTO 的身份运行所有工程。随着组织规模的扩大，我也扩大了规模。我有导师、教练和朋友提供了宝贵的建议，但没有人具体告诉我该怎么做。没有安全网，学习曲线很残酷。

Over the next four years, my role grew from managing a small team to running all of engineering as CTO. As the organization scaled, so did I. I had mentors, coaches, and friends who provided valuable advice, but no one was there to tell me specifically what to do. There was no safety net, and the learning curve was brutal.

当我离开公司时，我发现自己充满了建议。我也想有一个创意的出路，所以我决定参加“全国小说写作月”，这是一个30天写5万字的挑战。我试图写下我在过去四年中学到的一切，我亲身经历的一切，以及我看着别人成功和奋斗的一些观察。那个项目变成了你现在正在阅读的书。

When I left the company, I found myself bursting with advice. I also wanted a creative outlet, so I decided to participate in “National Novel Writing Month,” which is a challenge to write 50,000 words in 30 days. I attempted to write down everything I had learned over the past four years, everything I had personally experienced and several observations I’d made watching others succeed and struggle. That project turned into the book you are reading now.

本书的结构遵循工程师最终成为经理的典型职业道路的各个阶段。从作为导师的第一步到高级领导的挑战，我一直试图强调你在此过程中每一步通常学到的主要主题和经验教训。没有一本书可以涵盖所有细节，但我的目标是帮助您单独关注每个级别，而不是用与您当前情况无关的挑战细节来压倒您。

This book is structured to follow the stages of a typical career path for an engineer who ends up becoming a manager. From the first steps as a mentor to the challenges of senior leadership, I have tried to highlight the main themes and lessons that you typically learn at each step along the way. No book can cover every detail, but my goal is to help you focus on each level individually, instead of overwhelming you with details about challenges that are irrelevant to your current situation.

以我的经验，工程管理的大部分挑战在于“工程”和“管理”的交叉点。人的一面很难，我不想把那些人际关系的挑战卖得太短。但这些特定于人的管理技能也可以转化为跨行业和工作。如果您有兴趣在纯粹的领导力的人事管理方面进行改进，那么像First, Break All the Rules 1这样的书籍是很好的参考。

In my experience, most of the challenge of engineering management is in the intersection of “engineering” and “management.” The people side is hard, and I don’t want to sell the challenges of those interpersonal relationships short. But those people-specific management skills also translate across industries and jobs. If you are interested in improving on purely the people management side of leadership, books like First, Break All the Rules1 are excellent references.

然而，工程经理所做的并不是纯粹的人员管理。我们管理着一群技术人员，我们中的大多数人都是从实践专业知识的职位上来的。我不建议尝试任何其他方式！亲身实践的专业知识能给您带来可信度，帮助您做出决策并有效地领导您的团队。本书有很多部分专门讨论管理作为一门技术学科所面临的特殊挑战。

What engineering managers do, though, is not pure people management. We are managing groups of technical people, and most of us come into the role from a position of hands-on expertise. I wouldn’t recommend trying to do it any other way! Hands-on expertise is what gives you credibility and what helps you make decisions and lead your team effectively. There are many parts of this book dedicated to the particular challenges of management as a technical discipline.

工程管理很难，但有一些策略可以帮助它变得更容易。我希望在阅读本文时，您对如何处理工程管理的角色有一些新的想法，无论您是刚刚开始还是已经做了多年。

Engineering management is hard, but there are strategies for approaching it that can help make it easier. I hope that in reading this you get some new ideas for how you might approach the role of engineering management, whether you’re just starting out or have been doing it for years.

如何阅读本书

How to Read This Book

本书分为几个章节，涵盖越来越多的管理复杂性。第一章介绍了如何管理的基础知识，以及对经理的期望。接下来的两章涵盖了指导和成为技术主管，这两个都是管理路径上的关键步骤。对于有经验的经理，这些章节有一些关于如何管理这些角色的人的说明。以下四章分别讨论人员管理、团队管理、多团队管理、管理者管理。管理路径的最后一章，第 8 章，都是关于高层领导的。

This book is separated into chapters that cover increasing levels of management complexity. The first chapter describes the basics of how to be managed, and what to expect from a manager. The next two chapters cover mentoring and being a tech lead, which are both critical steps on the management path. For the experienced manager, these chapters have some notes on how you might approach managing people in these roles. The following four chapters talk about people management, team management, management of multiple teams, and managing managers. The last chapter on the management path, Chapter 8, is all about senior leadership.

对于刚入门的经理来说，现在阅读前三四章可能就足够了，然后略过其余部分，当你开始面对这些挑战时再回来。对于经验丰富的经理，您可能更愿意关注您目前正在努力解决的级别的章节。

For the beginning manager, it may be enough to read the first three or four chapters for now and skim the rest, returning when you start to face those challenges. For the experienced manager, you may prefer to focus on the chapters around the level that you’re currently struggling with.

贯穿始终的是具有三个反复出现的主题的部分：

Interspersed throughout are sections with three recurring themes:

询问首席技术官
这些是简短的插曲，用于讨论一个特定问题，该问题往往会在各个层次上出现。
好经理，坏经理
这些部分涵盖了工程经理的常见功能障碍，并提供了一些识别这些坏习惯并克服它们的策略。每个部分都放置在最有可能与功能障碍相对应的章节/级别中，但是这些功能障碍通常在每个经验级别中都可以看到。
具有挑战性的情况
从第 4 章开始，我会花一些时间来讨论可能出现的具有挑战性的情况。同样，虽然这些大致放置在最合适的级别，但无论您当前的级别如何，您都可以在其中找到有用的信息。

第 9 章有点像通配符，针对那些试图建立、改变或改善团队文化的人。虽然它是从初创公司领导者的角度编写的，但我认为其中大部分内容将适用于那些进入新公司或运营需要提升其文化和流程的团队的人。

Chapter 9 is a bit of a wildcard, aimed at those trying to set up, change, or improve the culture of their team. While it was written from a perspective of a startup leader, I think that much of it will apply to those coming into new companies or running teams that need an uplift in their culture and processes.

不仅仅是一本面向普通读者的鼓舞人心的领导力书籍，我还想写一些值得 O'Reilly 烙印的东西，随着时间的推移，你可以像参考Programming Perl一样参考这些东西。因此，请将本书视为工程经理的参考手册，这是一本专注于实用技巧的书，我希望在您的整个管理生涯中对您有所帮助。

More than an inspirational leadership book for a general-purpose audience, I wanted to write something worthy of the O’Reilly imprint, something you can refer back to over time in the same way you might refer to Programming Perl. Therefore, think of this book as a reference manual for engineering managers, a book focused on practical tips that I hope will be useful to you throughout your management career.

奥莱利野生动物园

O’Reilly Safari

笔记

Safari（前身为 Safari Books Online）是面向企业、政府、教育工作者和个人的会员制培训和参考平台。

Safari (formerly Safari Books Online) is a membership-based training and reference platform for enterprise, government, educators, and individuals.

1Marcus Buckingham 和 Curt Coffman，首先，打破所有规则：世界上最伟大的经理人的不同之处（纽约：Simon & Schuster，1999 年）。

1 Marcus Buckingham and Curt Coffman, First, Break All the Rules: What the World’s Greatest Managers Do Differently (New York: Simon & Schuster, 1999).

第 1 章管理 101

Chapter 1. Management 101

管理的秘诀是让讨厌你的人远离那些还没有下定决心的人。
凯西·斯坦格尔

你读这本书是因为你想成为一名优秀的管理者，但你知道管理者长什么样吗？你有过好经理吗？如果有人让你坐下来问你应该从一个好的经理那里得到什么，你能回答这个问题吗？

You’re reading this book because you want to be a good manager, but do you even know what one looks like? Have you ever had a good manager? If someone were to sit you down and ask you what you should expect from a good manager, could you answer that question?

对经理有什么期望

What to Expect from a Manager

每个人的第一次管理经验都在桌子的另一边，被管理的经验是你建立自己的管理理念的基础。不幸的是，我发现有些人在他们的职业生涯中从来没有一个好的经理。我的朋友说他们最好的经理是用“善意的忽视”来管理他们的。工程师只是知道要做什么，而经理则完全不理会他们。在最极端的情况下，一个人报告说在六个月内只与他的经理会面两次，其中一次是为了获得晋升。

Everyone’s very first experience of management is on the other side of the table, and the experience of being managed is the foundation on which you build your own management philosophy. Unfortunately, I’ve come to see that there are people who have never in their careers had a good manager. Friends of mine talk about their best managers as managing them with “benign neglect.” The engineer just kind of knows what to work on, and the manager just leaves them alone entirely. In the most extreme case, one person reported meeting only twice with his manager in the span of six months, one of those times to receive a promotion.

当您考虑一些替代方案时，良性忽视并不是那么糟糕。有些疏忽的经理在你需要帮助时不理你，把你的顾虑放在一边，他们避免与你见面，从不给你反馈，只是突然告诉你，你没有达到期望或没有资格晋升。当然，有些微观管理者会质疑你所做的每一件事的每一个细节，并拒绝让你自己做出任何决定。更糟糕的是，主动辱骂的经理会忽视你，直到他们想对你大喊大叫。可悲的是，所有这些角色都在我们公司周围走来走去，对他们团队的心理健康造成严重破坏。当您认为这些是唯一的选择时，除非您特别寻求帮助，否则大部分时间让您独自一人的经理似乎一点也不坏。

Benign neglect isn’t so bad when you consider some of the alternatives. There are the neglectful managers who ignore you when you need help and brush your concerns aside, who avoid meeting with you and who never give you feedback, only to tell you suddenly that you are not meeting expectations or not qualified to be promoted. And of course there are micromanagers who question every detail of everything you do and refuse to let you make any decisions on your own. Still worse are actively abusive managers who neglect you until they want to yell at you for something. Sadly, all of these characters are walking around our companies, wreaking havoc on the mental health of their teams. When you believe that these are the only alternatives, a manager who leaves you alone most of the time unless you specifically ask for help doesn’t seem so bad at all.

但是，还有其他选择。关心您作为一个人，并积极工作以帮助您在职业生涯中成长的经理。教您重要技能并为您提供宝贵反馈的经理。帮助您度过难关的经理，他们帮助您弄清楚您需要学习什么。希望有一天你接受他们的工作的经理。最重要的是，经理可以帮助您了解需要关注的重点，并使您能够集中精力。

There are, however, other options. Managers who care about you as a person, and who actively work to help you grow in your career. Managers who teach you important skills and give you valuable feedback. Managers who help you navigate difficult situations, who help you figure out what you need to learn. Managers who want you to take their job someday. And most importantly, managers who help you understand what is important to focus on, and enable you to have that focus.

至少，您应该期望您的经理根据需要执行一些任务，以使您和您的团队保持正轨。当您了解对经理的期望时，您可以开始询问您的需求。

At a minimum, there are a few tasks that you should expect your manager to perform as needed, in order to keep you and your team on track. As you learn what to expect from your manager, you can start to ask for what you need.

一对一会议

One-on-One Meetings

与您的直接经理进行一对一的会议 (1-1s) 是良好工作关系的基本特征。然而，许多经理忽视了这些会议，或者让他们觉得他们是在浪费你的时间。在一个好的 1-1 的接收端是什么感觉？

One-on-one meetings (1-1s) with your direct manager are an essential feature of a good working relationship. However, many managers neglect these meetings, or make them feel like a waste of your time. What does it feel like to be on the receiving end of a good 1-1?

1-1 有两个目的。首先，他们在您和您的经理之间建立了人际关系。这并不意味着您将所有时间都花在谈论您的爱好或家庭或闲聊周末。但是让你的经理稍微介入你的生活很重要，因为当有压力的事情发生时（家庭中的死亡、新孩子、分手、住房问题），向你的经理请假会容易得多或者告诉他你需要什么，如果他有你作为一个人的背景。当你的正常能量水平发生变化时，优秀的管理者会注意到，并希望他们足够关心并询问你。

1-1s serve two purposes. First, they create human connection between you and your manager. That doesn’t mean you spend the whole time talking about your hobbies or families or making small talk about the weekend. But letting your manager into your life a little bit is important, because when there are stressful things happening (a death in the family, a new child, a breakup, housing woes), it will be much easier to ask your manager for time off or tell him what you need if he has context on you as a person. Great managers notice when your normal energy level changes, and will hopefully care enough to ask you about it.

在工作中，我不是一个好朋友。我觉得有必要这么说，因为我认为有时我们会因为我们性格内向，或者我们不想在工作中结交朋友而忽略了关心同事。你可能会认为我是那种喜欢结交很多工作朋友的人，因此我不明白这对你来说是什么感觉，但我向你保证：我明白你不觉得人性的一面就是一切在工作场所很有趣。然而，作为一个内向的人并不是不努力将人们视为真正的人的借口。强大团队的基石是人际关系，这会带来信任。而信任，真正的信任，需要有能力和意愿在对方面前变得脆弱。所以，你的经理希望你能像对待工作之外的人一样对待你，

I am not a buddy-buddy person at work. I feel the need to say this because I think that sometimes we give ourselves a pass at caring about our colleagues because we’re introverts, or we don’t want to make friends at work. You might think that I am the sort who loves to make lots of work friends, and therefore I don’t understand how this feels to you, but I assure you: I understand that you don’t feel like that human side is all that interesting in the workplace. Being an introvert is not an excuse for making no effort to treat people like real human beings, however. The bedrock of strong teams is human connection, which leads to trust. And trust, real trust, requires the ability and willingness to be vulnerable in front of each other. So, your manager will hopefully treat you like a human who has a life outside of work, and spend a few minutes talking about that life when you meet.

1-1 的第二个目的是定期让您有机会与您的经理私下讨论任何需要讨论的问题。您应该期望您的 1-1 安排具有一定的可预测性，以便您可以为他们计划，因为完全控制 1-1 议程不是您的经理的工作。有时他会，但最好在一对一会议之前考虑一下您可能真正想要讨论的内容。如果您的经理不定期与您会面，或者不断取消或更改您的 1-1，则很难做到这一点。您可能不想定期进行 1-1，或者您可能只需要每隔几周进行一次。没关系，只要你不完全消除它们。根据需要使用它们，如果您发现想要更频繁地见面，请向您的经理询问。

The second purpose of a 1-1 is a regular opportunity for you to speak privately with your manager about whatever needs discussing. You should expect your 1-1s to be scheduled with some predictability so that you can plan for them, because it is not your manager’s job to completely control the 1-1 agenda. Sometimes he will, but it is good for you to put a little thought into what you might actually want to discuss before your 1-1 meetings. It is hard to do this if your manager does not regularly meet with you, or constantly cancels or changes your 1-1s. You may not want to do 1-1s regularly, or you may only need them every few weeks. That’s OK, so long as you don’t eliminate them completely. Use them as you need them, and if you find that you want to meet more frequently, ask your manager for that.

对于大多数人来说，好的 1-1 并不是状态会议。如果您是向高级管理层汇报的经理，您可以使用您的 1-1 来讨论关键项目的状态，或者仍处于初期阶段的项目，其中不一定有很多记录。但是，如果您是个人贡献者，那么 1-1 作为状态会议是重复的并且可能很无聊。如果您的 1-1 是交付无聊状态报告的可怕义务，请尝试为此目的使用电子邮件或聊天来腾出时间，并将您自己的一些主题带到 1-1。

For most people, good 1-1s are not status meetings. If you are a manager reporting up to senior management, you may use your 1-1 to discuss the status of critical projects, or projects that are still in the nascent stage where there’s not necessarily a lot written down yet. If you’re an individual contributor, though, a 1-1 as a status meeting is repetitive and probably boring. If your 1-1 is a dreadful obligation for delivering a boring status report, try using email or chat for that purpose instead to free up the time, and bringing some topics of your own to the 1-1.

我鼓励您与您的经理分担保持良好 1-1 的责任。附上你想讨论的事情的议程。自己准备时间。如果他定期取消或重新安排你的时间，让他找到一个更稳定的时间，如果这不可能，请确认你将要见面并分享的前一天（或那天早上，下午的会议）任何你有兴趣讨论的事情，让他知道你想见他。

I encourage you to share the responsibility of having good 1-1s with your manager. Come with an agenda of things you would like to discuss. Prepare for the time yourself. If he cancels or reschedules on you regularly, push him to find a time that is more stable, and if this isn’t possible, verify the day before (or that morning, for an afternoon meeting) that you will be meeting and share with him anything you are interested in discussing so he knows you want to meet.

反馈和工作场所指导

Feedback and Workplace Guidance

对经理的第二个期望是反馈。我不只是在谈论绩效评估，尽管那是其中的一部分。不可避免地，你会以某种方式搞砸，如果你的经理有什么好，她会很快让你知道你做了。这会很不舒服！特别是对于那些不习惯从父母以外的任何人那里获得行为反馈的新员工来说，这可能是一件非常令人迷惑的事情。

The second thing to expect from your manager is feedback. I’m not just talking about performance reviews, although that is part of it. Inevitably, you will screw up in some fashion, and if your manager is any good she will let you know quickly that you did. This is going to be uncomfortable! In particular, for those new to the workforce who are not used to getting behavioral feedback from anyone but their parents, this can be a pretty disorienting thing to have happen.

但是，您确实希望获得这种反馈，因为唯一比获得行为反馈更糟糕的是根本没有获得它，或者仅在您的绩效评估期间获得它。越早知道自己的坏习惯，就越容易改正。这也适用于获得好评。一位出色的经理会注意到您在日常工作中做得很好的一些小事，并会因此而认可您。跟踪这些反馈，无论好坏，并在您撰写年度自我评估时使用它。

You do want to get this feedback, though, because the only thing worse than getting behavioral feedback is not getting it at all, or getting it only during your performance review. The sooner you know about your bad habits, the easier they are to correct. This also goes for getting praise. A great manager will notice some of the little things you’re doing well in your day-to-day, and recognize you for them. Keep track of this feedback, good and bad, and use it when you write your self-review for the year.

理想情况下，如果是表扬，你从经理那里得到的反馈会是公开的，如果是批评的话，会是私人的。如果你的经理在开会后立即抓住你提供批评性反馈，这并不一定表明你的行为很糟糕。优秀的管理者知道快速提供反馈比等待合适的时间说些什么更有价值。在公共场合表扬被认为是一种最佳做法，因为它可以帮助经理让每个人都知道有人做了值得称赞的事情，并强化了积极行为的样子。如果你不喜欢公众的赞美，告诉你的经理！如果她问就好了，但如果她不问，你就不应该默默忍受。

Ideally, the feedback you get from your manager will be somewhat public if it’s praise, and private if it’s criticism. If your manager grabs you immediately after a meeting to provide critical feedback, that is not necessarily a sign that your behavior was terrible. Good managers know that delivering feedback quickly is more valuable than waiting for a convenient time to say something. Praising in public is considered to be a best practice because it helps the manager let everyone know that someone has done something laudable, and reinforces what positive behavior looks like. If you don’t like public praise, tell your manager! It would be great if she asked, but if she doesn’t, you shouldn’t suffer in silence.

您可能需要向您的经理索取其他类型的反馈。如果您要进行演示，您可以请她查看内容并提出更改建议。如果您编写了设计文档，她应该能够提供需要改进的领域的想法。作为工程师，我们主要从同行那里获得代码反馈，但你会做代码以外的事情，你的经理应该充当资源来帮助你改进这些事情。向你的经理征求意见也是表明你尊重她的好方法。人们喜欢乐于助人，经理们也不能幸免于这种奉承。

There are other types of feedback that you may want to ask for from your manager. If you are giving a presentation, you can ask her to review the content and suggest changes. If you’ve written a design doc, she should be able to provide ideas of areas for improvement. As engineers, we get code feedback mostly from our peers, but you will do things other than code, and your manager should act as a resource to help you improve those things. Asking your manager for advice is also a good way to show that you respect her. People like to feel helpful, and managers are not immune to this sort of flattery.

当谈到你在公司的角色时，你的经理需要成为你的头号盟友。如果您在一家有职业阶梯的公司，如果您正在积极寻求晋升，那么与您的经理坐下来询问您需要关注哪些领域才能获得晋升通常是一个好主意。如果您正在与队友或其他团队的人一起挣扎，您的经理应该在那里帮助您解决这种情况，并且她可以在必要时与其他人或团队合作以帮助您解决问题。不过，这通常需要你说些什么。如果你不向你的经理询问升职，不要指望她会神奇地给你一个。如果你对队友不满意，你的经理可能不会做任何事情，除非你把这个问题引起她的注意。

When it comes to your role at the company, your manager needs to be your number one ally. If you’re at a company with a career ladder, sitting down with your manager and asking her what areas you need to focus on to get promoted is usually a good idea if you are actively seeking a promotion. If you’re struggling with a teammate or a person on another team, your manager should be there to help you navigate that situation, and she can work with the other person or team as necessary to help you get to resolution. This usually requires you to say something, though. If you don’t ask your manager about a promotion, do not expect her to just give you one magically. If you’re unhappy with a teammate, your manager may not do anything unless you bring the issue to her attention.

当经理们能够识别和分配有助于我们成长和学习新事物的延伸项目时，这非常棒。然而，除了分配延伸项目之外，优秀的经理也会帮助你了解你正在做的工作的价值，即使它并不有趣或不光彩。您的经理应该是向您展示您的工作如何融入团队目标的更大图景的人，并帮助您在日常工作中感受到目标感。当您了解最平凡的工作如何为公司的整体成功做出贡献时，它就会变成一种自豪感。

It’s great when managers can identify and assign stretch projects that will help us grow and learn new things. Beyond assigning stretch projects, though, good managers will also help you understand the value of the work you’re doing even when it is not fun or glamorous. Your manager should be the person who shows you the larger picture of how your work fits into the team’s goals, and helps you feel a sense of purpose in the day-to-day work. The most mundane work can turn into a source of pride when you understand how it contributes to the overall success of the company.

随着您变得更资深，您获得的个人反馈的数量（无论好坏）都可能会减少。你在一个更高的层次上运作，你的经理在一个非常高的层次上运作。期望反馈的类型从个人反馈到团队或战略相关的输入有所改变。当你变得更高级时，更重要的是，你会感到自在地推动你的 1-1 并将主题讨论或反馈给你的经理，因为否则她不太可能在绩效评估之外花费大量时间。

As you become more senior, the amount of personal feedback you get, both good and bad, is likely to decrease. You are operating at a higher level, and your manager is operating at a very high level. Expect the type of feedback to change somewhat from personal feedback to team- or strategy-related input. It’s even more important as you become more senior that you feel comfortable driving your 1-1s and bringing topics for discussion or feedback to your manager, because she is otherwise unlikely to spend a lot of time on this outside of performance reviews.

培训和职业发展

Training and Career Growth

作为您与公司官僚机构之间​​的主要联络人，您的经理有责任帮助您找到职业发展的培训和其他资源。这可能会帮助您找到要参加的会议或要参加的课程，帮助您获得所需的书籍，或者将您指向公司其他地方可以帮助您学习的专家。

As the main liaison between you and the bureaucracy of the company, your manager holds some responsibility for helping you find training and other resources for career growth. This may be helping you find a conference to attend or a class to take, helping you get a book you need, or pointing you to an expert somewhere else in the company who can help you learn something.

经理作为提供指导和培训的人的角色并不是普遍的期望。在某些公司中，这些领域完全由您可以直接利用的培训部门管理。有些公司太小，没有钱提供大量培训，或者认为为员工提供必要的福利。

The role of manager as the person who provides mentoring and training is not a universal expectation. In some companies, these areas are entirely managed by a training arm that you can tap into directly. Some companies are too small to have the money to provide much training, or don’t think it’s a necessary perk to offer employees.

无论您在哪家公司工作，都希望您在很大程度上负责确定您想要什么样的培训类型。对于寻求技术领域培训的个人贡献者来说尤其如此。您的经理不太可能只是唾手可得的有趣会议或培训机会清单。

Whatever kind of company you work for, expect that you are responsible, for the most part, for figuring out what types of training you want. This is especially true for individual contributors looking for training in technical areas. Your manager is unlikely to just have a list of interesting conferences or training opportunities at his fingertips.

您的经理将直接为您的职业发展做出贡献的另一种方式是通过晋升和可能的补偿。如果您的公司有晋升流程，您的经理将以某种方式参与其中。对于通过委员会进行升职的公司，您的经理将指导您完成升职包的准备过程——委员会将审查的一组材料。如果您的经理或管理层直接决定升职，那么您的直属经理将在倡导您的升职并获得批准方面发挥重要作用。

The other way your manager will contribute very directly to your career growth is via promotion and, probably, compensation. If your company has a promotion process, your manager will be involved in it in some fashion. For companies that do promotion via committee, your manager will guide you through the process of preparing your promotion packet — the set of materials that the committee will review. If your manager or the management hierarchy determines promotions directly, your direct manager will be essential in advocating for your promotion and getting it approved.

无论以何种方式升职，你的经理都应该知道你是否有资格获得升职。当您对升职感兴趣时，向您的经理询问要关注的特定领域以获得升职非常重要。经理通常不能保证晋升，但优秀的经理知道系统在寻找什么，并且可以帮助您建立这些成就和技能。同样，这只是到目前为止。在更高级别的工作中，晋升的机会要少得多，您的经理可能需要您找到并提出使您有资格进入下一个级别的成就。

In whatever way promotions happen, your manager should have an idea of whether you are qualified to be promoted. When you are interested in being promoted, it’s very important to ask your manager for specific areas to focus on in order to get that promotion. Managers usually cannot guarantee promotions, but good managers know what the system is looking for and can help you build those achievements and skills. Again, this only goes so far. At more senior levels of work, opportunities for promotion are much more rare, and your manager may need you to find and propose the achievements that qualify you for the next level.

问 CTO：雄心勃勃

我刚开始工作，但我已经知道我的职业目标是有一天自己成为 CTO。我现在应该怎么做才能做到这一点？

I’ve just started working, but I already know that my career goal is to someday become a CTO myself. What should I be doing now to make that possible?

您需要学习的第一件事是如何工作。也许你已经知道这一点，但是当我刚从大学毕业时，我根本不知道如何去做这份工作。因为技术的日常工作与学校非常不同，所以你可能会学到很多关于成为一名工作工程师的过程的东西。我的具体建议是寻找一个工作场所，在那里您可以获得工作方面的指导和培训（例如测试、项目和产品管理以及协作）以及学习新的技术技能。你想建立一个坚实的技能基础，因为你需要它们才能成功。

The very first thing you need to learn is how to work. Maybe you know this already, but when I was first out of college, I didn’t really know how to do the job at all. Because the day-to-day work of tech is very different from school, there are probably a bunch of things you will learn about the process of being a working engineer. My specific advice would be to seek out a workplace where you can get mentorship and training in the aspects of doing the job (such as testing, project and product management, and collaboration) as well as learn new technical skills. You want to build a strong foundation of skills because you will need them to succeed.

我还建议您找到最好的经理和导师，并观察他们的工作。试着找一些人为他们工作，他们会推动你成功，也会奖励你成功，他们会激励你扩展自己。意识到扩展自己不仅仅是学习新技术：优秀的 CTO 除了良好的技术意识外，还具有很强的沟通能力、项目管理技能和产品意识。但是，您还想花大量时间编写代码，并真正了解如何编写高质量的代码。这可能需要几年的专注，你不能急于求成。

I also advise you to find the best managers and mentors you can, and watch them work. Try to find people to work for who push you to succeed but also reward you for success, who inspire you to stretch yourself. Realize that stretching yourself is about more than just learning new technologies: great CTOs have strong communication skills, project management skills, and product sense, in addition to good technical sense. However, you also want to spend a lot of time writing code, and getting really good at understanding how high-quality code is written. This will probably take a few years of focus, and you can’t rush it.

此外，我鼓励您创建和建立强大的同行网络。早期职业工程师通常不欣赏的一件事是他们当前的同行将如何转变为他们未来的工作。这个对等群体包括从你的同学到你的队友再到你在会议和聚会上遇到的人的每个人。有点害羞是可以的，但大多数 CTO 必须学习如何与各种各样的人交往并在公司之间建立强大的网络。

In addition, I encourage you to create and build a strong network of peers. One thing that early career engineers often don’t appreciate is how their current peers will turn into their future jobs. This peer group includes everyone from your schoolmates to your teammates to the people you meet at conferences and meetups. It’s OK to be a little bit shy, but most CTOs have to learn how to socialize with all sorts of people and create strong networks across companies.

最后要意识到的一件事是，大多数 CTO 都是小公司的 CTO。他们通常是初创公司的技术联合创始人。如果你想走这条路，最好的办法是为一家有很多离开它的人找到新公司的记录的公司工作。在这里，您将见到未来的联合创始人，并发现尽早进入新公司的机会。

One final thing to realize is that most CTOs are the CTOs of small companies. They are often the technical cofounders of startups. If you want to go down that path, the best thing to do is to work for a company that has a track record of people who have left it to found new companies. This is where you will meet your future cofounders and discover opportunities to get into new companies early.

如何管理

How to Be Managed

成为一名优秀经理的一部分是弄清楚如何进行管理。这与向上管理并不完全相同，尽管它是相关的。为自己的工作经历培养主人翁意识和权威感，而不是依靠你的经理来为你们的关系定下整个基调，这是拥有你的事业和工作场所幸福感的重要一步。

Part of being a good manager is figuring out how to be managed. This is not exactly the same as managing up, although it is related. Developing a sense of ownership and authority for your own experiences at work, and not relying on your manager to set the entire tone for your relationship, is an important step in owning your career and workplace happiness.

花时间思考你想要什么

Spend Time Thinking About What You Want

您的经理可以指出增长机会。她可以向您展示项目。她可以就您的学习和发展领域提供反馈。但她无法读懂你的想法，也无法告诉你什么会让你快乐。无论你是职场新人，还是进入职业生涯 20 年，弄清楚你想做什么、想学什么以及什么能让你快乐的责任都落在了你的肩上。

Your manager can point out opportunities for growth. She can show you projects. She can provide feedback on your areas of learning and development. But she cannot read your mind, and she cannot tell you what will make you happy. Whether you are brand new to the workplace or 20 years into your career, the onus of figuring out what you want to do, what you want to learn, and what will make you happy rests on your shoulders.

你可能会在你的生活中经历职业不确定的时期。许多人在毕业后的头两到五年内感到非常不确定，因为他们已经适应了独立的成年期。我感到非常不安，以至于我去了几年的研究生院，结果证明这是在熟悉的学术环境中寻找安全感和逃避我不知道如何很好地驾驭的工作。在攀登技术阶梯后，我再次遇到不确定性，只是在一家大公司感到有些无能为力。然后我在爬上管理阶梯后又遇到了行政领导的挑战。考虑到我的往绩记录，我预计我会每 5 到 10 年体验一次，直到我退休。

You’ll probably go through periods of career uncertainty in your life. Many people feel very uncertain in their first two to five years out of school, as they settle into independent adulthood. I felt so unsettled that I went to grad school for a couple of years, in what turned out to be a quest to find security in the familiar academic setting and an escape from a job I didn’t know how to navigate well. I hit uncertainty again after climbing the technical ladder only to feel somewhat powerless at a big company. And then I hit it again after climbing the management ladder only to encounter the challenges of executive leadership. I expect I’ll experience it every 5 to 10 years until I retire, given my track record.

当你经历职业生涯的各个阶段时，你会开始意识到世界上有多少不确定性。这是一个非常普遍的事实，一旦你得到了你认为你想要的工作，享受最终会消失，你会发现自己在寻找别的东西。你以为你想为那家很酷的初创公司工作，但你到了那里却发现它一团糟。你以为你想成为一名经理，却发现这份工作很辛苦，而且没有你预期的回报。

As you go through various stages of your career, you’ll start to realize how much uncertainty there is in the world. It’s a pretty universal truth that once you get the job you thought you wanted, the enjoyment eventually fades and you find yourself looking for something else. You think you want to work for that cool startup, and you get there only to find it’s a mess. You think you want to be a manager, only to discover that the job is hard and not rewarding in the ways you expected.

在所有这些不确定性中，您唯一可以依靠的人就是您自己。你的经理不能为你这样做。让你的经理发现你在哪里可能发生什么，但要了解自己，以便弄清楚你下一步想去哪里。

In all of this uncertainty, the only person you can rely on to pull through it is yourself. Your manager cannot do that for you. Use your manager to discover what’s possible where you are, but look to understand yourself in order to figure out where you want to go next.

你对自己负责

You Are Responsible for Yourself

认识自己是第一步。第二步是追求你想要的。

Knowing yourself is step one. Step two is going after what you want.

当您有需要谈论的事情时，将议程带到您的 1-1 中。当您想从事项目时，请询问。为自己辩护。如果您的经理没有帮助，请寻找其他地方寻求帮助。寻求反馈，包括对需要改进的领域的建设性反馈。当您收到反馈时，请客气地接受，即使您不同意。

Bring agendas to your 1-1s when you have things you need to talk about. When you want to work on projects, ask. Advocate for yourself. When your manager isn’t helpful, look for other places to get help. Seek out feedback, including constructive feedback on areas to improve. When that feedback comes to you, take it graciously, even when you don’t agree with it.

当你一直不开心时，说点什么。当你被卡住时，寻求帮助。当你想要加薪时，要求加薪。当你想要升职时，找出你需要做什么来获得它。

When you are persistently unhappy, say something. When you are stuck, ask for help. When you want a raise, ask for it. When you want a promotion, find out what you need to do to get it.

你的经理不能强迫你平衡工作与生活。如果您想回家，请弄清楚如何完成工作并回家。有时你将不得不违背文化来设定自己的界限，这会让人感到不舒服。另一方面，有时如果你想要一份更大的工作，你将不得不工作更多时间才能得到它。

Your manager cannot force work–life balance on you. If you want to go home, figure out how to get your work done and go home. Sometimes you will have to go against the cultural grain to set your own boundaries, and that will feel uncomfortable. On the flip side, sometimes if you want a bigger job, you will have to work more hours to get it.

你不会得到你所要求的一切，而且要求通常不是一种有趣或舒适的体验。然而，这是最快的前进方式。如果你的经理很认真，他会欣赏你的坦率。他可能不认真，或者他可能不喜欢你问，然后你就会知道你现在的情况。我不能保证它会顺利进行，但如果你为自己设定了一个目标，你应该尽你所能去实现它。

You will not get everything you ask for, and asking is not usually a fun or comfortable experience. However, it’s the fastest way forward. If your manager is conscientious, he’ll appreciate your candor. He may not be conscientious, or he may like you less for asking, and then you’ll know that about your current situation. I can’t guarantee you that it’ll go well, but if you’ve set a goal for yourself, you owe it to yourself to do what you can to make it happen.

让你的经理休息一下

Give Your Manager a Break

这是一份工作。你的经理有时会感到压力很大。她会不完美。她会说一些愚蠢的话，或者做一些让你觉得不公平或对你有害的事情。她会给你做你不想做的工作，当你抱怨做这件事时她会生气。她的工作是为公司和团队做最好的事情。不是不惜一切代价让你一直快乐。

This is a job. Your manager will be stressed out sometimes. She’ll be imperfect. She will say dumb things, or do things that feel unfair or harmful to you. She’ll give you work that you don’t want to do, and get annoyed when you complain about doing it. Her job is to do the best thing for the company and the team. It is not to do whatever it takes to make you happy all the time.

您与经理的关系就像任何其他密切的人际关系一样。你唯一能改变的人就是你自己。您绝对应该向您的经理提供反馈，但要明白，无论您认为她应该如何倾听或改变，她都可能不会倾听或改变。如果你发现自己出于某种原因开始积极地怨恨你的经理，你可能需要搬到另一个团队或寻找新工作。如果您发现自己对您工作的每一位经理感到不满，您可能需要考虑原因是他们还是您。也许你在没有经理的工作中会更快乐。

Your relationship with your manager is like any other close interpersonal relationship. The only person you can change is yourself. You should absolutely provide feedback to your manager, but understand that she may not listen or change no matter how much you think she should. If you find yourself starting to actively resent your manager for whatever reason, you probably need to move to a different team or look for a new job. If you find yourself resenting every manager you work for, you may need to think about whether the cause is them or you. Perhaps you’d be happier in a job where you don’t have a manager.

尤其是当你变得更高级时，请记住，你的经理希望你带来解决方案，而不是问题。尽量不要让每一个 1-1 都说明你需要什么东西，有什么问题，或者你想要更多的东西。当您遇到问题时，与其要求您的经理为您解决问题，不如尝试向她寻求有关如何解决问题的建议。寻求建议始终是表达尊重和信任的好方法。

Especially as you become more senior, remember that your manager expects you to bring solutions, not problems. Try not to make every 1-1 about how you need something, how something is wrong, or how you want something more. When you have a problem, instead of demanding that your manager solve it for you, try asking her for advice on how she might approach the problem. Asking for advice is always a good way to show respect and trust.

明智地选择你的经理

Choose Your Managers Wisely

您的经理可以对您的职业生涯产生巨大影响。因此，在评估工作机会时，不仅要考虑工作、公司和薪酬，还要考虑经理。

Your manager can make a huge difference in your career. So, as much as you can, consider not only the job, the company, and the pay, but also the manager when you are evaluating job opportunities.

强大的经理知道如何在他们的公司玩游戏。他们可以让你升职；他们可以得到重要人物的关注和反馈。强大的经理拥有强大的网络，即使您停止为他们工作，他们也可以为您提供工作。

Strong managers know how to play the game at their company. They can get you promoted; they can get you attention and feedback from important people. Strong managers have strong networks, and they can get you jobs even after you stop working for them.

强大的经理与您作为朋友喜欢的经理，甚至是您作为工程师尊重的经理之间存在差异。很多优秀的工程师之所以成为无效的管理者，是因为他们不知道或不想处理公司中的领导政治。一个强大的工程师可能会在他职业生涯的早期成为一个伟大的导师-经理，但对于一个更资深的人来说，他可能会成为一个糟糕的倡导者-经理。

There’s a difference between a strong manager and a manager that you like as a friend, or even one you respect as an engineer. Plenty of great engineers make ineffective managers because they don’t know or want to deal with the politics of leadership in their companies. A strong engineer may make a great mentor-manager to someone early in his career, but a terrible advocate-manager for someone who is more senior.

评估你自己的经历

Assessing Your Own Experience

在您发展这部分职业时，需要考虑以下一些问题：

Here are some questions to consider as you develop this part of your career:

  • 你有一个你认为好的经理吗？这位经理做了什么让你觉得有价值的事情？
  • 您多久与您的经理进行 1-1 会面？您是否与您的经理进行 1 对 1 交流，带来话题进行讨论？如果您的 1-1 是状态会议，您可以使用其他方式来传达该状态吗？
  • 当你有重大的生活事件时，你觉得你可以告诉你的经理吗？你觉得你的经理知道你个人的一些事情吗？
  • 您的经理是否向您提供了良好的反馈？反馈不好？有任何反馈吗？
  • 你的经理有没有帮助你设定今年与工作相关的目标？

第 2 章指导

Chapter 2. Mentoring

对于许多工程师来说，人员管理的第一步通常是非官方的。他们发现自己，通过抽签的运气，指导某人。

The first act of people management for many engineers is often unofficial. They find themselves, through the luck of the draw, mentoring someone.

指导对初级团队成员的重要性

The Importance of Mentoring to Junior Team Members

导师通常分配给团队的初级成员，例如刚从学校毕业的新员工或学生实习生。许多组织使用导师作为所有新员工入职流程的一部分。有时导师是团队中的另一个资历较浅的人，也许她自己才进入组织一两年；自己仍然可以清楚地记住入职或实习过程的人，并且可以与新人密切相关。其他时候，导师是一名高级工程师，除了帮助新员工加快流程速度外，他还可以担任技术导师。在一个健康的组织中，这种入职指导角色被用作双方的机会。导师有机会了解对另一个人负责是什么感觉，而被指导者则有一个只专注于他的监督者，

Mentors are commonly assigned to junior members of a team, such as new hires straight out of school or student interns. Many organizations use mentors as part of their onboarding process for all new hires. Sometimes the mentor is another junior person on the team, perhaps herself only a year or two into the organization; someone who can still clearly remember the onboarding or internship process herself, and can closely relate to the new person. Other times the mentor is a senior engineer who can act as a technical mentor in addition to helping the new hire get up to speed on the process. In a healthy organization, this onboarding mentorship role is used as an opportunity for both parties. The mentor gets the chance to see what it is like to have responsibility for another person, and the mentee gets an overseer who is focused on him alone, without other reports clamoring for his mentor’s attention.

我记得我的第一位导师，他指导我第一次认真体验作为软件工程师的工作。我是 Sun Microsystems 的实习生，在一个编写 JVM 工具的团队工作。这是我第一份需要构建真正的软件项目的工作，我很幸运有一位伟大的导师，一位名叫凯文的高级工程师。Kevin 是一位令人难忘的导师，因为尽管他是我们工作领域的高级技术负责人，但他还是为我腾出了时间。凯文没有给我看一张桌子，让我弄清楚我到底需要做什么，而是花时间和我讨论项目，和我一起坐在白板上，一起检查代码。我知道我应该完成什么，当我遇到困难时，我可以向他寻求帮助。那个夏天对我作为一名软件工程师的发展至关重要，因为在他的指导下，我开始看到我实际上可以做现实世界的工作，并且我有能力成为一名富有成效的员工。与凯文一起工作是我职业生涯的第一个重要里程碑。这段经历教会了我指导的价值。

I remember my first mentor, who guided me through my first serious taste of working as a software engineer. I was an intern at Sun Microsystems, working on a team that wrote JVM tools. This was the first job where I had a real software project to build, and I was lucky enough to have a great mentor, a senior engineer named Kevin. Kevin was a memorable mentor because, despite being a senior technical leader in the area we were working in, he made time for me. Instead of showing me a desk and leaving me to figure out what exactly I needed to do, Kevin took the time to discuss projects with me, to sit with me at the whiteboard, to go through the code together. I knew what I was expected to get done, and when I got stuck, I could ask him for help. That summer was critical for my development as a software engineer, because under his guidance I began to see that I could actually do real-world work and that I was capable of being a productive employee. Working with Kevin was one of my first major career milestones. This experience taught me the value of mentorship.

成为导师

Being a Mentor

如果你发现自己坐在导师的位置上，恭喜！这是一种并非每个人都能获得的体验：一种以相当安全的方式学习管理工作的机会，以及对他人负责的感觉。你不太可能因为作为一个糟糕的导师而被解雇（当然，除非你的行为举止不当——请不要攻击你的导师！）。对于许多导师来说，可能发生的最糟糕的情况是：a) 受指导者浪费了他们的时间，他们完成的编码工作更少，或者 b) 他们做得很差，以至于组织可能想要雇用/留住的人周围有糟糕的经历并且没有加入组织，或者选择比她原本可能更早离开组织。可悲的是，第二个结果比第一个结果更有可能。伟大的人才有时会被软弱的导师所浪费，他们无所作为，只是无视他们的指控，把时间浪费在琐碎的项目上，或者最糟糕的是，恐吓和贬低他们不想加入组织。但亲爱的读者，你不想这样做。你想成为一个伟大的导师！或者，也许您已经是一名经理，希望让您的团队在您需要他们承担的指导关系中更有效。您如何在不过度减慢发展速度的情况下建立良好、有效的指导关系？希望让您的团队更有效地处理您需要他们承担的指导关系。您如何在不过度减慢发展速度的情况下建立良好、有效的指导关系？希望让您的团队更有效地处理您需要他们承担的指导关系。您如何在不过度减慢发展速度的情况下建立良好、有效的指导关系？

If you find yourself in the mentor’s seat, congratulations! This is an experience that not everyone will get: an opportunity to learn in a fairly safe way about the job of management, and the feeling of being responsible for another person. It’s unlikely that you’ll get fired for being a bad mentor (unless, of course, you behave in an inappropriate manner — please don’t hit on your mentee!). For many mentors, the worst that can happen is that a) the mentee is a drain on their time and they get less coding work done, or b) they do such a poor job that someone whom the organization might otherwise want to hire/keep around has a bad experience and doesn’t join the organization, or opts to leave the organization sooner than she otherwise might. Sadly, the second outcome is far more likely than the first. Great talent is sometimes squandered by weak mentors who do little but ignore their charges, waste their time with trivial projects, or, worst of all, intimidate and belittle them out of ever wanting to join the organization. But you, dear reader, don’t want to do this. You want to be a great mentor! Or perhaps you are already a manager, looking to make your team more effective at the mentoring relationships you need them to take on. How do you create good, effective mentoring relationships without slowing development down too much?

指导实习生

Mentoring an Intern

我们将介绍的第一种指导关系是临时雇员。对于大多数科技公司来说，这是一个暑期实习生，一些聪明的学生仍在获得学位，并希望通过为贵公司工作获得一些宝贵的经验。此类学生的筛选过程各不相同；许多公司将这些机会视为直接从大学招聘优秀人才的渠道，但如果你要聘用的人是毕业一年多的人，那么期望候选人 a) 知道的很少，并且b) 除非他有很棒的经历，否则他明年可能会去其他地方实习。没有压力。

The first type of mentorship relationship we’ll cover is the temporary employee. For most tech companies, this is a summer intern, some bright student still in the midst of earning a degree and looking to get some valuable experience by working for your company. The screening process for such students varies; many companies view these opportunities as a pipeline to hiring great talent straight out of college, but if you’re taking on someone who is more than a year from graduation, it’s more realistic to expect that the candidate will a) know very little, and b) probably go elsewhere next year for his internship unless he has an amazing experience. No pressure.

所以你会发现自己在指导一个没有什么实际经验的大学生。你怎么能确保他的夏天很棒呢？即使你的公司不爱他，你也希望他爱你，因为他会回去告诉他所有的朋友他在你公司工作的那个夏天。这可能会对你从毕业班招聘全职员工的能力产生重大影响，而且你从那所学校招聘实习生这一事实可能表明你对招聘全职应届毕业生也很感兴趣。但别担心！让实习生开心不是火箭科学。

So you find yourself mentoring a college student with little real experience. How can you make sure that his summer is awesome? Even if your company doesn’t love him, you want him to love you, because he’ll go back and tell all his friends about the summer he had working for your company. That can have a big impact on your ability to hire full-time from the graduating class, and the fact that you pulled interns from that school probably indicates a serious interest in hiring new graduates full-time as well. But don’t worry! Making interns happy isn’t rocket science.

你需要的第一件事是让这个实习生从事某种项目。如果您作为导师没有坚持提出这个项目的想法，那就太好了，因为这样做可能是一项艰巨的任务。如果没有项目，你的实习生很可能整个夏天都完全迷失和无聊。对于有经验的员工来说，弄清楚在工作场所做什么已经够难的了，所以对于实习生来说这是一个特别高的要求。你必须有一个项目——至少是让他在最初几周开始的事情。如果您真的是空白，请查看您自己当前项目的小功能，这些小功能可能需要您几天才能完成，然后从那里开始。

The first thing you need is some sort of project for this intern to work on. It would be nice if you, as the mentor, weren’t stuck coming up with the idea for this project, because doing so can be a daunting task. Without a project, your intern has a good chance of being completely lost and bored the entire summer. Figuring out what to do in a workplace is hard enough for experienced hires, so it’s an especially tall order for an intern. You have to have a project in mind — at least something to get him started for the first couple of weeks. If you’re truly drawing a blank, look at small features of your own current project that would take you a few days to complete, and start there.

实习生的头几天将与任何新员工相似：入职、适应办公室、会见人、学习系统。在最初的几天里，尽可能多地和他坐在一起。让他开始安装 IDE 并检查代码。每天多次接触基地，以确保他不会因大量的新信息而感到迷茫或不知所措。与此同时，为他的项目做好准备。

The intern’s first few days will be similar to those of any new hire: onboarding, getting used to the office, meeting people, learning the systems. Sit with him as much as possible these first few days. Get him started installing the IDE and checking out the code. Touch base several times a day to make sure he’s not feeling lost or overwhelmed by the volume of new information. In the meantime, prepare yourself for his project.

一旦你有了一个项目，就开始将你刚刚萌芽的项目管理知识应用到手头的任务中。这个项目是否分解为里程碑？如果没有，请在实习生任期的前几天花一点时间来分解它。和你的实习生一起完成故障。对他有意义吗？倾听他的问题并回答。请记住，如果您将来决定成为经理，您正在练习您将需要的技能。在这种情况下，这些技能是倾听、沟通需要发生的事情以及适应他的反应。

Once you have a project, start applying your budding knowledge of project management to the task at hand. Is this project broken down into milestones? If not, spend a little time in the first few days of the intern’s tenure breaking it down. Walk through the breakdown with your intern. Does it make sense to him? Listen to his questions and answer them. Remember, you’re practicing skills that you will need should you decide in the future to become a manager. In this case, these skills are listening, communicating what needs to happen, and adjusting to his responses.

仔细听

Listen carefully

倾听是管理人的首要技能，也是最基本的技能。倾听是同理心的先导，同理心是质量经理的核心技能之一。无论您的职业生涯走到哪里，您都需要这项技能；即使是没有报告的首席工程师也需要能够听到其他人真正在说什么。因此，当您的学员与您交谈时，请注意您自己的行为。你是否把所有的时间都花在思考接下来要说什么上？你在考虑自己的工作吗？除了听他嘴里说的话，你还在做什么？如果是这样，你听得不好。

Listening is the first and most basic skill of managing people. Listening is a precursor to empathy, which is one of the core skills of a quality manager. You need this skill wherever your career takes you; even principal engineers with no reports need to be able to hear what others are really saying. So, when your mentee is speaking to you, pay attention to your own behavior. Are you spending all your time thinking about what you want to say next? Are you thinking about your own work? Are you doing anything other than listening to the words coming out of his mouth? If so, you’re not listening well.

无论是通过直接管理还是间接影响，领导力的早期教训之一是，人们不善于以他人可以完全理解的方式准确表达他们的意思。我们还没有实现 Borg hive mind 或 Vulcan mind 融合，所以我们不断地通过语言的针眼推动复杂的想法。语言并不是大多数工程师在细微差别和解释方面掌握的东西。因此，聆听不仅仅是聆听您的学员所说的话。当你与另一个人面对面时，你还必须解释他的肢体语言和他说这些话的方式。他在看你的眼睛吗？他在微笑吗？皱眉？叹息？这些小信号给你一个线索，让你知道他是否感到被理解。

One of the early lessons in leadership, whether it is via direct management or indirect influence, is that people are not good at saying precisely what they mean in a way that others can exactly understand. We have yet to achieve Borg hive mind or Vulcan mind meld, so we’re constantly pushing complex ideas through the eye of the needle of language. And language is not something that most engineers have mastered in nuance and interpretation. So listening goes beyond hearing the words your mentee is saying. When you’re face to face with another person, you also have to interpret his body language and the way he’s saying those words. Is he looking you in the eye? Is he smiling? Frowning? Sighing? These small signals give you a clue as to whether he feels understood or not.

准备好用不同的方式说几次复杂的事情。如果您觉得您不理解您的导师问您的问题，请以不同的方式重复该问题。让他纠正你。如有必要，使用散布在办公室各处的白板来绘制图表。花你需要花费的时间去感受被理解，就像你理解被指导者一样。请记住，在您的学员眼中，您拥有巨大的权力。他可能会担心把这个机会搞砸，尽力取悦你，努力不让自己看起来很愚蠢。即使他不明白的事情，他也可能不会问问题。让您的生活更轻松，并从他那里解决这些问题。

Be prepared to say anything complex a few times, in different ways. If you feel that you don’t understand something your mentee has asked you, repeat the question in a different way. Let him correct you. Use those whiteboards scattered around your office, if necessary, to draw diagrams. Spend the time that you need to spend to feel understood, and like you understand the mentee. And remember that you’re in a position of huge power in your mentee’s eyes. He’s probably nervous about screwing this opportunity up, trying his best to please you, and trying hard not to look stupid. He may not ask questions even when he doesn’t understand things. Make your life easier and get those questions out of him. The odds of you spending all of your time answering questions are slim compared to the odds that your intern will go off in the absolute wrong direction because he didn’t ask enough questions.

清楚地沟通

Clearly communicate

话虽如此，如果实习生确实花了太多时间向您寻求帮助，而自己却从未寻求帮助怎么办？好吧，这让你有机会学习另一种管理技能：沟通需要发生的事情。如果您希望他在问您问题之前自己进行研究，请告诉他！让他向你解释一段代码，或者一些产品或流程，并指出你认为解释它的文件。如果他连指点都做不到，那么你开始了解这位实习生的潜力。如果一切都失败了，给他项目的第一个里程碑，并告诉他单独工作一两天。这就是在实习生开始工作之前分解项目的价值所在：你已经预先接受了一些更难的思考。他可能会以比您预期的快得多的速度完成所有事情，让您大吃一惊，但拥有这样的惊喜真是令人高兴！通常，您需要在整个过程中提供一些推动和清晰，以使实习生朝着正确的方向前进。

With that said, what if the intern does spend too much time asking you for help, without ever looking for help himself? Well, that gives you an opportunity to work on another management skill: communicating what needs to happen. If you expect him to do research on his own before asking you a question, tell him so! Ask him to explain a piece of code to you, or some product or process, and point him to the documents that you believe explain it. If he can’t do it even with pointers, well, you’re starting to learn something about the potential of this intern. If all else fails, give him the first milestone of the project and tell him to work on it alone for a day or two. Therein lies the value of breaking the project down before the intern starts working on it: you’ve taken on some of the harder thinking up front. He may surprise you by finishing everything much faster than you anticipated, but what a happy surprise to have! Generally, you’ll need to provide some nudging and clarity along the way to keep the intern going in the right direction.

校准你的反应

Calibrate your response

这将我们带到您练习的最终管理技能：适应实习生的反应。在这种师徒关系的过程中会发生很多事情。他可以远远超出你的期望。他可以应付简单的任务。他可以很快地完成工作，但质量很差，或者他可以很慢地工作以产生过于完美的东西。在实习的前几周，您正在了解您需要与他联系以提供正确调整的频率。可能是每周一次。可能是一天一次。它的频率可能低于每周一次，但我建议无论如何都尝试每周检查一次，并花任何额外的时间作为公司的额外面试/销售周期。

This brings us to the final management skill for you to practice: adjusting to the intern’s responses. So many things can happen in the course of this mentoring relationship. He can far outstrip your expectations. He can struggle with simple tasks. He can produce work very quickly, but it’s of poor quality, or he can work very slowly to produce something that’s overly perfect. In the first few weeks of the internship, you’re learning the frequency that you need to check in with him to provide the right adjustments. It may be once a week. It may be once a day. It may be less frequently than once a week, but I would recommend trying to check in once a week regardless, and spending any extra time as an additional interview/sell cycle for the company.

希望夏天能以良好的方式结束。他完成了一个有一定价值的项目。你需要练习倾听、交流和调整。他留下了对您公司的快乐想法，并且您已经获得了一些关于您是否想现在、很快或永远做这件事的洞察力。恭喜！

Hopefully, the summer ends on good terms. He completed a project that has some value. You got practice listening, communicating, and adjusting. He leaves thinking happy thoughts about your company, and you have gained some insight as to whether you want to do this management thing now, soon, or ever. Congratulations!

询问 CTO：指导暑期实习生

我应该指导一名暑期实习生，但我不知道从哪里开始。实习生应该怎么做？我如何准备帮助这个人度过一个美好的夏天？

I’m supposed to mentor a summer intern, but I have no idea where to begin. What should the intern do? How do I prepare to help this person have a great summer?

准备中暑期实习生应该不会花太多时间，但这对你指导他的成功至关重要。以下是您需要做的基本事情：

Preparing for a summer intern shouldn’t take much time, but it’s crucial to your success in mentoring him. Here are the basic things you need to do:

  1. 为他的到来做好准备。你知道他哪一天来吗？如果没有，找出来。然后确保在他到达那里时为他设置物理和数字环境。他会在你附近有一张桌子吗？一台电脑？访问系统和软件？即使在大公司，实习生有时也会忽略很多这些步骤，没有什么比出现在你的大工作中无处可坐且无法访问系统更糟糕的了。
  2. 有一个项目让他工作。最好的实习是那些有明确项目的实习。决定实习生项目的诀窍是你想要一些具体但不紧急的东西，一些与团队相关的东西，但也有一些可以由入门级工程师在你的实习生一半的时间内完成的东西在那里。因此，如果他将在那里工作 10 周，给他一个您认为可能需要大约 5 周的新员工才能完成的项目。这实现了两个目标。这给了他足够的时间，所以如果他有很多其他活动要做，比如去培训或你实习计划设置的社交活动，他仍然有时间完成。如果他在程序结束之前完成它，那就太好了——他应该对你的代码库的某些部分有足够的了解，以便在剩下的时间里做其他工作。请记住，此人是实习生。
  3. 计划让他展示他在节目结束时所做的工作。这有助于他获得超越你和其他导师的曝光度，并让他明确期望你希望他完成一个项目。对于贵公司是否向该实习生提供全职工作机会，或者如果他尚未毕业，是否将他带回另一个夏天，您很可能会成为决定的重要组成部分。您可能需要花一些时间指导他如何进行演示。如果您的团队定期进行演示日或团队会议，则演示文稿可能应遵循该格式。演示文稿无需冗长或详细，但向团队展示他的工作是帮助实习生觉得他的工作很重要的好方法。我向你保证，那些觉得公司欣赏他们的工作的实习生是他们毕业后最有可能回来的人。

指导新员工

Mentoring a New Hire

我大学毕业后的第一份工作是在一家非常大的科技公司。我们称它为 BigTechCo。我被安排在一个正在发布几年的项目的团队中。我的经理带我去了我的办公室，然后让我独自一人弄清楚需要做什么。我不知道如何寻求帮助，我害怕如果我这样做会被视为傻瓜。不出所料，我气馁了，在气馁中，我决定最好的办法就是去读研究生。所以我做了。

My first job out of college was at a very large tech company. We’ll call it BigTechCo. I was put on a team that was in the midst of releasing a project several years in the making. My manager showed me to my office and then left me alone to figure out for myself what needed to be done. I didn’t know how to ask for help, and I was afraid that I would be seen as a fool if I did. Unsurprisingly, I got discouraged, and in my discouragement I decided that the best thing to do was to go to graduate school. So I did.

我从研究生院毕业的第一份工作完全不同。我没有被展示一张桌子然后一个人呆着，而是安排了一位导师。他鼓励我提出问题。我们进行了一些结对编程，以便我可以了解代码库，以及该项目的测试工作方式（我第一次尝试单元测试！）。几天之内我就很有成效，在这份工作的头几个月学到的东西比我在 BigTechCo 工作的整个时间里学到的都多。我将这几乎完全归功于我刚开始时得到的指导。

My first job out of graduate school could not have been more different. Instead of being shown a desk and left alone, I was set up with a mentor. He encouraged me to ask questions. We did some pair programming so that I could learn the code base, and the way that testing worked for this project (my first taste of unit testing!). I was productive within days, and learned more in the first few months of that job than I had learned in the entire time I worked at BigTechCo. I credit this almost entirely to the mentoring I got when I started.

指导新员工至关重要。作为新聘导师，你的工作包括入职、帮助这个人有效地适应公司的生活，以及建立你和她在公司的联系网络。这可能比指导实习生更容易，但这种关系和指导通常会持续更长时间。

Mentoring new hires is critical. Your job as a new hire mentor consists of onboarding, helping this person adjust to life in the company effectively, and building your and her network of contacts in the company. It can be an easier job than mentoring an intern, but the relationship and mentoring will usually go on for a lot longer.

这是一个让您以全新的眼光看待公司世界的机会。很难记住第一次体验你的世界是什么感觉。工作如何完成？有什么规则，说的和不说的？例如，您可能在人力资源手册中有一个标准的休假政策；这是口语规则。潜规则是感恩节后一周不要休假，因为您从事电子商务，这对企业来说是重要的一周。一个更微妙的潜规则规定了在要求别人帮助你之前，你需要自己挣扎多久。有许多过程、文化和行话是如此的第二天性，以至于你可能没有意识到它们对新手来说完全陌生。注意到这些事情让你有机会澄清它们。潜规则不仅会让新人更难加入，还会让你更难做好自己的工作。因此，充分利用这种新鲜视角的礼物。

This is an opportunity for you to see the world of your company through fresh eyes. It can be hard to remember what it was like to experience your world for the first time. How does work get done? What are the rules, spoken and unspoken? For example, you may have a standard vacation policy in the HR handbook; this is a spoken rule. The unspoken rule is that you don’t take vacation the week after Thanksgiving because you’re in ecommerce and that’s an important week for the business. A more subtle unspoken rule dictates approximately how long you are expected to struggle with something by yourself before asking someone else to help you. There are many bits of process, culture, and jargon that are so second-nature that you might not realize they’re completely foreign to a newcomer. Noticing these things gives you the opportunity to clarify them. Unspoken rules don’t just make it harder for new people to join, they can also make it harder for you to do your job well. So take full advantage of this gift of fresh perspective.

有效的团队有他们提供给新员工的良好入职文件。诸如设置开发环境的分步指南、了解跟踪系统的工作原理以及熟悉工作所需的工具等对于新员工来说至关重要。这些文件应不断发展，以适应工作场所本身的变化。通过帮助她完成文档工作来指导新员工，并让她在入职期间遇到任何意外时修改这些文档，这为她提供了一个强有力的承诺信息。这向她表明她有学习的权力和义务，并为了整个团队的利益分享她所学到的东西。

Effective teams have good onboarding documents they provide to new hires. Things like step-by-step guides to setting up their development environments, learning how tracking systems work, and familiarizing themselves with the tools they will need for the job are crucial for new hires. These documents should constantly evolve to meet the changes of the workplace itself. Mentoring a new hire by helping her work through the documents, and having her modify those documents with any surprises she encounters during onboarding, provides a powerful message of commitment to her. It shows her that she has the power and obligation to learn, and to share what she’s learned for the benefit of your whole team.

这里的部分指导机会是介绍新人的机会。公司充满了人际网络，可以快速传输知识和信息。将这个人带入你的一些人脉将帮助她更快地跟上进度，这将为你提供一个新的进入她最终形成并加入公司的任何网络的机会。计划长期在同一家公司工作的人，尤其是在大公司，通常会通过非正式网络找到机会。有一天，您的学员可能会加入您有兴趣加入的团队，或者您可能希望有一天将她带入您在另一个领域运行的团队。

Part of the mentoring opportunity here is the chance to introduce the new person around. Companies are full of human networks that exist to transmit knowledge and information quickly. Bringing this person into some of your networks will help her get up to speed faster, and it will give you a new entree into whatever networks she ends up forming and joining in her time with the company. People planning on staying with the same company for a long time, particularly in large companies, often find opportunities via informal networks. Your mentee may someday be on a team that you are interested in joining, or you may someday want to bring her into a team you are running in another area.

即使你对管理完全没有兴趣，如果没有建立一个由值得信赖的人组成的强大网络来分享信息和想法，就很难在任何拥有多个团队的公司建立职业生涯。工作场所是围绕人和他们的互动而建立的，这些网络构成了任何职业的基础，无论是专注于管理还是个人技术贡献。你可能是一个内向的人，或者一个不觉得社交容易的人，但是有意识的努力和练习去认识新朋友并帮助他们成功会得到回报。你对此的态度将决定成败。采用这样的心态，即网络建设是您的时间和精力的值得投资。

Even if you have absolutely no interest in management, it’s very difficult to build a career at any company with multiple teams without building a strong network of trusted people to share information and ideas with. The workplace is built around humans and their interactions, and these networks form the basis of any career, whether it’s focused around management or individual technical contributions. You may be an introvert, or someone who does not find socializing easy, but conscious effort and practice in getting to know new people and helping them succeed will pay off. Your attitude about this will determine success or failure. Adopt the mindset that network building is a worthwhile investment of your time and energy.

技术或职业指导

Technical or Career Mentoring

我只想就这个话题说几句话，因为这种类型的指导通常与管理路径没有直接关系。话虽如此，在我们职业生涯的某个阶段，我们大多数人都会从事某种程度的技术指导、职业指导或两者兼而有之。我们中的许多人还将获得导师，或者可能会被鼓励寻找导师。你如何才能使这种类型的指导有效？

I’m only going to say a few words on this topic, because this type of mentoring is usually not directly related to the path of management. With that said, at some point in our careers most of us will engage in some degree of technical mentoring, career mentoring, or both. Many of us will also be given a mentor, or perhaps be encouraged to find a mentor. How can you make this type of mentoring effective?

最好的指导关系在更大的工作背景下自然而然地发展。当一名高级工程师指导团队中的一名初级工程师以帮助他提高工作效率时，他们可以一起解决与他们双方相关的问题。高级工程师之所以有价值，是因为受指导者编写的代码更好，需要的修改更少，开发速度更快。初级工程师显然获得了实践指导的价值，并获得了对他工作环境有深刻理解的人的价值。这种指导通常不是正式的关系，可能是高级工程师工作的预期部分因为它为团队带来了巨大的价值。

The best mentoring relationships evolve naturally and in the context of larger work. When a senior engineer mentors a junior engineer on the team in order to help him be more productive, they can work on problems together that are relevant to both of them. The senior engineer gets value because the code written by the mentee is better, requires fewer revisions, and develops faster. The junior engineer obviously gets the value of hands-on instruction and access to someone with a deep understanding of the context he is working in. This type of mentoring is usually not a formal relationship and may be an expected part of the job for senior engineers because it delivers so much value to the team.

许多公司运行正式的指导计划，他们在团队中匹配人员，虽然这些计划有时可以增强网络，但对于指导者和被指导者来说，它们通常是一种模棱两可的义务。如果您发现自己处于其中一种关系中，那么您能做的最好的事情就是明确您的期望和目标。

Many companies run formal mentoring programs where they match people up across teams, and while these programs can sometimes enhance networks, they are often an ambiguous obligation for both the mentor and the mentee. If you find yourself in one of these relationships, the best thing you can do is be specific about your expectations and goals around it.

当你是导师

When you are a mentor

告诉你的导师你对他的期望。如果您希望他提前为您的会议做好准备，并提出他提前发送给您的问题，请提出要求。明确说明您的时间承诺。然后在他问问题时对他诚实。如果您至少不能利用这种专业距离向他提供他可能无法从经理或同事那里得到的坦率建议，那么成为相对陌生人的导师是没有意义的。

Tell your mentee what you expect from him. If you want him to come prepared for your meetings with questions he has sent you in advance, ask for that. Be explicit about your time commitment. And then be honest with him when he asks questions. There’s no point in being a mentor to a relative stranger if you can’t at least use that professional distance to offer him the kind of candid advice that he may not get from his manager or coworkers.

对指导说不也是可以的。有时您会觉得有义务对每个向您寻求帮助的人说“是”，但您的时间很宝贵。除非您认为这对您和您正在指导的人有益，否则不要这样做。如果有人让你做他的导师，你不能接受，最好只是说你做不到。不要因为他问就觉得你必须给他一个理由。当您的经理要求您指导某人而您没有时间这样做时，拒绝会比较棘手。您可能需要向您的经理提供一些理由，例如您当前的工作量、计划的假期或其他会使指导变得不可能的承诺。无论你做什么，都不要说是，然后就没有真正做好指导工作。

It’s also OK to say no to mentoring. Sometimes you can feel obligated to say yes to every person who asks you for help, but your time is valuable. Don’t do it unless you think it will be rewarding for you and the person you’re mentoring. If someone asks you to be his mentor and you can’t accept, it’s best just to say that you can’t do it. Don’t feel like you must give him a reason just because he asked. When your manager asks you to mentor someone and you don’t have the time to do it, saying no is trickier. You may need to give your manager some reasons, such as your current workload, a planned vacation, or other commitments that would make mentoring impossible. Whatever you do, don’t say yes and then fail to actually do the mentoring work.

当你是学员时

When you are a mentee

想想你想从这段关系中得到什么，并为你的会议做好准备。如果您从公司以外的人那里获得指导，这个建议尤其重要，他们没有得到报酬，而是作为一种友好的姿态志愿服务。你欠这个人不要浪费她的时间。如果您没有时间准备或觉得没有必要进行准备，请问问自己，师徒关系是否真的是您所需要的。有时我们最终会得到导师，因为有人认为我们应该拥有他们，但我们只能遇到这么多人喝咖啡，一天也只有这么几个小时。你不必有导师。也许相反，你需要一个朋友、治疗师或教练。很容易低估导师的时间，因为你通常不会为此付出代价，

Think about what you want to get out of this relationship, and come prepared to your sessions. This advice is especially relevant if you’re getting mentorship from someone outside of your company, who is not being paid but is volunteering as a friendly gesture. You owe it to this person not to waste her time. If you don’t have the time to prepare or don’t feel that preparation is necessary, ask yourself whether the mentoring relationship is really something you need at all. Sometimes we end up with mentors because someone thinks we should have them, but there are only so many people we can meet for coffee, and only so many hours in the day. You don’t have to have a mentor. Maybe instead you need a friend, or a therapist, or a coach. It can be easy to undervalue your mentor’s time, because you usually aren’t paying for it, so be respectful and consider finding a paid professional to help you instead.

好经理，坏经理：Alpha Geek

Good Manager, Bad Manager: The Alpha Geek

在某些办公室，无论是在指导关系中还是在指导关系之外，您都会遇到“阿尔法极客”。阿尔法极客被驱使成为团队中最好的工程师，总是有正确的答案，并成为解决所有难题的人。阿尔法极客重视智力和技术能力高于所有其他特征，并认为这些属性应该决定谁来做决定。Alpha 极客通常无法处理异议，并且很容易受到她认为试图抢走她的聚光灯或可能抢她风头的人的威胁。她相信自己是最好的，并且只回复支持这种观点的信息。阿尔法极客试图创造一种卓越的文化，但最终却创造了一种恐惧的文化。

In some offices, whether in a mentoring relationship or outside of one, you’ll encounter an “alpha geek.” The alpha geek is driven to be the best engineer on the team, to always have the right answer, and to be the person who solves all the hard problems. The alpha geek values intelligence and technical skill above all other traits, and believes these attributes should determine who gets to make decisions. The alpha geek usually can’t deal with dissent, and is easily threatened by those she perceives as trying to steal her spotlight or who might upstage her. She believes herself to be the best, and responds only to messages that support that view. The alpha geek tries to create a culture of excellence, but ends up creating a culture of fear.

阿尔法极客通常是一位优秀、高效的工程师，她进入管理部门要么是因为她被推到了管理部门，要么是因为她认为团队中最聪明的人应该是经理。她倾向于通过贬低他们的错误来削弱为她工作的人，在最糟糕的情况下，她会在没有警告的情况下重做队友的工作。有时，阿尔法极客会为团队所做的所有工作而功劳，而不是承认团队成员的力量。

The alpha geek is usually an excellent, effective engineer who goes into management either because she was pushed into it or because she believes that the smartest person on the team should be the manager. She tends to undermine the people who work for her by belittling their mistakes and, at her worst, redoing the work of her teammates without warning. Sometimes the alpha geek will take credit for all of the work that a team does rather than acknowledging the strength of the team members.

在他们最好的情况下，阿尔法极客可以激励年轻的开发人员，即使他们看起来很吓人。他有所有的答案。10 年前，她曾在该系统的原始版本上工作，并且仍然认识作者，如果您需要弄清楚什么，她可以毫无问题地完成。他确切地知道为什么你试图做的那件事不会奏效，当它不起作用时，相信我，他会提醒你他是如何告诉你的。要是你听他的话，按照他的方式做事就好了！Alpha 极客可以教你很多东西，如果他们愿意的话，他们可以设计伟大的系统，帮助构建这些系统很有趣。一般来说，阿尔法极客如果不是非常聪明，就不会取得他们现在的成就，所以他们确实有很多可以教给他们的团队的东西，而且许多工程师尊重这种聪明，足以忍受缺点。

At their best, alpha geeks can be inspirational to younger developers, even though they seem very intimidating. He has all the answers. She worked on the original version of that system 10 years ago and still knows the authors, and if you need to figure something out, she can do it without a problem. He knows exactly why that thing you’re trying to do won’t work, and when it doesn’t, believe me, he’ll remind you how he told you so. If only you had listened to him and done things his way! Alpha geeks have a lot to teach you, if they want to, and they can design great systems that can be fun to help build. In general, alpha geeks would not have gotten as far as they have without being very smart, so they do have a lot that they can teach their teams, and many engineers respect that intelligence enough to put up with the downsides.

在最糟糕的情况下，阿尔法极客不能让其他任何人获得任何荣耀而不为自己争取一些荣耀。它们是任何好主意的起源，但与创造坏主意无关，只是他知道它们会失败。阿尔法极客认为每个开发人员都应该确切地知道她知道什么，如果你不知道什么，她会兴高采烈地指出你的无知。阿尔法极客对于应该如何做事情可能非常严格，并且对他没有提出的新想法持封闭态度。当人们抱怨他们构建的系统或批评他们过去的技术决策时，Alpha 极客会受到很大的威胁。当他们必须从他们在智力上不尊重的任何人那里获得指导时，他们绝对讨厌它，并且可能对非技术角色的人非常贬低。

At their worst, alpha geeks can’t let anyone else get any glory without claiming some of it for themselves. They are the origin of any good ideas but had no part in creating the bad ideas, except that he knew they would fail. The alpha geek believes that every developer should know exactly what she knows, and if you don’t know something, she will gleefully point out your ignorance. The alpha geek can be very rigid about how things should be done and closed off to new ideas that he didn’t come up with. Alpha geeks get very threatened when people complain about systems they built or criticize their past technical decisions. They absolutely hate it when they have to take direction from anyone they don’t respect intellectually, and can be very demeaning toward people in nontechnical roles.

当工程师第一次成为导师时，阿尔法极客的习惯通常开始出现。如果你想知道为什么尽管你的技术能力很强，但人们似乎没有向你寻求帮助，问问自己你是否表现出一些迹象表明你是一个极客。您是否认为自己是一位不费吹灰之力并且总是说出您的想法的工程师？您是否急切地寻找陷阱、寻找错误、不愿承认其他人有一个好主意或编写了好代码？您是否认为正确性比其他任何事情都重要得多，以至于始终值得为您认为正确的事情而奋斗？

The alpha geek habit often starts to show up when engineers first become mentors. If you have ever wondered why people don’t seem to come to you for help despite your clearly strong technical skills, ask yourself whether you’re showing some signs of being an alpha geek. Do you view yourself as an engineer who does not pull any punches and always says exactly what you think? Are you eagerly seeking out the gotcha, hunting for mistakes, reluctant to admit that someone else has had a good idea or has written good code? Do you believe that correctness is so much more important than anything else that it is always worth fighting hard for what you believe to be correct?

如果您怀疑自己可能是 alpha 极客，那么指导可能是打破这种习惯的绝佳机会。如果您将您的学员视为需要教导和指导的人，您的目标是以最适合她的方式帮助她，您可以开始看到您的激进风格使她更难学习的地方。练习教学的艺术可以帮助我们学习如何培养和指导，如何措辞让别人听，而不是简单地大喊大叫。另一方面，如果您不愿意改变自己的风格来帮助学员成功，请不要自愿成为导师！

If you suspect that you may be an alpha geek, mentoring can be a great opportunity to break out of that habit. If you view your mentee as someone to teach and guide, where your goal is to help her in the way that best works for her, you can start to see where your aggressive style makes it harder for her to learn. Practicing the art of teaching can help us learn how to nurture and coach, how to phrase things so that others will listen, instead of just shouting them down. On the flip side, if you’re unwilling to change your style to help a mentee succeed, please don’t volunteer to be a mentor!

Alpha 极客是绝对糟糕的经理，除非他们能够学会放弃自己作为房间里最聪明的人和团队中最技术人员的身份。技术含量高的实践型经理可能对高级工程师的小型团队有好处，但阿尔法极客通常最好远离管理，更多地关注技术战略和系统设计。您往往会在以技术为中心的初创公司中看到担任 CTO 角色的 alpha 极客，在那里他们被赋予了设计和开发重点，而以执行为重点的工程副总裁则相反。

Alpha geeks make absolutely terrible managers, unless they can learn to let go of their identity as the smartest person in the room and most technical person on the team. Highly technical hands-on managers can be good for small teams of senior engineers, but alpha geeks are often better off kept out of management and given more of a focus on technical strategy and system design. You tend to see alpha geeks in the CTO role at technology-focused startups, where they are given a design and development focus across from an execution-focused Vice President of Engineering.

如果您曾经有能力将人员提拔到管理层，请非常非常小心地为您的 Alpha 极客团队管理职位，并密切关注他们在该角色中的影响。阿尔法极客文化可能对协作非常有害，并且会严重破坏那些感到无法反击的人。相信自己的价值来自于比其他人了解更多的阿尔法极客也可以隐藏信息以保持自己的优势，这会降低团队中的每个人的效率。

If you’re ever in the position to promote people to management, be very, very careful in giving your alpha geeks team management positions, and keep a close eye on the impact they have in that role. The alpha geek culture can be very harmful to collaboration and can deeply undermine those who feel unable to fight back. Alpha geeks who believe that their value comes from knowing more than others can also hide information in order to maintain their edge, which makes everyone on the team less effective.

给导师经理的提示

Tips for the Manager of a Mentor

你衡量什么，你就会改进。作为经理，您通过制定清晰、专注、可衡量的目标来帮助您的团队取得成功。很多时候，我们无法将这种基本智慧应用到指派导师的过程中，但它在这里和其他任何地方一样适用。当您需要为新员工或实习生分配导师时，请弄清楚您希望通过建立关系来实现什么。然后，找到可以帮助实现这些目标的人。

What you measure, you improve. As a manager you help your team succeed by creating clear, focused, measurable goals. So often, we fail to apply this basic wisdom to the process of assigning mentors, but it applies here as much as anywhere else. When you need to assign a mentor for your new hire or intern, figure out what you’re hoping to achieve by creating the relationship. Then, find the person who can help meet those goals.

首先，首先要弄清楚为什么要建立这种指导关系。在我之前讨论过的两个案例中，指导关系的存在是为了一个非常具体的目的：帮助团队中的新人，无论是全职新员工还是只待几个月的人，都能跟上进度并富有成效。当然，这些并不是公司运行的唯一一种指导计划。有时人们会设置指导计划来帮助初级人员与团队外的高级人员结对，以促进职业或技能发展。这些程序可能很好，但通常导师和被指导者除了被匹配在一起之外，得到的指导很少。大多数时候，这些计划对任何一方的收益都很少。如果导师没有参与或太忙而没有时间花时间在这个项目上，那么受指导者会感到失望。如果被指导者不知道如何寻求帮助或如何处理师徒关系，这通常会让人感觉像是被迫社交，浪费了双方的时间。因此，如果您的公司在新员工和实习生之外建立指导计划，请在推动人们加入之前尝试确保该计划有一些指导和结构。

First of all, figure out why you are setting up this mentoring relationship in the first place. In the two cases I discussed earlier, the mentoring relationship existed for a very specific purpose: helping a new person on the team, whether a full-time new hire or someone who will only be around for a few months, get up to speed and be productive. Of course, those aren’t the only kind of mentoring programs that companies run. Sometimes people set up mentoring programs to help junior people pair with senior people outside of their team, for career or skills growth. These programs can be nice, but often the mentor and mentee are given very little guidance beyond the fact that they have been matched together. Most of the time, these programs yield very little to either party. If the mentor is not engaged or is too busy to spend any time on this project, it’s a disappointment for the mentee. If the mentee doesn’t know how to ask for help or what to do with the mentoring relationship, it often feels like forced socializing and a waste of time for both parties. So if your company is setting up mentoring programs outside of new hires and interns, try to make sure that there is some guidance and structure to the program before you push people into it.

其次，认识到这是导师的额外责任。如果导师做得好，她的工作效率可能会在导师期间放缓一些。如果您有一位工程师参与了一个对时间敏感的项目，您可能不想同时推动他进行指导。因为这是一项额外的责任，所以将其视为您可能分配的任何其他重要的额外责任。寻找一个你认为可以胜任这个角色，并且想要在编码能力之外脱颖而出的人。

Secondly, recognize that this is an additional responsibility for the mentor. If the mentor does a good job, her productivity may slow down some during the mentoring period. If you’ve got an engineer involved in a time-sensitive project, you may not want to push him into mentoring at the same time. Because this is an additional responsibility, treat it as you would any other important additional responsibility you might hand out. Look for someone that you believe can succeed in the role, and who wants to distinguish herself beyond her coding ability.

无论指导安排的来源是什么，常见的指导陷阱包括将其视为地位低的“情感劳动”职位，假设“喜欢”必须指导“喜欢”，并且未能利用这个机会直接观察团队的潜力。

Whatever the source of the mentoring arrangement, common mentoring pitfalls include viewing it as a low-status “emotional labor” position, assuming that “like” must mentor “like,” and failing to use the opportunity to observe potential on your team firsthand.

情感劳动是一种思考传统女性“软技能”的方式——即解决人员和团队情感需求的技能。由于结果很难量化衡量，情绪劳动通常被认为不如编写软件重要。它被认为是应该在没有财务认可的情况下提供的东西。我并不是建议你应该付给人们额外的钱来担任导师，但他们需要为他们所做的工作得到认可，并且导师应该被视为一等公民，考虑到这个人可能承担的其他责任有。正如我之前所说，做好计划，并为导师提供时间来做好工作。你已经投资于建立这种指导关系，无论是在招聘上花费的数千美元和大量时间，或创建指导计划的开销和协调。认识到指导是一项需要时间的工作，但也会以更好的员工网络、更快的入职和更高的实习转化率的形式产生宝贵的回报，因此值得继续投资以取得成果。

Emotional labor is a way to think about traditionally feminine “soft skills” — that is, skills that address the emotional needs of people and teams. Because the outcome can be hard to quantitatively measure, emotional labor is often dismissed as less important work than writing software. It’s assumed to be something that should just be provided without financial recognition. I’m not suggesting that you should pay people extra money to serve as mentors, but they need to be recognized for the work they put in, and the mentor should be treated as a first-class citizen with respect to other responsibilities the person might have. As I said before, plan for it, and provide the mentor the time to do the job right. You have already invested in creating this mentoring relationship, whether it’s the thousands of dollars and many hours spent on hiring, or the overhead and coordination of creating a mentoring program. It’s worth continuing the investment through to fruition by recognizing that mentoring is work that takes time, but also yields valuable returns in the form of better employee networks, faster onboarding, and higher internship conversion.

当我要求你不要假设喜欢必须指导喜欢时，我的意思是你不应该期望女性只指导女性，男性只指导男性，有色人种 (PoC) 只指导其他 PoC，等等。这在指导计划中出现了很多。这些类型的指导关系有其一席之地，但作为一名科技女性，我个人厌倦了唯一专注于多样性领域的指导。当您考虑建立指导关系时，除非指导计划的目的是出于对多样性的关注，否则请为人们提供适合他们情况的最佳指导。像导师一样在一种情况下确实有意义 - 即拥有来自类似工作角色的导师。当辅导预计包含工作技能培训部分时，

When I ask you to not assume that like must mentor like, I mean that you should not expect women to only mentor women, and men to only mentor men, people of color (PoC) to only mentor other PoC, and so on. This comes up a lot in mentorship programs. These types of mentoring relationships have their place, but as a woman in tech, I personally get tired of the only mentoring being focused around lines of diversity. As you’re thinking about creating mentorship relationships, unless the purpose of the mentoring program is driven from a diversity focus, give people the best mentor for their situation. Like mentoring like does make sense in one case — namely, having mentors from similar job roles. When the mentoring is expected to have a job skills training component, the best mentors are going to be people who are further along in their mastery of the job skills that the mentee is trying to develop.

最后，利用这个机会奖励和培训团队中未来的领导者。如您所知，领导力需要人际互动才能存在。培养耐心和同理心是在基于团队的环境中工作的任何人职业道路的重要组成部分。才华横溢、内向的开发人员可能永远不想正式管理，但鼓励他们进行 1-1 指导有助于他们发展更强大的外部视角，更不用说他们自己的网络了。相反，一个不耐烦的年轻工程师在帮助实习生成功（在你的监督下）时可能会发现一定程度的谦逊。

Finally, use this opportunity to reward and train future leaders on your team. As you know by now, leadership requires human interaction to exist. Developing patience and empathy is an important part of the career path of anyone working in a team-based environment. Brilliant, introverted developers may not ever want to formally manage, but encouraging them to mentor 1-1 helps them develop stronger external perspectives, not to mention their own networks. Conversely, an impatient young engineer may find a degree of humility when tasked with helping an intern succeed (under your supervision).

询问 CTO：招聘实习生

我的公司曾多次询问我们是否雇用实习生。我们过去没有，但我很想开始这样做以增加我们的招聘人数。我应该考虑什么？

My company has had several inquiries as to whether or not we hire interns. We have not in the past, but I’m tempted to start doing this in order to increase our hiring pool. What should I be thinking about?

实习计划是公司增加招聘渠道并在毕业前找到优秀候选人的好方法。然而，许多公司认为实习计划的目标是聘请能够为他们做很多工作的实习生，因此他们错过了该计划的价值。我确实有几条建议：

Internship programs are a great way for companies to increase their hiring pipeline and find strong candidates before they graduate. However, many companies think that the goal of an internship program is to hire interns who will do a lot of work for them, and thus they miss the value of the program. I do have a couple of pieces of advice:

  • 不要雇用实习后一年内不会毕业的实习生。这些天来，技术课程的大学毕业生有很多选择，你雇用的离毕业不近的实习生不太可能回来全职为你工作。你的实习计划不是让你在夏天完成额外工作的方式；这是您识别和吸引人才的一种方式。距离毕业两年或更长时间的人可能会在承诺第一份全职工作之前寻找新的探索机会。当您只雇用少数实习生时，您希望他们所有人都有成为全职员工的高潜力。
  • 与招聘全日制毕业生相比，招聘实习生相对容易。对实习生的需求较少，因此您应该有很多选择。您可以选择以多种方式利用这个机会，但鼓励您从代表性不足的群体中招聘候选人。实习计划的多样性将转化为新毕业生招聘的多样性，进而转化为组织的多样性。

导师的关键要点

Key Takeaways for the Mentor

作为导师，重要的是要专注于自己的三项行动。

It’s important to focus on three actions for yourself as a mentor.

保持好奇心和开放的心态

Be Curious and Open-Minded

随着你在职业生涯中的成长，你会经历很多可教的时刻，很多关于事情应该如何或不应该如何的课程。这些可能是“最佳实践”，也可能是错误造成的伤痕。这种无意识的积累会影响我们的思维并降低我们的创造力。当我们闭上思绪并停止学习时，我们开始失去维持和发展成功的技术职业的最有价值的技能。我们周围的技术总是在变化，所以我们必须不断地体验这种变化。

As you grow in your career, you’ll experience a lot of teachable moments, a lot of lessons in how things should or should not be. These can be “best practices,” or scars caused by mistakes. This unconscious buildup can cloud our thinking and reduce our creativity. When we close our minds and stop learning, we start to lose the most valuable skill for maintaining and growing a successful technical career. Technology is always changing around us, so we must continually experience that change.

指导提供了一个很好的机会来培养好奇心并以全新的眼光看待世界。当面对学员的问题时，您可以开始观察您的组织对于新人来说不是那么明显。您可能会发现您认为自己理解但无法解释清楚的领域。您将有机会回顾您在工作期间收集的可能值得质疑的假设。虽然许多人认为创造力是关于看到新事物，但它也是关于看到对其他人隐藏的模式。当您拥有的唯一数据点是您自己的经验时，很难看到模式。与第一次学习事物的新人一起工作可以揭示这些隐藏的模式，并帮助你建立你可能没有建立的联系。

Mentoring provides a great opportunity to cultivate curiosity and see the world through fresh eyes. When faced with a mentee’s questions, you can start to observe what about your organization is not so obvious to a new person. You might find areas you thought you understood but cannot explain clearly.
