The goal is not to stress them out, but to help them get context into what they’re dealing with. The extreme shielders think they can best focus and motivate their teams by giving clear goals. But humans usually need some sort of context into why these goals have been set, and thereby into what problems they’re working to solve. If you’re going to have operational issues in November if a particular system isn’t up and running, your team deserves to understand that consequence. Appropriate context is what helps teams make good decisions about how and where to focus their energy. As the manager, it’s not your job to make all of those decisions by yourself.

盾牌有时会犯的另一个错误是否认外部世界存在任何戏剧。如果裁员发生在公司的另一部分并且团队从其他人那里发现，而不是保护你的团队免受戏剧性影响，你创造了一种情况，他们觉得正在发生一些不好的事情，没有人愿意承认。相反，如果您以一种直截了当、情绪低落的方式传达有关此类事件的信息，则可以减少流言蜚语并迅速消除对团队的影响。

Another error that the shield sometimes makes is denying that any drama exists in the outside world. If layoffs happen in another part of the company and the team finds out from someone else, rather than shielding your team from drama, you’ve created a situation where they feel like something bad is happening and no one wants to admit it. If you instead communicate information about such events in a straightforward, low-emotion way, you alleviate the gossip and quickly neutralize the impact on your team.

你可能是一个盾牌，但你不是父母。有时，在结合盾牌和导师的角色时，我们最终会与我们的团队建立一种育儿式的关系，并将他们视为脆弱的孩子，适当地受到保护、培养和责备。你不是他们的父母。您的团队由需要受到适当尊重的成年人组成。这种尊重对你和他们的理智都很重要。当您将他们的错误视为您自己的孩子般的延伸时，很容易将他们的错误视为个人，或者过于投入情感以至于您将他们与您的每一次分歧都视为个人。

You may be a shield, but you are not a parent. Sometimes, in combining the roles of shield and mentor we end up in a parenting-style relationship with our team, and treat them like fragile children to be protected, nurtured, and chided as appropriate. You are not their parent. Your team is made up of adults who need to be treated with appropriate respect. This respect is important for your sanity as well as for theirs. It’s too easy to take their mistakes personally when you view them as a child-like extension of yourself, or to get so emotionally invested that you take every disagreement they have with you personally.

如何做出好的决定

How to Drive Good Decisions

您在团队决策过程中的角色是什么？你知道吗？您可能有一个产品经理，他与您的团队合作并拥有产品路线图，或您的团队致力于开发的一组业务功能。您可能有一位技术主管，正如我们在第 3 章中介绍的那样，他仍然深谙技术，但也在考虑项目管理和需要完成的工作。那么，工程经理你会怎么想？

What is your role in the decision-making process for your team? Do you know? You may have a product manager who works with your team and owns the product roadmap, or the set of business features that your team has committed to working on. You probably have a tech lead who, as we covered in Chapter 3, is still deep in the technology but is also thinking about project management and the work that needs to be done. So where does that leave you, the engineering manager?

你承担的责任比你想象的要多。虽然产品经理负责产品路线图，而技术主管负责技术细节，但您通常对团队在这些元素中的每一个方面的进展负责。领导力的本质是，虽然你可能只有权指导决策而不是发号施令，但你仍然会根据这些决策的结果来判断。

You have more responsibility than you may expect. While the product manager is responsible for the product roadmap, and the tech lead is responsible for the technical details, you are usually accountable for the team’s progress through each of these elements. The nature of leadership is that, while you may only have the authority to guide decisions rather than dictate them, you’ll still be judged by how well those decisions turn out.

创建数据驱动的团队文化

Create a Data-Driven Team Culture

当您有产品或业务负责人时，她应该习惯于使用有关业务、客户、当前行为或市场潜力的数据来证明她的决定是正确的。开始将其他数据添加到组合中。例如，向该人员提供有关团队生产力的数据（例如完成功能所需的时间）或有关质量度量的数据（例如用于处理中断的时间，或者在 QA 中或发布后发现的错误数量）。这些效率和技术数据点可用于评估有关产品功能和技术变更的决策。

When you have a product or business head, she should be accustomed to using data about the business, the customers, the current behavior, or the market potential to justify her decisions. Start adding other data to the mix. For example, give that person data about team productivity (such as the time it takes to complete features) or data about quality measures (like how much time is spent dealing with outages, or the number of bugs found in QA or after releases). These efficiency and technical data points can be used to evaluate decisions on both product features and technical changes.

锻炼你自己的产品肌肉

Flex Your Own Product Muscles

强大的领导力关心培养成功和拥有一个交付成功项目的团队，这意味着磨练您对什么对您的客户重要的理解。无论您是为外部客户编写代码、为其他工程师开发工具，还是运行支持团队，您都有一些依赖于您工作输出的团队。把他们当作你的客户。花时间培养客户同理心很重要，因为您需要为工程师的工作提供背景信息。培养客户同理心还将帮助您确定技术的哪些领域对您的客户有最大的直接影响，而这种理解将指导您在哪里投入工程努力。

Strong leadership cares about cultivating success and having a team that delivers successful projects, which means honing your understanding of what is important to your customer. Whether you’re writing code for an external customer, developing tools for other engineers, or even running a support team, you have some group that depends on the output of your work. Treat them as your customers. Taking the time to develop customer empathy is important because you’ll need to give your engineers context for their work. Developing customer empathy will also help you figure out which areas of the technology have the greatest direct impact on your customers, and that understanding will guide where you invest engineering effort.

展望未来

Look into the Future

从产品和技术的角度来看，您需要提前两步思考。了解产品路线图的走向有助于您指导技术路线图。许多技术项目因其能够更轻松地启用新功能的能力而受到支持——例如，重写结账系统以插入 Apple Pay 等支付类型，或者迁移到支持通过 WebSockets 进行流式数据更改的新 JavaScript 框架模型，以构建更具交互性的体验。开始向产品团队询问有关未来可能是什么样子的问题，并花一些时间跟上可能会改变您对正在编写的软件或操作它的方式的看法的技术发展。

You need to think two steps ahead, from a product and technology perspective. Getting a sense of where the product roadmap is going helps you guide the technical roadmap. Many technical projects are supported on the strength of their ability to enable new features more easily — for example, rewriting the checkout system to plug in payment types like Apple Pay, or moving to a new JavaScript framework model that supports streaming data changes via WebSockets, in order to build a more interactive experience. Start asking the product team questions about what the future might look like, and spend some time keeping up with technological developments that might change the way you think about the software you’re writing or the way you’re operating it.

审查您的决策和项目的结果

Review the Outcome of Your Decisions and Projects

谈谈你用来激励项目的假设是否真的被证明是正确的。在你重写了那个系统之后，团队的动作真的更快了吗？当您添加新功能时，客户行为是否按照产品团队的预测方式发生了变化？你从 A/B 测试中学到了什么？在项目完成后很容易忘记审查假设，但如果你让自己和团队养成这种习惯，你总是会从你的决定中学习。

Talk about whether the hypotheses you used to motivate projects actually turned out to be true. Was it true that the team moved faster after you rewrote that system? Did customer behavior change in the way the product team predicted when you added the new feature? What have you learned from your A/B tests? It’s easy to forget to review assumptions after the project is done, but if you make this a habit for yourself and your team, you’ll always learn from your decisions.

对流程和日常进行回顾

Run Retrospectives for the Processes and Day-to-Day

敏捷过程通常在每两周的开发冲刺结束时举行一次回顾会议，在那里您讨论冲刺期间发生的事情并选择一些事件（好的、坏的或中性的）进行详细讨论。无论您是以敏捷方法还是其他方式工作，常规流程回顾对于检测模式和强制对决策结果进行清算都有很大的价值。团队是否对他们如何获得需求感觉良好？他们对代码质量感觉良好吗？此过程可帮助您了解您随着时间的推移所做的决定如何影响您的团队在日常工作中的运作方式。这种方法比收集有关团队健康的数据更主观，但可以说它比许多客观指标更有价值，

Agile processes usually have a retrospective meeting at the end of each two-week development sprint, where you discuss what happened during the sprint and pick a few events — good, bad, or neutral — to discuss in detail. Whether you work in an agile methodology or some other fashion, the regular process retrospective has a lot of value for detecting patterns and forcing a reckoning with the outcome of decisions. Is the team feeling good about how they get requirements? Do they feel good about the code quality? This process helps you learn how the decisions you make over time affect the way your team operates in the day-to-day. This approach is more subjective than gathering data about the team’s health, but it’s arguably even more valuable than many objective measures, because it comes from the things the team itself is noticing and struggling with or celebrating.

好经理，坏经理：冲突避免者，冲突驯服者

Good Manager, Bad Manager: Conflict Avoider, Conflict Tamer

杰森的团队工作过度。每个人都知道查尔斯应该致力于大型系统重写，但他已经有几个月没有从事自己的宠物项目了。在听到有关 Charles 没有为新系统提供帮助的投诉后，Jason 召集团队并要求他们投票决定应该放弃哪些项目以减少工作量。任何人投票放弃查尔斯的宠物项目都不足为奇——也就是说，除了查尔斯之外的任何人都不足为奇，他从未从杰森那里听到过任何关于这件事的消息，并且认为他在做正确的事。

Jason’s team is overworked. Everyone knows that Charles should be working on the big system rewrite, but he’s been off on his own pet project for months. After hearing complaints that Charles isn’t helping with the new system, Jason calls the team together and asks them to vote on what projects should be dropped to get the workload down. It’s no surprise to anyone that they vote to drop Charles’s pet project — no surprise, that is, to anyone except Charles, who has never heard anything about this from Jason and who figured he was doing the right thing.

杰森的球队感受到了压力，部分原因是杰森似乎没有与其他球队一起为他们挺身而出。他讨厌对新项目说不，但他也不会要求更多的人来帮助管理负载。杰森很酷，每个人都同意，但要让他真正采取行动解决冲突或做出艰难的决定是非常困难的。结果，团队过度劳累，努力确定前进的优先顺序，并且在其成员中怀有数起怨恨。

Jason’s team is feeling the crunch partly because Jason doesn’t seem to stand up for them with other teams. He hates to say no to new projects, but he also doesn’t ask for more people to help manage the load. Jason is cool, everyone agrees, but it is so hard to get him to actually act on resolving conflicts or making difficult decisions. As a result, the team is overworked, struggles to prioritize a way forward, and is nursing several grudges among its members.

莉迪亚的团队也感到紧张，她有自己的查尔斯要对付。她向查尔斯保证，他将有时间参与这个项目，但很明显，优先事项已经改变，因此他的工作需要随之改变。在与 Charles 的 1-1 中，Lydia 解释了当前的工作量，并告诉 Charles，他的团队需要他帮助进行系统重写。Charles 很不高兴，Lydia 不喜欢这种谈话，但她知道作为团队的经理，她有责任确保他们专注于最重要的项目。

Lydia’s team is also feeling crunched, and she has her own Charles to deal with. She promised Charles that he would get time to work on this project, but it’s clear that priorities have changed and so his work will need to change with them. In her 1-1 with Charles, Lydia explains the current workload, and tells Charles that his team needs him to help with the system rewrite. Charles is unhappy, and Lydia doesn’t enjoy this conversation, but she knows that as the manager of the team, she’s responsible for making sure they’re focused on the most important projects.

Lydia 知道这个项目对团队来说很重要，所以在她争取更多人的同时，她确保团队知道她为什么决定接手这个大项目。她与团队合作确定工作的优先级，并通过遵循呈现选项和征求反馈的结构来指导他们解决他们对使用何种技术的分歧。Lydia 的团队形容她强硬但公平，虽然意见不合，但团队善于应对挑战，合作良好。

Lydia knows that this project is important for the team to own, so while she pushes for more people, she makes sure that the team knows why she decided to take on this big project. She works with the team to prioritize the work, and guides them through their disagreements on what technology to use by following a structure for presenting options and soliciting feedback. Lydia’s team describes her as tough but fair, and though disagreements happen, the team is good at getting through challenges and collaborates well.

当用如此鲜明的术语表达时，很明显杰森没有很好地处理冲突，而莉迪亚正在驯服它。虽然看起来 Jason 的民主风格应该会导致一个被授权的团队，但他无法拒绝或对任何决定承担责任意味着没有人感到非常安全。很难知道 Jason 的球队接下来会发生什么，因为他没有指导球队，而是让球队自己指导。

When put in such stark terms, it seems pretty clear that Jason is not handling conflict well, while Lydia is taming it. While it seems like Jason’s democratic style should lead to an empowered team, his inability to say no or to take the responsibility for any decisions means that no one feels very secure. It’s hard to know what’s going to happen next on Jason’s team because instead of guiding the team, he’s having the team guide itself.

拥有一个不断争吵和不同意的团队是痛苦的，并且可能非常不正常。但存在人为和谐之类的东西，避免冲突的管理者倾向于支持和谐而不是功能性工作关系。为分歧自行解决创造一个安全的环境比假装所有分歧都不存在要好得多。

Having a team that is constantly bickering and disagreeing is painful, and can be very dysfunctional. But there is such a thing as artificial harmony, and conflict-avoidant managers tend to favor harmony above functional working relationships. Creating a safe environment for disagreement to work itself out is far better than pretending that all disagreement does not exist.

管理冲突的注意事项

The Dos and Don’ts of Managing Conflict

  • 不要完全依赖共识或投票。共识在道德上可能看起来具有权威性，但这假设参与投票过程的每个人都是公正的，在各种结果中拥有平等的利益，并且对背景有相同的了解。在每个人具有不同专业水平和不同角色的团队中，这些条件很少能满足。当团队否决查尔斯的工作时，共识可能是彻头彻尾的残酷。不要让人们为你知道会失败的投票而设置，而不是承担作为经理自己传递坏消息的责任。
  • 做建立清晰的流程来消除决策的个性化。当您希望允许群体决策时，群体需要有一套明确的标准来评估决策。从对目标、风险和要回答的问题的共同理解开始，然后再做出决定。当您将决策的所有权分配给团队中的某个人时，请明确应该咨询团队中的哪些成员以获得反馈，以及哪些人需要被告知决策或计划。
  • 不要对正在酝酿的问题视而不见。避免冲突的另一种表现方式是在问题持续太久之前无法解决问题。作为经理，如果您在绩效评估过程中给出负面反馈，这对您的员工来说应该不会是一个重大惊喜。在撰写评论之前，您可能没有考虑到细微差别，但是如果某人的工作存在重大问题，则该人应该在您注意到它们时立即知道它们。如果您自己没有注意到这些问题，而是在审查过程中通过几个同行的反馈了解了这些问题，那不是一个好兆头。这可能表明您没有集中注意力，也没有在 1-1 中为您的团队腾出空间与同事讨论他们遇到的问题。
  • 一定要解决问题，不要闹剧。解决冲突和培养功能障碍是有区别的。你想留出空间让人们表达沮丧，但要注意发泄情绪和真正的人际关系问题之间的区别。使用您的判断来决定应该解决什么以及应该放弃什么。要问的关键问题是：这是一个持续存在的问题吗？这是你个人注意到的吗？这是团队中许多人都在努力解决的问题吗？是否存在权力动态或潜在偏见？目标是找出导致团队合作效率降低的问题并解决它们，而不是成为团队的治疗师。
  • 不要在其他团队中使用它。具有讽刺意味的是，避免冲突的经理经常在涉及其他团队时寻求冲突。他们对自己的团队有强烈的认同感，并且会对他们认为来自外人的威胁做出积极的反应。当出现问题时，例如跨团队的事件，经理会变成恶霸并要求为他的团队伸张正义，或者将问题归咎于其他团队。有时，这种行为是经理对自己团队的压抑情绪的一种发泄方式。正如一位朋友所说，“我没有告诉我的员工 10% 的事情需要改进，因为我担心他们会错过关于 90% 好的事情的信息，所以我接受了对问责制的渴望出在其他球队。我真的只是希望每个人都负起全部责任，
  • 做记住要善良。想要被其他人喜欢是自然而然的人性。我们中的许多人认为，被人喜欢的方式就是被视为友善——友善本身就是目标。然而，你作为经理的目标不应该是善良，而应该是善良. “Nice”是礼貌社会的语言，你试图与陌生人或熟人相处。尼斯正在说“请”和“谢谢”，并为那些在行李或婴儿车中挣扎的人提供门。当被问及你的情况时，Nice 会说“我很好”，而不是“我的心情非常糟糕，我希望你别管我”。在随意的谈话中，Nice 是一件好事。但作为经理，你的人际关系会更深，友善更重要。告诉没有准备好升职的人她还没有准备好，并用她需要做的工作来支持这一点是很好的。引导那个人说“也许你可以升职”然后看着她失败是不友善的。告诉某人他在会议中的行为正在扰乱团队，这很好。很尴尬，也很不舒服
  • 不要害怕。避免冲突往往源于恐惧。我们害怕做出决定的责任。我们害怕看起来要求太高。我们担心如果我们给他们不愉快的反馈，他们会退出。我们害怕人们不喜欢我们，或者当我们冒这个风险时我们会失败。有些恐惧是自然的，对冲突的结果敏感是一种明智的习惯。
  • 做好奇。思考你的行为是对抗冲突恐惧的最佳方式。我将这个决定推给团队是因为他们真的是最适合做决定的人，还是我只是害怕如果我做出一个不受欢迎但必要的决定，人们会生我的气？我是否避免与我的同事一起解决这个问题，因为她真的很难共事，还是我只是希望问题会自行解决，因为我不想讨论它并且可能是错误的？我是因为我的员工今天真的过得很糟糕而且这只是一次性的，所以我推迟给我的员工这个反馈，还是因为我害怕如果我告诉他他会不喜欢我作为经理，我推迟了？仔细考虑你的行为，你不太可能会寻找不必要的冲突。

具有挑战性的情况：团队凝聚力破坏者

Challenging Situations: Team Cohesion Destroyers

创建职能团队的关键要素之一是建立能够良好且愉快地一起工作的团队。我曾经接受过一个快乐的工程团队的测试：“如果你在晚上给他们买披萨，他们会留下来一起社交，还是会尽快跑出去？”

One of the critical elements of creating functional teams is building teams that work well and happily together. I was once given a test of a happy engineering team: “If you buy them pizza in the evening, will they stick around and socialize together, or will they race out the door as quickly as possible?”

我对此有一些小问题。有义务每天在严格的时间带他们离开办公室的员工与那些愿意站在周围聊天的人一样投入或更少。然而，更大的一点仍然是一个好点。大多数凝聚在一起的团队都有一种同志情谊，这让他们在一起开玩笑、喝咖啡、分享午餐，并且彼此友好。他们可能有他们尊重的义务和工作之外的激情，但他们并不认为他们的团队是他们每天都渴望逃避的东西。

I have some quibbles with that. Employees with obligations that take them out of the office at a strict time every day are no more or less engaged than those who are willing to stand around and chat. The larger point, however, is still a good one. Most gelled teams have a sense of camaraderie that makes them joke together, get coffee, share lunch, and feel friendly toward one another. They may have obligations they respect, and passions outside of work, but they don’t view their team as something they’re eager to escape every day.

这里真正的目标是心理安全——也就是说，一个团队的成员愿意承担风险并在彼此面前犯错。这是一个成功团队的基础。凝聚团队的工作始于创造导致心理安全的友善。您可以通过花时间了解人们作为人类并询问他们的课外生活和兴趣来鼓励这一点。让他们分享他们觉得舒服的分享。询问他们孩子的生日派对过得怎么样，他们的滑雪之旅怎么样，他们的马拉松训练怎么样。这不仅仅是空谈；它促进了相关性，人们作为个体的感觉，而不仅仅是匿名的齿轮。

The real goal here is psychological safety — that is, a team whose members are willing to take risks and make mistakes in front of one another. This is the underpinning of a successful team. The work of gelling a team begins by creating the friendliness that leads to psychological safety. You can encourage this by taking the time to get to know people as human beings and asking them about their extracurricular lives and interests. Let them share what they feel comfortable sharing. Ask how their child’s birthday party went, how their ski trip was, how their marathon training is going. This is more than empty small talk; it fosters relatedness, the sense of people as individuals and not just anonymous cogs.

除了您个人培养相关性之外，您还希望您的团队之间有自己的相关性。当公司谈论招聘“文化契合度”时，他们通常意味着他们想雇用他们可以友好的人。虽然这可能会产生一些不良后果，例如歧视，但它来自一个明智的地方。友好的团队更快乐，凝聚得更快，并且往往会产生更好的结果。我的意思是，你真的想每天和一群你讨厌的人一起去上班吗？

Beyond you personally cultivating relatedness, you want your teams to have their own relatedness among themselves. When companies talk about hiring for “culture fit,” they often mean they want to hire people they can be friendly with. While this can have some unwanted consequences, such as discrimination, it comes from a wise place. Teams that are friendly are happier, gel faster, and tend to produce better results. I mean, do you really want to go to work every day with a bunch of people you hate?

这就是为什么那些破坏团队凝聚力的人如此成问题的原因。他们的行为方式几乎总是让团队中的其他人很难在他们周围感到安全。我们将这些员工称为“有毒”，因为他们往往会使与他们接触的每个人的效率降低。快速处理它们是良好管理的重要组成部分。

This is why those who undermine team cohesion are so problematic. They almost always behave in a way that makes it hard for the rest of the team to feel safe around them. We refer to these employees as “toxic” because they tend to make everyone who comes into contact with them less effective. Dealing with them quickly is an important part of managing well.

辉煌的混蛋

The Brilliant Jerk

有毒员工的一种变体是聪明的混蛋，正如我们之前讨论的那样，她个人产生了巨大的结果，但又是如此自我驱动，以至于她几乎在她周围的每个人中都产生了恐惧和厌恶的混合。聪明的混蛋所面临的挑战是，她的才华可能已经得到了很长一段时间的奖励，而且她像救生筏一样紧紧抓住它。承认世界上除了纯粹的智力或生产力之外还有其他价值，这将挑战她在世界上的地位，而且对她来说往往是一个可怕的提议。所以她用她的智慧欺负人，以严厉的方式减少反对的声音，无视那些她认为与她不相称的人，让她对任何她认为是愚蠢的事情的挫败感公开地渗出。

One variant of the toxic employee is the brilliant jerk, who, as we discussed earlier, produces individually outsized results, but is so ego-driven that she creates a mixture of fear and dislike in almost everyone around her. The challenge of the brilliant jerk is that she’s probably been rewarded for a very long time for her brilliance, and she clings to it like a life raft. Acknowledging that there is value in the world beyond sheer intelligence or productivity would challenge her place in the world and tends to be a scary proposition for her. So she bullies with her intellect, cutting down dissenting voices in a harsh way, ignoring those she believes are not her equal, and letting her frustration with anything she sees as stupid seep out openly.

如今，大多数地方都声称他们不会容忍聪明的混蛋，但我个人认为这不是真的。经理很难证明解雇一个工作出色的人是合理的，即使她会消耗她周围的每个人——尤其是如果这个人只是不规则的混蛋。多少混蛋太多了？你开始围绕这个想法跑圈，试图证明让她继续工作的合理性。你给她反馈，她会在一段时间内好转，但随后会变得更糟。

These days, most places claim that they don’t tolerate brilliant jerks, but I personally don’t believe that is true. It’s incredibly hard for a manager to justify getting rid of someone who produces great work, even though she’s a drain on everyone around her — especially if this person is only irregularly a jerk. How much jerk is too much? You start to run rings around the idea to try to justify keeping her on. You give her feedback, and she gets a little bit better for a while, but then she gets worse.

避免聪明混蛋综合症的最好方法就是不雇用一个。一旦他们被录用，摆脱出色的混蛋需要一定程度的管理信心，我认为这是不常见的。幸运的是，这些人经常会摆脱自己，因为即使你可能没有勇气解雇他们，你也不太可能愚蠢到提拔他们。对？希望如此。

The best way to avoid brilliant jerk syndrome is to simply not hire one. Once they’re hired, getting rid of brilliant jerks takes a level of management confidence that I think is uncommon. Fortunately, these folks will often get rid of themselves, because even though you may not have the guts to fire them, it’s unlikely that you’ll be stupid enough to promote them. Right? Let’s hope so.

需要一个强大的经理来处理船上的一个聪明的混蛋。期待她在所有反馈上与您战斗。这对你们俩都不容易。困难在于，如果她不认为自己的行为有问题，她就不会改变它。单靠你不可能让她相信她的行为是个问题。世上所有的证据都无法改变一个不想改变的人。

It takes a strong manager to deal with a brilliant jerk onboard. Expect her to fight you tooth and nail on all feedback. This isn’t going to be easy on either of you. The difficulty is, if she doesn’t see her behavior as a problem, she won’t change it. It’s unlikely that you alone will be able to convince her that her behavior is a problem. All the evidence in the world can’t change a person who doesn’t want to change.

在拥有出色的混蛋的情况下，您可以为您的团队做的最好的事情就是简单而公开地拒绝容忍不良行为。这可能是少数几个颠覆“公开表扬，私下批评”的例子之一。当一个人的不良行为对团队有明显的影响，并且你不希望你的文化模仿时，你需要在当下说些什么来明确标准。“请不要那样对人说话；这是不尊重的。” 你会想要严格控制自己的反应，因为在公共场合传达这个是走一条好路。如果你看起来情绪化，它可能会破坏你。冒犯者可能会把你的反馈写成只是情绪，或者你可能会认为是在挑剔对方。保持反馈中立，但如果您要立即提供反馈，请保持中立，在公众场合。请注意，这种方法只能用于您认为对整个团队有害的行为。如果您只是认为这个人在私下损害您的利益，请私下讨论。你的首要目标是保护整个团队，第二个目标是保护团队中的每个人，最后一个目标是保护自己。

The best thing you can do for your team, in the context of having a brilliant jerk, is to simply and openly refuse to tolerate bad behavior. This may be one of the few instances where “praise in public, criticize in private” is upended. When a person is behaving badly in a way that is having a visible impact on the team, and a way you don’t want your culture to mimic, you need to say something in the moment to make the standard clear. “Please do not speak to people that way; it is disrespectful.” You’ll want to have tight control of your own reaction because delivering this in public is walking a fine line. If you seem emotional, it may undermine you. The offender may write off your feedback as just emotion, or you may come off as picking on the person. Keep the feedback neutral but to the point if you are going to deliver it in the moment, in public. Note that this approach should only be used for behavior you feel is detrimental to the whole group. If you just think the person is undermining you personally, discuss it in private. Your first goal is to protect your team as a whole, the second is to protect each individual on the team, and your last priority is protecting yourself.

非沟通者

The Noncommunicator

另一个非常常见的问题团队成员是不沟通者——对你、对他的队友、对他的产品经理隐藏信息的人。喜欢秘密工作并在一切都完成并完美后揭开神奇项目的人。不是与队友讨论事情，而是恢复他们的提交，或者拿走他们的票并为他们做工作的人。不想通过代码审查并且不要求对大项目进行设计审查的人。

Another very common problem team member is the noncommunicator — the person who hides information from you, from his teammates, from his product manager. The person who prefers to work in secret and unveil a magical project when everything is done and perfect. The person who, instead of talking things out with teammates, reverts their commits, or takes their tickets and does the work for them. The person who doesn’t want to go through code review and who doesn’t ask for design review on big projects.

这个团队成员惹恼了他周围的每个人。作为不沟通者的经理，你必须尽快将这种隐藏信息的习惯扼杀在萌芽状态。如有必要，请明确说明他没有达到对工作的期望。这通常是一种恐惧的表现——这个人害怕被人发现缺乏，或者他会被要求做他不感兴趣的工作。有时这是一个人觉得自己应该有更多责任的标志不尊重他的经理。不管是什么原因，这个人破坏了团队凝聚力，因为他没有与其他队友合作；他觉得分享他正在进行的工作并不安全，他的恐惧常常为团队的其他成员树立榜样。

This team member annoys everyone around him. As the noncommunicator’s manager, you have to nip this information-hiding habit in the bud as soon as possible. If necessary, make it clear that he’s not meeting expectations for his work. This is often a sign of fear — the person is afraid that he’ll be found lacking, or he’ll be asked to do work he’s not interested in. Sometimes it’s a sign of a person who feels he should have more responsibility and who doesn’t respect his manager. Whatever the cause, this person disrupts team cohesion because he isn’t being collaborative with the rest of his teammates; he doesn’t feel safe sharing his work in progress, and his fear often sets an example for the rest of the team.

如果可能，请解决隐藏的根本原因。如果隐藏者害怕被批评，你的团队是否有需要解决的苛刻文化？您的团队总体上是否具有这种心理安全感？团队的其他成员是否将这个人视为局外人，可能是因为他的背景或技能不同？如果团队拒绝个人，您将需要决定是尝试纠正团队还是将个人转移到另一个团队。有时，移动个人是最仁慈的事情；其他时候，最好的解决方案是与整个团队合作，改变文化的平衡，打破排斥新人的习惯。

If possible, address the root cause of the hiding. If the hider is afraid of being criticized, does your team have a harsh culture that needs to be addressed? Does your team have that psychological safety in general? Is the rest of the team treating this person like an outsider, perhaps because he has a different background or skill set? If the team is rejecting the individual, you will need to decide whether to try to correct the team or move the individual to another team. Sometimes, moving the individual is the kindest thing to do; other times, the best solution is to work with the team as a whole to change the balance of culture and break the habits that exclude new people.

缺乏尊重的员工

The Employee Who Lacks Respect

第三种有毒的人是根本不尊重你作为经理的人，或者不尊重她的队友的人。解决这个人会很困难，你可能需要经理的帮助，但如果你能自己处理这个问题，那就是一个很好的品格的标志。简而言之，如果您的团队成员不尊重您或她的同事，她为什么要在那里工作？问她是否想在你的团队中工作。如果她说她愿意，请清楚而冷静地列出您的期望。如果她说她没有，请开始将她转移到另一个团队的过程，或者帮助她离开公司。

The third type of toxic individual is the person who simply doesn’t respect you as a manager, or who doesn’t respect her teammates. Addressing this person will be difficult and you may require some help from your manager, but if you can handle this yourself, it’s a sign of great character. Simply put, if your team member doesn’t respect you or her peers, why is she working there? Ask her if she wants to be working on your team. If she says she does, lay out what you expect, clearly and calmly. If she says she doesn’t, start the process to move her to another team, or help her leave the company.

而已？而已。你不能让一个不尊重你或不尊重你的团队的人为你工作。它会侵蚀团队其他成员的凝聚力，因为他们想知道那个人不尊重你是否正确。越早取下创可贴越好。

That’s it? That’s it. You can’t have a person working for you who doesn’t respect you, or doesn’t respect your team. It will eat away at the cohesion of the rest of the team as they wonder whether that person is right in not respecting you. The sooner you pull off the Band-aid, the better.

高级项目管理

Advanced Project Management

作为工程经理，您将帮助为您的团队制定时间表。当较大的组织试图弄清楚季度或年度的计划可能是什么样子时，您将估计您的团队是否可以完成某些项目、这些项目的工作量以及您是否有合适的人来完成工作。您可能会被问到，除了当前的承诺之外，您的团队是否可以接受旧系统的支持，或者您需要雇用多少人来支持新计划。该组织希望您能够进行即兴估算和更具体的项目规划。

As an engineering manager, you will help set the schedule for your team. As the larger organization tries to figure out what the plans for the quarter or year might look like, you’ll estimate whether your team can do certain projects, how much work those projects will be, and whether you have the right people to complete the work. You might be asked if your team can take on the support of old systems in addition to their current commitments, or how many people you’d need to hire in order to support a new initiative. The organization will expect you to be capable of doing both off-the-cuff estimation and more concrete project planning.

我们在第 3 章关于成为技术主管的讨论中对项目管理进行了高级概述，但现在我想深入研究一些高级工作。作为团队的经理，虽然您可能会将一些项目计划推给您的技术主管，但您可能需要自己做一些工作。您可能必须决定要承担哪些项目，以及何时推迟接受项目。您可能会被要求粗略估计何时完成工作，甚至是以敏捷方式计划和迭代的工作。

We gave a high-level overview of project management in Chapter 3’s discussion of being a tech lead, but now I want to dig into some of the advanced work. As the manager of a team, while you may push some of the project planning onto your tech leads, you’ll likely need to do some of that work yourself. You may have to decide which projects to take on, and when to push back on accepting projects. You’ll probably be asked for rough estimates as to when work will be done, even work that is planned and iterated on in an agile fashion.

您需要对团队的节奏和节奏有强烈的认识，才能成功管理他们的工作量，但幸运的是，有一些捷径可以提供帮助。

You need to have a strong sense of the rhythms and pace of your team to manage their workload successfully, but fortunately there are some shortcuts that can help.

项目管理经验法则

Project Management Rules of Thumb

以下是一些需要牢记的经验法则。

Here are some rules of thumb to keep in mind.

这些都不能替代敏捷项目管理

None of this is a replacement for agile project management

在开始之前，我想明确一点，我并不是建议您进入瀑布模式并从一开始就详细计划每个项目。然而，大多数团队都有高层次的长期目标和短期目标，这将使他们能够实现这些目标。在实际规划较小部分的细节时，团队协作划分和粗略估计工作的敏捷过程对于平滑和组织日常工作非常有效。作为经理，您不会试图破坏甚至拥有执行过程的那一部分。然而，你要对更大的图景负责——以几个月而不是几周来衡量的成就——这就是你必须开始进行一些更高层次的计划的地方。

Before I begin, I want to make clear that I’m not suggesting that you go into waterfall mode and plan every project in detail from the get-go. However, most teams have both high-level, long-term goals, and short-term objectives that will enable them to meet those goals. When it comes to actually planning the details of the smaller pieces, an agile process where the team collaborates to divide and roughly estimate work is very effective at smoothing and organizing the day-to-day. As the manager, you’re not trying to disrupt or even own that part of the execution process. However, you are responsible for the larger picture — the accomplishments that are measured in months instead of weeks — and this is where you have to start exerting some higher-level planning.

每位工程师每季度有 10 个高效的工程周

You have 10 productive engineering weeks per engineer per quarter

一年有 52 周，或每季度约 13 周。但是，实际上您的团队将失去很多时间。假期、会议、审查季节、生产中断、新员工入职——所有这些事情都让人无法专注。不要期望每个团队成员每季度在主要项目上投入超过 10 周的时间。第 1 季度（紧接寒假之后）可能效率最高，而第 4 季度（包括冬季和年终假期的季度）可能效率最低。

There are 52 weeks in a year, or about 13 per quarter. However, realistically your team will lose a lot of that time. Vacations, meetings, review season, production outages, onboarding new employees — all of these things take away from focus. Don’t expect to get more than 10 weeks’ worth of focused effort on the main projects per team member per quarter. It’s likely that Q1 (immediately after the winter holidays) will be the most productive and Q4 (the quarter that includes winter and the end-of-year holidays) will be the least productive.

预算 20% 的时间用于全面的通用维持工程工作

Budget 20% of time for generic sustaining engineering work across the board

我所说的“通用的持续工程工作”是指测试、调试、清理遗留代码、迁移语言或平台版本，以及做其他必须完成的工作。如果你养成了这个习惯，你可以每季度用它来处理一些中型遗留代码并获得不错的改进。随时清理系统使这些系统易于使用，从而使您的团队在新功能上不断前进。在最坏的情况下，您可以使用这种松弛来解决功能开发中的意外延迟，但如果您将计划安排到 100% 进行功能开发，预计功能开发将由于这种过度计划而迅速放缓。

By “generic sustaining engineering work,” I mean testing, debugging, cleaning up legacy code, migrating language or platform versions, and doing other work that has to happen. If you make this a habit, you can use it to tackle some of the midsize legacy code every quarter and get decent improvements. Cleaning up systems as you go keeps those systems easy to work in, which keeps your teams moving forward on new features. In the worst case, you can use this slack to smooth over unexpected delays in feature development, but if you fill the schedule to 100% with feature development, expect that the feature development will quickly slow down as a result of this overscheduling.

当你接近最后期限时，你的工作就是说不

As you approach deadlines, it is your job to say no

你几乎肯定会有偶尔的最后期限，要么是你设定的目标日期，要么是从高处降下来的目标日期。实现这些目标的唯一方法是在项目结束时缩小范围。这意味着，作为工程团队负责人，您将与您的技术负责人和产品负责人/业务代表合作，找出哪些“必备品”实际上不是必备品。你将不得不对双方说不。有时工程团队会说如果不做一些其他技术工作他们不可能实现一个特性，你需要弄清楚什么时候推动一个 hack 实现，什么时候阻止正确的实现。将有一些产品功能需要显着的工程复杂性才能实现，你需要与产品团队一起找出真正的必备品，同时解释实现他们愿景的成本。当事态发展时，您将成为团队选择的人，以决定什么可以实际实施，或者需要多少时间才能完成所有工作。

You will almost certainly have occasional deadlines, either goal dates that you’ve set or goal dates that came down from on high. The only way to achieve these goals is to cut scope at the end of the project. That means that you, as the engineering team lead, will partner with your tech lead and the product lead/business representative to figure out what “must-haves” are not actually must-haves. You will have to say no to both sides. There will be times when the engineering team will say that they can’t possibly implement a feature without doing some other technical work, and you will need to figure out when to push for a hack implementation and when to hold back for the right implementation. There will be product features that require significant engineering complexity to implement, and you’ll need to work with the product team to figure out the real must-haves while explaining the cost to get to their vision. When push comes to shove, you’ll be the person to give the team options as to what can realistically be implemented, or how much more time getting everything in will require.

使用加倍规则进行快速估算，但推动计划时间以估算更长的任务

Use the doubling rule for quick estimates, but push for planning time to estimate longer tasks

流行的软件估计加倍规则是，“每当要求进行估计时，请猜测并加倍。” 当你被要求进行即兴猜测时，这条规则是合适的并且很好用。但是，当您谈论您认为需要超过几周时间的项目时，请继续将估算值加倍，但要明确表示您需要一些计划时间才能确定时间表。有时，较长的任务将花费您估计的两倍以上，在您将团队投入到一个未知的大型项目之前，花一些时间更仔细地计划是值得的。

The popular doubling rule of software estimation is, “Whenever asked for an estimate, take your guess and double it.” This rule is appropriate and good to use when you’re asked for an off-the-cuff guess. However, when you’re talking about projects that you think will take longer than a couple of weeks, go ahead and double the estimate, but make it clear that you’ll need some planning time before you’re sure about the timescale. Sometimes the longer tasks will take far more than twice your estimate, and it’s worth spending some time planning more carefully before you commit your team to a big, unknown project.

对你给团队带来的估计有选择性

Be selective about what you bring to the team to estimate

我强调你在这个估计和规划过程中的角色的部分原因是，让工程师不断要求他们进行随机项目估计的经理会分散注意力和压力。作为经理，您有责任处理不确定性并限制您向团队暴露的不确定性。不要成为工程师和公司其他人之间的电话，来回鹦鹉学舌，分散那些忙于你已经承诺完成的重要任务的人的注意力。但你也不是黑洞。尝试建立一个团队范围的流程来讨论新功能和客户投诉，并限制在此流程之外发生的估计。

Part of the reason that I stress your role in this estimation and planning process is that it’s distracting and stressful for engineers to have a manager who’s constantly asking them for random project estimates. As the manager, you’re responsible for handling uncertainty and limiting how much of that uncertainty you expose to your team. Don’t be a telephone between the engineers and the rest of the company, parroting messages back and forth and distracting people who are busy with the important tasks you’ve already committed to do. But you’re not a black hole, either. Try to get a teamwide process in place for talking about new features and customer complaints, and limit estimations that occur outside of this process.

询问 CTO：加入小团队

我是一个由五名工程师组成的团队的新聘经理。我之前在其他公司担任过经理，但我对公司、技术和团队都是全新的。在最初的几周里，我应该如何看待我的时间？

I’m a newly hired manager for a team of five engineers. I have been a manager before at other companies, but I’m brand new to the company, the technology, and the team. How should I think about my time in these first few weeks?

作为经理加入一个小团队是很困难的。当你从软件工程师晋升为经理时，平衡技术工作是一回事，但与新的团队一起管理和学习新代码是另一回事。

Joining a small team as a manager is tough. It’s one thing to balance technical work when you’ve been promoted to manager from software engineer, but it’s another thing to come in new with a team to manage and new code to learn.

有几种方法可以在不打扰团队的情况下进入软件。首先，让某人带您了解系统和架构，以及测试和发布软件的过程。如果有一个正常的开发人员入职流程，您可以在其中学习如何检查代码和部署系统，请完成该流程。花一些时间熟悉代码库，并开始观看代码审查或拉取请求（如果存在）。

There are a few ways to get into the software without annoying the team. First, get someone to walk you through the systems and architecture, as well as the process for testing and releasing the software. If there is a normal developer onboarding process where you learn how to check out code and deploy the systems, go through that process. Spend some time getting comfortable in the code bases, and start watching the code reviews or pull requests, if they exist.

计划在前 60 天内至少开发几个功能。采用指定的功能并添加它。与其中一位工程师就他正在开发的功能配对，并在您开始开发自己的功能时让他与您配对。让团队成员审查您的代码。如果支持是团队职责的一部分，则执行发布，并轮换支持系统至少几天。

Plan to work on at least a couple of features in your first 60 days. Take a specced-out feature and add it. Pair with one of the engineers on a feature he’s working on, and have him pair with you as you start working on a feature of your own. Get your code reviewed by a member of the team. Perform a release, and do a rotation of supporting the systems for at least a couple of days if support is part of the team’s responsibilities.

您可能会说这意味着您的管理层入职可能会更慢，因为您也在学习如何在系统中工作。这种放缓是值得的。通过了解代码、编写代码的过程以及团队日常使用的工具和系统，您将获得管理团队所需的理解，以及他们看到您所需的技术可信度作为一个有能力的领导者。

You can probably tell that this means your management onboarding may go more slowly because you’re also learning how to work in the systems. This slowdown is worth it. By getting to know the code, the processes for writing code, and the tools and systems your team use for their day-to-day, you will gain the understanding necessary for managing the team, and the technical credibility necessary for them to see you as a capable leader.

评估你自己的经历

Assessing Your Own Experience

  • 什么既然你是一个团队的经理，你的新职责是什么？为了腾出时间来承担这些新职责，您停止了哪些任务或将其交给了其他人？
  • 您觉得自己对团队中编写、部署和支持代码的日常挑战的了解程度如何？
  • 您的团队多久将工作标记为已完成？
  • 您上一次编写功能、调试问题或与团队成员合作处理他或她正在努力处理的代码是什么时候？
  • 是否有一两个团队成员对团队造成了很大的负面影响？你有什么计划来解决前进的问题？
  • 您的团队成员看起来是否彼此参与？他们在会议上微笑吗？在聊天中开玩笑？一起喝咖啡还是一起吃午饭？你们最后一次坐在一起不谈工作是什么时候？
  • 你的团队如何做出决定？您是否有分配决策责任的流程？你认为自己要为做出哪些决定负责？
  • 您最后一次审查已完成的项目以查看其是否已实现目标是什么时候？
  • 您的团队对他们为什么要从事他们正在从事的项目的理解程度如何？
  • 您上一次削减项目范围是什么时候？你用什么来确定要切割的部分？

第 6 章管理多个团队

Chapter 6. Managing Multiple Teams

欢迎来到多团队管理的世界！在讨论管理经理之前，我们将讨论管理多个团队，因为虽然这些事情是相关的，但它们不一定一致。不过，您现在可能有技术主管向您报告，并且在直接管理超过三四个人的工作与了解几个团队正在发生的事情的细节的过程中兼顾可能意味着一件重要的事情：您不是在写作（很多，任何，生产）代码。

Welcome to the world of multiple-team management! We’re going to talk about managing multiple teams before we talk about managing managers, because while those things are related, they don’t necessarily coincide. You probably have tech leads reporting to you now, though, and juggling the work of directly managing more than three or four people with the process of understanding details about what’s happening across a couple of teams probably means one important thing: you’re not writing (much, any, production) code.

当我为之前的工作创建职业阶梯时，工程总监角色通常是一个人开始管理多个大型团队的地方。让我们回顾一下我的工程阶梯中的一些描述：

When I created the career ladder for my previous job, the director of engineering role was usually the place where a person would start to manage multiple large teams. Let’s review some of the description from my engineering ladder:

工程总监负责技术团队的一个重要领域。工程总监通常带领工程师跨越多个产品领域或多个技术功能。技术主管和个人贡献者都向他们报告。
通常不期望工程总监每天编写代码。但是，工程总监负责其组织的整体技术能力，并在必要时通过培训和招聘来指导和提高整个团队的能力。他们应该拥有强大的技术背景，并花一些时间研究新技术并紧跟科技行业的趋势。他们将被期望帮助调试和分类关键系统，并且应该充分了解他们监督的系统，以执行代码审查并根据需要帮助研究问题。他们应该主要通过作为精通技术的声音向团队中的工程师询问业务和产品问题，从而为架构和设计工作做出贡献，
工程总监主要关注确保复杂交付物的顺利执行。为此，他们专注于确保我们不断评估和完善我们的开发/基础设施标准和流程，以创造能够为业务带来持续价值的技术。他们负责创建高性能、高速的组织，随着我们作为企业的成长和发展，对流程进行衡量和迭代。他们是组织招聘、员工管理和规划、职业发展和培训的领导者。必要时，董事将管理供应商关系并参与预算过程。
工程总监的影响力应该跨越技术组织的多个领域。他们负责在组织中培养和培养下一代领导和管理人才，并帮助这些人才学习如何平衡技术与人员的领导和管理。他们痴迷于创建高效、敬业和积极进取的组织，并且期望他们在组织内拥有保留目标。此外，工程总监负责战略性地平衡以产品/业务为中心的近期和长期工作与技术债务和战略技术开发。
董事是强有力的领导者，他们为技术与公司其他领域之间以及跨技术部门的跨职能协作树立了榜样。此次合作的目标是制定战略和战术技术路线图，以解决业务需求、效率和收入以及基础技术创新。主管是一个非常强大的沟通者，他既可以简化技术概念向非技术合作伙伴解释它们，又可以以启发和指导他们的方式向技术团队解释业务方向。工程总监帮助为 Rent the Runway 技术创造积极的公众形象，并能够将公司及其区域出售给潜​​在的候选人。
由于他们对技术和业务驱动因素的广泛接触，董事负责指导其组织中所有团队的目标设定过程，帮助这些团队阐明支持业务计划以及技术和组织质量的目标。

我努力确保我们指出工程总监不一定每天都在编写代码，因为我认为一个负责多个团队的实际管理的人编写代码是非常困难的。到目前为止，您的日程安排可能已经从“制造者”转移到“经理”。在您的 1 对 1、与其他工程负责人的会议、团队计划会议以及与您的同行在产品管理或其他业务职能方面的会议期间，您可能非常忙碌。在这一点上对你的日程安排要现实一点。如果你没有足够的时间来专注于它，并且你不能切实保证每周至少有几天的时间，那么你编写的任何代码都会非常缓慢。

I took pains to make sure that we called out the fact that engineering directors would not necessarily be writing code every day, because I believe that it is very difficult for a person responsible for hands-on management of multiple teams to write code. Your schedule, by this point, has probably moved away from “maker” and firmly into “manager.” Between your 1-1s, meetings with other engineering leads, team planning sessions, and sessions with your peers in product management or other business functions, you’re probably quite busy. Be realistic about your schedule at this point. If you don’t have solid blocks of time to dedicate to it and you can’t realistically guarantee solid blocks of time at least a few days a week, any code you write is going to be very slow-going.

对我们来说幸运的是，有一些方法不需要编写大量生产代码就可以亲自动手。代码审查是在实践中坚持下去的好东西，至少作为二级审查者是这样。如果您在更亲力亲为时创建了系统，请与这些系统保持互动，因为您会比大多数人更好地记住细节，并且您可以通过代码审查和问题帮助在这些系统中工作的工程师。调试和生产支持也很有价值。你如何保持动手能力取决于你的技能。如果您在进入管理部门之前不是一个强大的调试器，那么跳入事件可能比有用更烦人。结对编程或修复小错误或功能可能对您更有帮助。我们常常认为这些小努力不值得，

Fortunately for us, there are ways to stay hands-on that don’t require writing a lot of production code. Code reviews are a good thing to stay in practice with, at least as a secondary reviewer. If you created systems when you were more hands-on, stay engaged with those systems, because you’ll remember the details better than most, and you can help engineers working in those systems with code reviews and questions. Debugging and production support are also valuable. How you stay hands-on depends on your skill set. If you were not a strong debugger before you went into management, jumping into incidents may be more annoying than useful. You may be more helpful doing pair programming, or fixing minor bugs or features. So often we diminish these small efforts as not worthwhile, but they’re very good at keeping you in tune with the feeling of software development and showing your teams that you are willing and able to help out with the day-to-day in a valuable way.

如果你在进入这个角色之前没有花足够的时间编码来让自己深入、流利地使用至少一种编程语言，那么放手的风险就会大大增加。我强烈建议你在进入管理层之前花时间掌握编程。对我来说，这花了大约 10 年，包括我的本科和研究生学位。你可能比我做得更快，但在这方面要仔细检查自己。在花费有限的时间来熟悉编写它的基础知识、使用标准开发环境和在标准框架中工作之后，你是否觉得至少一种编程语言足够流利，可以有效地为用它编写的良好代码库做出贡献和图书馆？最终，即使是最深的知识也会萎缩，

The risk of going hands-off is greatly amplified if you don’t spend enough time coding before moving into this role to get yourself deeply, fluently comfortable with at least one programming language. I advocate strongly that you spend the time to gain mastery of programming before moving into management. For me, this took about 10 years, including my undergraduate and graduate degrees. You may do it faster than I did, but scrutinize yourself carefully in this regard. Do you feel fluent enough in at least one programming language to productively contribute to a good code base written in it, after a limited time spent getting up to speed in the basics of writing it, using a standard development environment, and working in standard frameworks and libraries? Eventually even the deepest knowledge will atrophy, but fluency in working in a language (which includes comfort with its standard tools, libraries, and runtimes) is something that sticks with you for a long time.

有用的流利程度还需要对使用这种语言高效工作意味着什么有根深蒂固的理解，希望在与其他人一起构建生产软件的团队中。如果没有这种构建软件的节奏感，您将在这个级别的工作的关键部分之一上挣扎：调试团队问题并保持您的团队顺利生产高质量的软件。

Useful fluency also requires an ingrained understanding of what it means to work productively in such a language, hopefully on a team with other people building production software. Without this sense of the rhythms of building software, you’ll struggle with one of the critical parts of the job at this level: debugging team issues and keeping your teams producing quality software smoothly.

最后，即使你不打算写太多代码，我强烈建议你每周至少有半天的时间完全摆脱会议或其他义务，并尝试将这段时间至少部分用于一些创意追求。您可以为您的工程博客撰写博客文章、准备会议演讲或参与开源项目。做一些事情来消除创意之痒，否则你作为经理可能很难去抓挠。

Finally, even if you don’t intend to write much code, I strongly advise you to keep at least a solid half-day once a week completely free from meetings or other obligations, and try to use this time at least partially on some creative pursuit. You might write blog posts for your engineering blog, prepare conference talks, or participate in an open source project. Do something to scratch that creative itch, which can otherwise be hard for you to scratch as a manager.

问 CTO：我想念代码！

我管理着两个复杂的团队，而我的管理职责迫使我从技术职责中退缩。我发现我非常想念代码。这是否表明我不应该成为经理？

I’m managing two complex teams and my management responsibilities are forcing me to step back from technical responsibilities. I find that I miss code terribly. Is this a sign that I shouldn’t be a manager?

几乎每个从重度动手技术角色转变为管理角色的人都有一个过渡期，他们经常质疑自己是否犯了错误。此外，许多人担心他们会在此过程中失去所有宝贵的技能。问问自己，你是否已经内化了管理不是一份工作的想法。科技行业充斥着鄙视管理的人，认为管理不如编写代码重要。但管理是一项工作，是一项必要且重要的工作，尤其是你现在的工作。

Almost everyone who goes from a heavily hands-on technical role into management has a transition period where they question frequently whether they’ve made a mistake. Furthermore, many worry that they’re losing all of their valuable skills in the process. Ask yourself whether you’ve internalized the idea that management is not a job. The tech industry is filled with people who despise management, thinking it’s not as important a job as writing code. But management is a job, it is a necessary and important job, and in particular, it’s your job right now.

编写代码充满了快速的胜利，特别是对于有经验的开发人员。你让测试通过，你看到新特性变得生动，你得到了一些东西要编译，你解决了一个问题。管理层很少有明显的快速获胜，尤其是对于新经理而言。对更简单的时代感到渴望是很自然的，那时只有你和你的电脑，而你不必与所有这些凌乱、复杂的人类打交道。当你第一次开始全职工作时，你可能对你的学生时代有类似的怀念，因为当你离开学校时，你就知道从中会发生什么。怀念那些简单的时代是可以​​的，对你放弃的东西有点恐惧。但是你不能一次做所有事情。成为一名出色的经理需要您专注于管理技能，这需要放弃一些技术重点。这是一种权衡，你必须决定你是否愿意做。

Writing code is full of quick wins, especially for the experienced developer. You make tests pass, you see new features come to life, you get something to compile, you fix a problem. Management has fewer obvious quick wins, especially for new managers. It’s natural to feel some longing for simpler times, when it was just you and your computer and you didn’t have to deal with all these messy, complicated humans. You probably felt some similar nostalgia for your school days when you first started working full-time, because by the time you left school you knew exactly what to expect from it. It’s OK to feel nostalgia for the simpler times, and a little bit of fear for what you’re giving up. But you can’t do everything all at once. Becoming a great manager requires you to focus on the skills of management, and that requires giving up some of your technical focus. It’s a tradeoff, and one you’ll have to decide if you’re up to making.

管理你的时间：重要的是什么？

Managing Your Time: What’s Important, Anyway?

当你有太多的管理职责以至于你没有时间编写代码时，你会开始觉得你的一天被别人的一时兴起当作人质。你开始看到会议堆积如山：一对一、计划会议、状态更新。站立。坐下。打架打架！

When you have so many management duties that you have little time to code, you can start to feel like your day has been taken hostage by the whims of others. You start to see the meetings pile up: the one-on-ones, the planning meetings, the status updates. Standups. Sit-downs. Fight fight fight!

等等，不——不要在作战室打架！

Wait, no — no fighting in the war room!

是时候——现在——让你弄清楚如何管理你的时间。否则，你会发现自己的日子已经过去，几乎没有什么可展示的。你仍然有作为经理的责任。除了参加会议之外，您仍然需要做更多的可交付成果——例如为团队设定目标、帮助您的产品团队在产品路线图上添加详细信息，以及确保分配的任务实际完成。如果你不小心，最后一个，跟进任务完成，可能会成为你一天中最大的时间沉没和分心之一。

It’s time — now — for you to figure out how to manage your time. Otherwise, you’ll find yourself with days gone by and little to show for them. You still have responsibilities as a manager. You still have deliverables that require you to do more than sit in a meeting — things like setting goals for the team, helping your product team put details on the product roadmaps, and making sure that an assigned task actually got finished. That last one, following up on task completion, can become one of the biggest time sinks and distractions in your day if you aren’t careful.

时间管理是个人的事情。有些人非常有条理，这些人制定了复杂的策略来管理他们的日历和待办事项列表。我为这些人鼓掌。我通常不是其中之一。但是，我发现 David Allen 的《Getting Things Done 1 》一书中的想法很有用，即使您没有采用整个过程，我也建议您阅读它。

Time management is a personal thing. Some people are very organized, and those people develop complex strategies for managing their calendars and to-do lists. I applaud these people. I am not generally one of them. However, I have found the ideas in David Allen’s book Getting Things Done1 to be useful to think about, and I recommend reading it even if you don’t adopt the whole process.

与此同时，无论你的策略是什么，我的一般时间管理理念都会很好地为你服务。管理你的时间归结为一件重要的事情：理解重要性和紧迫性之间的区别。几乎所有的任务都将落在这两个元素的图表上。粗略地说，它们位于四个象限之一（见表 6-1）。

In the meantime, my general time-management philosophy will serve you well no matter what your tactics might be. Managing your time comes down to one important thing: understanding the difference between importance and urgency. Pretty much all of your tasks will fall on a graph of these two elements. Roughly, they are in one of four quadrants (see Table 6-1).

表 6-1。优先考虑你的时间
不紧急 紧急

重要的

Important

战略：腾出时间

Strategic: make time

明显的工作

Obvious work

不重要

Unimportant

明显避免

Obvious avoid

诱人的分心

Tempting distractions

如果它很重要和紧急，你正在做。你知道我在说什么。您正在帮助修复一个重大中断。绩效评估报告将于明天到期。您想向一位出色的候选人提出要约，而该候选人的另一项竞争要约将在两天内到期。如果你把球丢在这个类别的任务上，你就会失去一些有形的东西。您不太可能对完成这些事情的需要视而不见。

If it’s important and urgent, you’re doing it. You know what I’m talking about. There’s a major outage that you’re helping to fix. Performance review write-ups are due tomorrow. You want to make an offer to a great candidate who has another competing offer expiring in two days. If you drop the ball on a task in this category, you lose something tangible. It’s unlikely that you’re blind to the need to get these sorts of things done.

当你开始失去重要性时，时间管理的很大一部分挑战就出现了。紧迫性往往比重要性更明显。回复电子邮件就是一个很好的例子。很容易被电子邮件吸引来分散注意力，因为红点告诉你有新的东西，你很迫切地需要承认它。然而，电子邮件真正紧急的频率是多少？电子邮件可能是传达紧急、时间敏感信息的最糟糕的工具。感觉很紧急，但并不紧急。这就是为什么这么多精确的时间管理技巧鼓励在一天中的特定时间阅读和回复电子邮件的原因。我们也倾向于用明显代替紧急在确定某物的价值时。如果您的日历上有一个会议，那么您当时应该在哪里是很明显的，但是那个会议真的很紧急，还是您使用它来避免考虑使用时间的最佳方式？

A big part of the challenge of time management emerges when you start to lose the sense of importance. Urgency is often more clearly felt than importance. Responding to email is a good example. It’s easy to get sucked into email as a distraction, because the red dot tells you there’s something new, and it feels urgent to you to acknowledge it. And yet how often is email really urgent? Email is probably the worst vehicle for conveying urgent, time-sensitive information. It feels urgent, but it isn’t urgent. This is why so many precise time-management tips encourage reading and responding to email at specific times of the day. We also tend to substitute obvious for urgent in determining something’s value. If a meeting is on your calendar, it’s obvious where you should be at that time, but is that meeting really urgent, or are you using it to avoid thinking about the best way to use your time?

有很多感觉紧急但并不紧急的事情。例如，整个互联网。新闻、脸书、推特。聊天可能会让人感觉很紧急，但在一个并置团队的情况下，聊天几乎和电子邮件一样糟糕，无法传达真正紧急和重要的信息。我们已经将现代科技工作场所的大量沟通从电子邮件转移到了 Slack 和 HipChat 等聊天系统中。这有利有弊，但重要的是要注意移动通信与消除通信不同。文字和信息不断流动，它们只是移动到不同的地方，而聊天中不断变化的信息流会让您更加分心。

There are many things that feel urgent that aren’t. The whole of the internet, for example. News, Facebook, Twitter. Chat can feel urgent, but chat is almost as bad as email for communicating truly urgent and important information in the case of a collocated team. We’ve moved a lot of communication in the modern tech workplace out of email into chat systems like Slack and HipChat. This has benefits and drawbacks, but it’s important to note that moving communication is not the same thing as eliminating communication. The words and information keep flowing, they just move to different places, and you can get even more distracted by the ever-moving trickle of information in chat.

很可能你把很多时间花在紧急但稍微重要的事情上，而牺牲了重要但不紧急的事情。一个重要但不紧急的任务的例子实际上是为会议做准备，以便您可以以健康的方式指导他们。健康的会议需要各方的参与，以及有利于简短但富有成效的会议的文化要求参与者做一些前期工作来准备参加会议。作为多个团队的经理，您可以通过将有效的会议文化推广到您的团队来赢回大量时间。让人们负责以任何有意义的方式进行准备。提前询问议程项目。任何涉及一群人的标准会议，无论是计划、回顾或事后分析，都应该有明确的程序和预期的结果。

It’s likely that you’re spending a lot of your time on things that are urgent but only slightly important, and sacrificing things that are important but not urgent. One example of an important but not urgent task is actually preparing for meetings so that you can guide them in a healthy way. Healthy meetings require involvement from all parties, and a culture that favors short but productive meetings requires that participants do some up-front work to come to the meeting prepared. As a manager of multiple teams, you can win back a lot of time by pushing an efficient meetings culture down to your teams. Hold people accountable to prepare in whatever way makes sense. Ask for agenda items up front. Any sort of standard meeting that involves a group of people, whether it’s planning, retrospective, or postmortem, should have a clear procedure and expected outcomes.

与上一级别相比，此级别的主要变化之一是您的老板会期望您足够成熟，能够独立管理自己和您的团队。这意味着你的经理相信你会在所有重要但不紧急的事情变得紧急之前主动处理它们，尤其是在它们对你的经理来说变得紧急之前。没有人会告诉你如何管理你的日历，让自己有时间去做这件事。我看到经理们在这一点上失败了，因为他们无法以有组织的方式处理所有不同的任务。

One of the major changes at this level compared to the previous level is that your boss will expect you to be mature enough to manage yourself and your teams independently. This means that your manager trusts you to proactively deal with all those important but not urgent things before they become urgent, and especially before they become urgent for your manager. No one will tell you how to manage your calendar to give yourself the time to do this. I’ve seen managers fail at this point because they just could not juggle all the different tasks in an organized fashion.

会议可能属于紧急但不重要的类别，您可能会决定在没有明确需要的情况下不参加会议。在此特定管理级别过度部署此策略时要非常小心。让您的团队成功前进并愉快地参与其中的责任就在您的肩上。当你停止参加他们所有的内部会议时，你可能会错过帮助你及早发现问题的线索——一个主要问题是存在太多无聊的会议。在会议期间，环顾您的团队的房间并注意他们的参与度。如果他们中的一半人睡着了，盯着太空看，在他们的手机或笔记本电脑上忽略了程序，或者以其他方式离开，会议就是在浪费他们的时间。你参加这些会议部分是为了关注你团队的活力和士气。一个快乐的团队会感到精力充沛和投入。一个不快乐或没有动力的团队会感到筋疲力尽或无聊。

Meetings can fall into that urgent but not important category, and you may decide to simply not attend them where you’re not clearly needed. Be very careful with over-deploying this strategy at this particular level of management. The responsibility of keeping your teams successfully moving forward and happily engaged is on your shoulders. When you stop going to all of their internal meetings, you run the risk of missing out on the very clues that will help you catch problems early — a major one being the existence of too many boring meetings. During meetings, look around the room at your team and notice their engagement. If half of them are falling asleep, staring off into space, on their phones or laptops ignoring the proceedings, or otherwise disengaged, the meeting is wasting their time. Your attendance at these meetings is partially to pay attention to the dynamics and morale of your team. A happy team will feel energized and engaged. An unhappy or unmotivated team will feel drained or bored.

回到重要但不紧急的事情。考虑未来是这份清单的重中之重。毫无疑问，有些事情你知道你应该做但却推迟了。也许它正在为您正在招聘的角色编写工作描述。也许它正在制定招聘计划。它可能是审查一个项目的当前工作，以确保没有明显的问题出现，或者与另一个团队的经理交谈，在如何推进一个共同的问题上存在冲突或意见分歧。它可能正在培养重要的事情清单，但你有一段时间没有考虑过，所以你知道应该关注什么。如果你不留出一些时间专注于这些问题，它们就会以消极的方式悄悄地接近你。作为多个团队的经理，您负责平衡思考的广度和深度，

Back to matters important but not urgent. Thinking about the future is high on this list. There are undoubtedly things that you know you should do but have put off. Perhaps it’s writing job descriptions for roles you’re hiring for. Perhaps it’s developing a hiring plan at all. It might be reviewing the current work on a project to make sure no obvious problems are creeping in, or talking to a manager on another team where there is conflict or a difference of opinion on how to move forward on a shared issue. It might be cultivating the list of things that are important but you haven’t thought about in a while, so you know what to focus on. If you don’t set aside some time to focus on these issues, they’ll sneak up on you in negative ways. As a manager of multiple teams, you’re responsible for balancing breadth and depth of thinking, for knowing the details of your teams today but also looking at where you need to be going in the future and what you need to get there.

当你履行新的义务时，开始问自己：我正在做的事情有多重要？是否因为紧急而显得重要？这周我花了多少时间在紧急的事情上？我是否设法为不紧急的事情腾出足够的时间？

As you navigate your new obligations, start to ask yourself: How important is the thing I’m doing? Does it seem important because it is urgent? How much time have I spent this week on urgent things? Have I managed to carve out enough time for things that are not urgent?

成为经理最难、最短的一课

作为一名经理，我有一张关于我的团队需要什么的心理清单。我正在监控的事情，我试图修复的事情，我试图为他们找到的事情。我的工作是了解正在发生的事情以及整个团队需要什么才能有效。

As a manager, I have this mental list of things about what my team needs. Things that I’m monitoring, things that I’m trying to fix, things that I’m trying to find for them. It’s my job to understand what is going on and what the team as a whole needs to be effective.

也许你可以看看事情的状态，然后说，“我们现在有一个截止日期，我们需要的是下个月的另一位工程师。那个工程师就是我。”

Maybe you can look at the state of things and say, “We have a deadline right now, and what we need is another engineer for the next month. That engineer is me.”

但更有可能的是，您查看事物的状态并意识到您的团队需要的是一名经理。因为你需要雇佣 X 更多的人。因为 Y 有很大的潜力，但需要一些指导。因为产品或设计或其他团队没有给你你需要的东西，所以你需要去拿它。因为过程很重要，而您拥有的过程是不充分的或完全错误的。

But more likely you look at the state of things and realize that what your team needs is a manager. Because you need to hire X more people. Because Y has a lot of potential but needs some coaching. Because product or design or some other team hasn’t given you what you need, so you need to go and get it. Because process is important, and the process you have is insufficient or just plain wrong.

如果你的团队需要一个经理而不是一个工程师，你必须接受这样的事实：作为那个经理意味着你不能成为那个工程师。我知道有些人两者都能做到，但你需要决定，如果你要在其中一个烂透，那会是哪一个。

If your team needs a manager more than they need an engineer, you have to accept that being that manager means that you by definition can’t be that engineer. I know some people manage both, but you need to decide, if you’re going to suck at one, which one that will be.

当我不擅长成为一名工程师时，我感觉很糟糕，但不擅长成为一名经理将是我强加给其他人的选择。这不公平。

I feel bad when I suck at being an engineer, but sucking at being a manager would be a choice I inflicted on other people. That’s not fair.

因此，在另一天结束时，当我觉得我没有编写足够的代码并且无法量化我所取得的成就时，我告诉自己，我是一名尽我所知的优秀经理。这对于今天来说已经足够了。

So at the end of another day when I feel like I didn’t write enough code and I have no way to quantify what I’ve achieved, I tell myself I was being as good a manager as I know how to be. And that has to be enough for today.

凯特休斯顿

Cate Huston

决定和授权

Decisions and Delegation

这些天结束时你感觉如何？如果您像许多新的全职经理一样，您可能会感到非常筋疲力尽。即使你没有写很多代码——或者任何代码！——一整天，当你回到家时，你会发现自己没有精力决定晚餐吃什么，没有精力做爱好，想要吃舒适的食物，也许喝点啤酒，然后茫然地盯着电脑或电视，直到该睡觉了。

How do you feel at the end of the day these days? If you’re like many new full-time managers, you probably feel quite drained. Even though you didn’t write a lot of code — or any code! — all day, when you get home you find yourself with no energy to decide what to eat for dinner, no energy for hobbies, and the desire to eat comfort food, drink a beer perhaps, and stare blankly at the computer or TV until it’s time to go to bed.

管理多个团队的头几个月感觉就像是一场死亡行军，即使你的工作时间并不过分。您曾经专注的注意力在您一天中的各种会议之间被分割和切块。在管理多个团队的头几个月里，我反复失声；我完全不习惯每天说这么多。我的一个朋友最近成为了一名工程总监，她不得不开始让助理为她订午餐，因为她发现自己会忘记吃饭——当她意识到自己需要食物时，没有精力决定吃什么。

The first several months of managing multiple teams can feel like a death march, even when your hours are not excessive. Your once-focused attention gets sliced and diced between the various meetings that pepper your day. I lost my voice repeatedly during my first few months managing multiple teams; I was totally unused to talking so much every single day. A friend of mine recently became a director of engineering, and she had to start having an assistant order her lunch because she discovered that she would forget to eat — and had no energy to decide what to eat when she realized she needed food.

所以，首先，坏消息是：摆脱这种情况的唯一方法就是经历它。事实上，我预计大多数人会经历一段时间。如果你根本没有经历过，要么认为自己非常幸运，要么仔细检查以确保你真的在关注所有需要你注意的事情。根据我的经验，无论是经历这种转变还是管理其中的人，如果你不觉得有点不知所措，你可能会错过一些东西。

So, first, the bad news: the only way out of this situation is to go through it. In fact, I would expect most people to go through this for a while. If you haven’t experienced it at all, either count yourself extremely lucky, or double-check to make sure you’re really paying attention to everything that needs your attention. In my experience both going through this transition and managing people in it, if you don’t feel a little bit overwhelmed, you’re likely missing something.

从现在开始，描述管理感觉的最佳方式是转盘。如果你不熟悉它，盘旋是一种花哨的杂耍形式，杂耍者有几个杆子，每个杆子上都有一个盘子旋转。杂耍者必须注意每个盘子，然后才能减速到从杆子上掉下来的速度。你的盘子是你正在监督的人和项目，你的工作是弄清楚每个人在什么时候需要多少关注。重要的是你要以学生的心态来处理这种旋转。你还在学习如何旋转盘子，你会因为忽视它们太久而将一些盘子掉在地板上。磨练关于何时触摸哪个盘子的直觉是游戏的名称。

The best way to describe the feeling of management from here on out is plate spinning. If you’re not familiar with it, plate spinning is a fancy form of juggling where the juggler has several poles, each with a plate spinning on top of it. The juggler must attend to each plate before it slows down enough to fall off the pole. Your plates are the people and projects you’re overseeing, and your job is to figure out how much attention each one needs at what time. It’s important that you approach this spinning with a student’s mind. You’re still learning how to spin plates, and you’re going to drop some on the floor because you’ve neglected them for too long. Honing your instincts about when to touch which plate is the name of the game.

现在有个好消息：随着时间的推移，你会变得更好。你的直觉会改善。您将开始认识到项目进展不佳、准备退出的人员以及表现不佳的团队的早期预警信号。我在上一节中建议您仔细考虑退出会议，部分原因是这些会议是您了解健康和不健康动态的地方。这也是为什么我强烈建议您与直接向您汇报的每个人保持定期、可靠的 1 对 1 会议的做法。如果您有太多人，您可能需要缩短这些会议或每两周而不是每周举行一次会议，但是因为您太忙于其他事情而跳过 1-1 会议是一个很好的方式来错过员工的警告信号打算退出。

Now for the good news: you’ll get better at this over time. Your instincts will improve. You’ll start to recognize the early warning signs of projects that are going poorly, people who are getting ready to quit, and teams that are underperforming. I recommended in the last section that you think carefully about dropping out of meetings, and part of the reason is that those meetings are where you learn what healthy and unhealthy dynamics look like. This is also why I strongly advise you maintain your practice of regular, reliable 1-1 meetings with everyone who reports directly to you. If you have too many people, you may need to shorten those meetings or hold them biweekly instead of weekly, but skipping 1-1s because you’re too busy with other things is a great way to miss the warning signs of an employee who is going to quit.

我将此部分称为“决策和授权”——那么授权在哪里适用？委派是您摆脱同时旋转太多盘子的感觉的主要方式。当任务来找你时，问问自己：我需要成为完成这项工作的人吗？答案可能取决于几个因素（见表 6-2）。

I called this section “Decisions and Delegation” — so where does delegation fit in? Delegation is the primary way you claw yourself out of the feeling of having too many plates spinning at once. As tasks come at you, ask yourself: do I need to be the person who completes this work? The answer may depend on a few factors (see Table 6-2).

表 6-2。决定何时委派或自己做
频繁 不常见

简单的

Simple

代表

Delegate

自己做

Do it yourself

复杂的

Complex

代表（仔细）

Delegate (carefully)

代表培训目的

Delegate for training purposes

任务的复杂程度和频率可以作为确定是否以及如何委派的指南。

The degree of complexity and the frequency of the task can act as guides to determining whether and how you should delegate.

委派简单和频繁的任务

Delegate Simple and Frequent Tasks

如果任务简单且频繁，请找一个您可以将其交给的人。简单而频繁的任务示例可能包括运行每日站会、每周编写团队进度摘要或进行次要代码审查。您的技术主管或其他高级工程师可以负责这些任务，甚至可能不需要培训即可。

If the task is simple and frequent, find someone to whom you can hand it off. Examples of simple and frequent tasks might include running daily standups, writing up a summary of the teams’ progress each week, or conducting minor code reviews. Your tech leads or other senior engineers can take responsibility for these tasks and probably won’t even need training to do so.

自己处理简单和不经常的任务

Handle Simple and Infrequent Tasks Yourself

如果自己做某件事比向别人解释要快，而且很少需要做，那就卷起袖子去做，即使你认为这项任务低于你。这可以是任何事情，从为您的团队预订临时会议门票到运行生成季度报告的脚本。

If it’s faster to do something yourself than it would be to explain it to someone else and it rarely needs to be done, roll up your sleeves and do it, even if you deem the task beneath you. This can be anything from booking the occasional conference ticket for your team to running the script that generates quarterly reports.

使用复杂和不经常的任务作为新任领导者的培训机会

Use Complex and Infrequent Tasks as Training Opportunities for Rising Leaders

撰写绩效评估和制定招聘计划等任务由您自己完成。但是，这些也是您希望传授给新晋经理的技能。你可能会让技术主管和你一起为实习生写绩效评估，或者让高级工程师提供反馈，说明他认为明年需要多少新人来支持一个项目。在这些任务上寻求上级的帮助，直到你觉得可以完成这些任务，但是一旦你觉得舒服了，就开始拉拢正在崛起的领导者来了解他们是如何完成的。

Tasks like writing performance reviews and making hiring plans are yours alone. However, these are also the skills you will want to pass on to rising managers. You may have a tech lead sit with you to write the performance review for an intern, or have a senior engineer provide feedback on how many new people he believes would be needed to support a project next year. Ask for help from above on these tasks until you feel comfortable doing them, but once you feel comfortable, start pulling in rising leaders to learn how they are done.

委派复杂和频繁的任务来发展您的团队

Delegate Complex and Frequent Tasks to Develop Your Team

项目规划、系统设计或在停机期间成为关键人物等任务是您在团队中培养人才同时让团队运行得更好的最大机会。优秀的管理者花费大量时间在这些领域培养团队成员。你的目标是让你的团队能够在没有你太多投入的情况下高水平运作，这意味着他们需要能够接管这些复杂任务并在没有你的情况下运行它们的人。

Tasks like project planning, systems design, or being the key person during an outage are the biggest opportunity you have to grow talent on your team while also making the team run better. Strong managers spend a lot of their time developing members of their teams in these areas. Your goal is to make your teams capable of operating at a high level without much input from you, and that means they’ll need individuals who can take over these complex tasks and run them without you around.

您的团队是在学习如何独立运作，还是让他们依赖您来完成关键职能？列出你和只有你真正知道如何为团队做的任务。其中一些可能是合适的，例如撰写绩效评估或制定招聘计划，但其中许多对于教您的团队完成自我很重要。项目管理。入职新团队成员。与产品团队合作，将产品路线图目标分解为技术可交付成果。生产支持。这些都是团队成员需要学习的技能。提前教他们可能需要时间，但从长远来看，它会节省你的时间。不仅如此，教你的团队如何做这些事情也是你工作的一部分。作为经理，你有责任在你的组织中培养人才，

Are your teams learning how to operate independently, or are you keeping them dependent on you for critical functions? List the tasks that you and only you really know how to do for the team. Some of them may be appropriate, like writing performance reviews or making hiring plans, but many of them are important to teach your teams to accomplish themselves. Project management. Onboarding new team members. Working with the product team to break down product roadmap goals into technical deliverables. Production support. These are all skills members of your team need to learn. Teaching them may take time up front, but in the long run it will save you time. Not only that, but teaching your team how to do these things is part of your job. It is your responsibility, as a manager, to build up the talent in your organization, and to help your people learn new skills they’ll need for the next stages of their careers.

授权是一个开始缓慢但变成职业发展的基本要素的过程。如果你的团队在没有你的情况下无法正常运作，你会发现很难升职。发展你的天赋并将决策下推到那个天赋，这样你就可以找到新的有趣的盘子来学习如何旋转。

Delegation is a process that starts slow but turns into the essential element for career growth. If you teams can’t operate well without you around, you’ll find it hard to be promoted. Develop your talent and push decisions down to that talent so that you can find new and interesting plates to learn how to spin.

询问 CTO：警告信号

我现在经历过几次团队出乎意料地挣扎，一个人毫无征兆地退出。是否有任何警告信号我可以提早发现这些问题？

I’ve experienced a couple of times now when teams have struggled unexpectedly, and a person has quit without warning. Are there any warning signs I can look out for to catch these issues earlier?

那里绝对是您在管理一段时间后开始注意到的信号。以下是我学会发现的一些：

There are definitely signals that you start to notice after you’ve been managing for a while. Here are some I’ve learned to spot:

  • 这平时很健谈、快乐和忙碌的人突然开始早退、迟到、在工作日休息离开、在会议中保持安静、不闲聊。这个人要么有重大的个人问题，要么准备辞职。通常，当有个人问题（例如生病的亲戚、人际关系问题或健康问题）时，人们会告诉别人，但并非总是如此。如果这发生在重大调整之后，例如晋升、团队重组或其他事件，这个人可能会觉得她被忽视了。无论出于何种原因，您都可能希望进行一次诚实的对话，并在她辞职之前尝试找到问题的根源。
  • 技术负责人声称一切进展顺利，但经常跳过你的 1-1，并且很少在他的状态更新中提供详细信息。这个人可能隐藏了一些东西。通常他隐瞒的是进度比他预期的要慢得多，或者他正在构建项目范围之外的东西。帮助他尽早制定清晰的项目计划，并为当事情发生变化时如何调整该计划设定期望，这样他就更难掩饰缺乏进展。还可以帮助他阐明项目的目标和范围，这对于一些新的技术主管来说可能是令人生畏的。在管理不知所措的新员工时，您可能遇到过类似的事情。这也与花费大量时间倡导新语言/平台/流程而不是完成工作的人有关。
  • 团队在他们的会议上完全没有精力。事实上，会议感觉就像是一场艰苦的会议，产品经理和技术负责人在做所有的谈话，而团队的其他人则静静地坐着，或者只在被要求时才说话。缺乏参与会议往往意味着团队没有参与工作，或者觉得他们在决策过程中没有发言权。
  • 团队的项目清单似乎每周都在变化，这取决于当天客户的心血来潮。除了取悦客户之外，该团队还没有考虑过其目标，并且可能需要更好的产品或业务方向。
  • 一个小团队内部似乎在理解上非常分散；工程师自称对他们不从事的系统一无所知，并且缺乏了解这些系统的好奇心或开放性。与更大的团队或公司相比，这个团队更能被他们的日常工作和他们接触的系统所识别。他们可能不愿意根据更大的团队或业务的需求来改变他们的系统。

具有挑战性的情况：说不的策略

Challenging Situations: Strategies for Saying No

经理的工作包括通过创造可以开展工作的肥沃环境，让她的员工轻松完成工作。她专注于她的团队，以便他们可以做他们最擅长的事情。她在团队中培养友情和友谊，并帮助人们学习新技能。在所有这些事情上，她都是推动者、教练和拥护者。

A manager’s job involves making it easy for her employees to get things done by creating fertile environments in which work can happen. She focuses her team so that they can do what they do best. She cultivates camaraderie and friendship on the team, and helps people learn new skills. In all these things, she is an enabler, a coach, and a champion.

但为了营造这样的环境，她有时不得不说不。她必须对团队说不。她必须对她的同龄人说不。她甚至必须对她的老板说不。这些拒绝中的每一个都以自己的方式很难，强大的经理必须制定有效的策略来拒绝。以下是我确定的一些。

But to create this environment, she sometimes must say no. She must say no to the team. She must say no to her peers. She must even say no to her boss. Each of these nos is hard, in its own way, and a strong manager must develop effective strategies for saying no. Here are a few that I have identified.

“是的，而且”

“Yes, and”

当你是一名经理时，对你的老板说不看起来很少像一个简单的“不”。相反，它看起来像是即兴喜剧的“是的，并且”的技巧。“是的，我们可以做那个项目，我们需要做的就是推迟这个目前在路线图上的另一个项目的启动。” 以积极的态度做出回应，同时仍能阐明现实的界限，这将使您进入高级领导层的主要联盟。对于大多数工程师来说，这种积极的否定是一项相当难掌握的技能。我们习惯于表达项目的缺点，摆脱下意识的“不，这不可能发生”的习惯是很困难的。开始掌握“是”和“不”的策略，尤其是在与你的老板和同事互动时，看看它如何经常将有争议的分歧转化为现实的优先谈判。

Saying no to your boss rarely looks like a simple “no” when you’re a manager. Instead, it looks like the “yes, and” technique of improvisational comedy. “Yes, we can do that project, and all we will need to do is delay the start of this other project that is currently on the roadmap.” Responding with positivity while still articulating the boundaries of reality will get you into the major leagues of senior leadership. This type of positive no is a pretty hard skill for most engineers to master. We’re used to articulating the downsides of projects, and getting out of the knee-jerk “no, that can’t happen” habit is hard. Start mastering the “yes, and” strategy for saying no, particularly when interacting with your boss and peers, and see how it often transforms contentious disagreements into realistic negotiations for priority.

创建策略

Create Policies

当涉及到您的团队时，您希望帮助他们了解如何才能获得“是”。也许您正在与一位工程师打交道，他想为一个项目切换到一种新的编程语言，而您的团队没有使用这种语言。关于为什么这种语言是完成这项工作的完美工具，他有一些很好的论据，但你不愿意仅仅因为它是完美的而添加新工具。你可能很想直接说不，给出理由，然后离开，有时这会奏效。但是你可能会发现自己一遍又一遍地说同样的“不”，给出同样的理由。“不，我们需要更多懂这种语言的人；我们需要了解将这种语言投入生产意味着什么。” “不，我们需要有伐木标准；我们需要考虑测试会是什么样子。” 当你开始重复自己，您有合理政策的基础。该政策包括必须满足的硬性要求才能说是，以及考虑决策的一些指导方针。制定政策可以帮助您的团队提前了解获得“是”的成本。

When it comes to your team, you want to help them understand what it takes to get to “yes.” Perhaps you are dealing with an engineer who wants to switch to a new programming language for a project, one that your team doesn’t use. He has some great arguments as to why this language is the perfect tool for the job, but you’re reluctant to add a new tool just because it’s perfect. You might be tempted to just say no, give the reasoning, and leave it, and sometimes that will work. But you may find yourself saying the same “no” over and over again, giving the same reasons. “No, we need to have more people who know that language; we need to understand what it means to put that language into production.” “No, we need to have standards for logging; we need to think about what testing would look like.” When you start repeating yourself, you have the basis for a reasonable policy. That policy consists of the hard requirements that must be met in order to say yes, and some guidelines for thinking about the decision. Making a policy helps your team know in advance the cost of getting to “yes.”

“帮我说是”

“Help Me Say Yes”

策略很有用，但并不涵盖所有情况。下一个策略“帮我说是”类似于政策编写，但更适用于没有明确政策的一次性情况。有时你会听到一些看起来很不周到的想法。“帮我说是”意味着您提出问题并深入挖掘您认为如此可疑的元素。通常，这种提问方式会帮助人们自己意识到他们的计划不是一个好主意，但有时他们的思维方式会让你大吃一惊。无论哪种方式，对想法的好奇询问都可以帮助您说不，同时进行教学。

Policies are useful, but they don’t cover every case. The next strategy, “help me say yes,” is similar to policy writing, but works better for the one-off instances where there is no clear policy. Sometimes you’ll hear ideas that seem very ill-considered. “Help me say yes” means you ask questions and dig in on the elements that seem so questionable to you. Often, this line of questioning helps people come to the realization themselves that their plan isn’t a good idea, but sometimes they’ll surprise you with their line of thinking. Either way, curious interrogation of ideas can help you say no and teach at the same time.

呼吁预算

Appeal to Budget

当涉及到您的团队和同事时，您可以使用的一种策略是吸引时间和预算。简明扼要地列出当前的工作量，并表明几乎没有回旋余地。有时这与“现在不行”相结合，这是另一种有点被动攻击性的拒绝方式。“现在不行”意味着你可能同意这个想法，但现在做不到，所以也许你将来会去做。这通常是正确的，因此很容易回到“不是现在”模式。但正如我之前所讨论的，当你暗示“不是现在”意味着你会在“以后”认真做某事时，你需要确保以后真的会发生。

When it comes to both your team and your peers, one tactic that you can use is appealing to time and budget. Lay out the current workload in plain terms, and show how there is little room to maneuver. Sometimes this is coupled with “not right now,” another somewhat passive-aggressive way of saying no. “Not right now” implies that you might agree with the idea but can’t do it at this moment, so maybe you’ll get to it in the future. This is frequently true, and so it’s easy to fall back into “not right now” mode. But as I discussed earlier, when you give an implied promise that “not right now” means that you’ll seriously do something “later,” you need to be sure that later can actually happen.

以团队的方式合作

Work as a Team

谈到您的同行，有时您和您的同行（尤其是跨职能部门——即您的产品或业务同行）需要共同行动拒绝。这可以适用于任何级别的否。有时你会利用你的技术权威以对产品团队有利的方式说不。有时您会呼吁财务部门帮助您对某些预算超支说不。扮演好警察/坏警察可能有点不诚实，因此请谨慎使用它，但将您的权威借给“拒绝”可能很有用，然后当您将来需要支持自己的“拒绝”时可以求助.

Speaking of your peers, there will be times when you and your peers (particularly across functions — i.e., your product or business peers) will need to act together to say no. This can apply to a no at any level. Sometimes you will use your technical authority to say no in a way that is beneficial to the product team. Sometimes you will appeal to the finance department to help you say no to certain budget excesses. Playing good cop/bad cop can be a little bit dishonest, so use this sparingly, but it can be useful to lend your authority to a no and then be able to call in the favor when you need support for your own no in the future.

不要推诿

Don’t Prevaricate

当你知道你需要说不时，最好快点说，而不是拖延和拖延过程。如果您有权说不，并且您不相信某些事情应该发生，请帮自己一个忙，不要为这个过程而苦恼。有时你会犯错，所以当你发现自己太快说不时，为犯下的错误道歉。你不会有幸仔细调查和分析每个决定，所以练习习惯于快速拒绝（和快速同意！）以做出低风险、低影响的决定。

When you know that you need to say no, it’s better to say it quickly than to delay and drag out the process. If you have the authority to say no, and you don’t believe something should happen, do yourself a favor and don’t agonize over the process. You’ll be wrong sometimes, so when you discover that you were too quick to say no, apologize for making that mistake. You won’t have the luxury to carefully investigate and analyze every decision, so practice getting comfortable with the quick no (and the quick yes!) for low-risk, low-impact decisions.

问 CTO：我的技术主管没有管理

一世有一个技术负责人，他应该监督我们的一位初级工程师，负责将我们的应用程序从 Objective-C 重写为 Swift 的项目。我刚发现初级工程师还没有制定项目计划，也没有回答我在设计评审中给出的任何反馈。我如何让技术主管在我不必介入的情况下进行管理？

I have a tech lead who was supposed to be overseeing one of our junior engineers on a project to rewrite our app from Objective-C to Swift. I just found out that the junior engineer still hasn’t created a project plan, and hasn’t answered any of the feedback I gave in the design review. How do I get the tech lead to manage this without me having to step in?

委派失败发生。听起来你的技术主管不明白你让她负责确保初级工程师跟进设计反馈并制定项目计划。所以第一步是询问技术主管为什么这些事情还没有发生。

Delegation failures happen. It sounds like your tech lead doesn’t understand that you’re holding her responsible for making sure that the junior engineer follows up on design feedback and creates a project plan. So the first step is to ask the tech lead why these things haven’t happened yet.

您将得到的答案很可能是多种因素的组合。一，技术负责人忙于自己的工作，不记得跟进初级工程师。这种情况发生了，你必须提醒她，指导和监督这个人的工作需要与她的代码和其他职责一起安排。

The answer you will get is likely to be a combination of things. One, the tech lead is busy with her own work and didn’t remember to follow up with the junior engineer. This happens, and you’ll have to remind her that mentoring and overseeing this person’s work needs to be scheduled in with her code and other responsibilities.

第二，技术负责人可能不知道如何在初级工程师不想遵守时间表时推动他。问她是如何从他那里得到信息的，看看你是否有机会提出不同的方法。有时，新的技术主管不愿意推动人们制定项目计划，因为他们觉得自己没有权威，并且当他们要求某事而对方永远不会交付时会感到慌乱。

Two, the tech lead may not know how to push the junior engineer when he doesn’t want to commit to a schedule. Ask her how she’s tried to get the information from him, and see whether you have an opportunity to suggest different approaches. Sometimes new tech leads are reluctant to push people for project plans because they don’t feel that they have authority and are flustered when they ask for something and the other person just never delivers.

最好的办法是与您的技术主管合作，让她有技能和信心向团队其他成员索取报告。这将比亲自介入并要求他们慢，但你会教团队尊重她的要求并教她如何独立领导团队。

The best thing to do here is to work with your tech lead to give her the skills and confidence to ask for reports from other members of the team. It will be slower than stepping in and asking for them yourself, but you’ll teach the team to respect her requests and teach her how to lead the team independently.

代码之外的技术元素

Technical Elements Beyond Code

这个级别的管理变得混乱。我们聘用经理的部分原因是他们的技术技能，但我们中的许多人认为这份工作并不是真正的“技术性”。毕竟，经理可能不会写太多代码或做太多系统设计，对吧？

Management at this level gets confusing. We hire managers based partially on their technical skills, but many of us think of this job as not really “technical.” After all, the manager is probably not writing much code or doing much systems design, right?

假设这个级别的工作本质上变得非技术性是错误的。事实证明，运行有效的工程团队比纯粹的管理技能要多，如果你了解软件工程的实践和纪律，这个级别的管理将需要你学习一些最容易学习的新技能。您现在将把您的技术重点转向观察和改进您的开发人员在其中运行的工作系统。特别是，您现在需要关注整个团队的技术健康信号。但这些健康信号是什么？

Assuming that the job at this level becomes essentially nontechnical is a mistake. It turns out there’s more to running effective engineering teams than pure management skills, and management at this level will require you to learn some new skills that are easiest to learn if you understand the practice and discipline of software engineering. You’re going to turn your technical focus now to observing and improving the systems of work that your developers are operating within. In particular, you now need to develop an eye for the technical health signals for the overall team. But what are those health signals?

流行的管理书籍首先，打破所有规则2讨论了您可以回答的几个问题，以帮助预测团队的生产力和满意度。其中有：

The popular management book First, Break All the Rules2 discusses several questions you can answer to help predict team productivity and satisfaction. Among them are:

  • 我知道在工作中对我的期望是什么吗？
  • 我是否拥有正确完成工作所需的材料和设备？
  • 我有机会每天做我最擅长的事情吗？

对于大多数工程师来说，这些问题的答案可以通过他们推送代码的速度和频率来辨别。如果他们需要做的工作很清楚，他们就知道要写什么代码。如果工具、票证、自动化和流程可用且易于使用，他们就能够编写代码。如果他们没有因过多的会议或淹没在支持和事件管理中而分心，他们将有机会每天编写代码。这些健康信号——代码发布的频率、代码签入的频率和事件的频率——是团队知道该做什么、有工具去做、每天都有时间去做的关键指标.

For most engineers, the answer to these questions can be discerned by the speed and frequency with which they push code. If the work they need to do is clear, they know what code to write. If the tools, tickets, automation, and process are available and easy to use, they are able to get the code written. And if they’re not distracted by excessive meetings or drowning in support and incident management, they’ll get a chance to write code every day. These health signals — frequency of code releases, frequency of code check-ins, and infrequency of incidents — are the key indicators of a team that knows what to do, has the tools to do it, and has the time to do it every day.

衡量开发团队的健康状况

Measuring the Health of Your Development Team

当您专注于开发团队的健康时，请戴上技术帽子来设计系统和流程，以保持一切顺利。创建开发人员完成工作所需的工具。帮助他们集中注意力，这样他们就可以很容易地弄清楚接下来需要发生什么。询问每个流程以确定它应该提供的价值，并始终问自己是否可以进一步自动化。考虑这些方法来衡量团队的健康状况。

When you’re focusing on the health of your development teams, put on your technical hat to design systems and processes that will keep things moving. Create the tools that developers need to do their jobs. Help them focus so they can easily figure out what needs to happen next. Interrogate every process to determine the value it should provide, and always ask yourself if it can be automated further. Consider these ways to measure the health of your team.

发布频率

Frequency of Releases

在第 5 章我谈到了技术团队的一个常见功能障碍是不发布代码，发布频率是最直接的衡量标准。如果您的公司没有意识到频繁发布代码的价值，我很抱歉。在这个现代时代，代码更改频率是健康工程团队的主要指标之一。以产品为中心的团队的优秀工程经理知道如何创建团队可以快速行动的环境，而快速行动的一部分需要将工作分解成小块。即使您的公司不喜欢它，您也必须努力帮助您的团队实现他们产品的最佳发布频率。以免您认为这不适用于您，因为您正在构建一个不能经常发布的产品（例如数据库），

In Chapter 5 I talked about how a common dysfunction of technical teams is not shipping code, and release frequency is the most direct measure of this. If your company doesn’t appreciate the value of releasing code frequently, I’m sorry. In this modern era, frequency of code change is one of the leading indicators of a healthy engineering team. Great engineering managers of product-focused teams know how to create environments where their teams can move fast, and part of moving fast requires breaking work down into small chunks. Even if your company doesn’t appreciate it, you must work to help your team achieve the best release frequency possible for their product. Lest you think this doesn’t apply to you because you’re building a product (say, a database) that can’t release frequently, I’m sure there is a complete artifact pushed to a beta/developer testing environment that provides a similarly valuable measure in terms of frequency and stability.

为什么不更频繁地发布？看看你的团队。如果他们不连续或每天发布，发布过程是什么样的？多久时间？在过去的几个月里，关于发布的问题多久出现一次？当事情出错时会是什么样子？您多久因问题而不得不延迟或回滚发布？延迟或回滚的影响是什么？您如何确定代码是否已准备好投入生产？这需要多长时间？谁主要负责确定这一点？
