Do thorough reference checks for anyone you’re planning to bring on board, even if you’ve worked with that person before. Ask the references to describe the ways that the person succeeds as well as the ways she fails. Ask them if they would work with or for this person again. Ask them what they love about the person, and what drives them crazy. If you’re not doing reference checks when you hire management, you’re doing your team a massive disservice. Reference checks, even ones chosen carefully by the candidate, often reveal a lot about what you can expect to get when hiring her. Don’t leave out this crucial step.

询问 CTO：在您的技能范围之外进行管理

我现在不仅负责管理我部门的软件开发团队，还负责管理运营和 QA 团队。我以前从来没有管理过这些类型的团队，所以你有什么建议可以做好吗？

I’m now responsible for managing not only my division’s software development teams, but also the operations and QA teams. I have never had to manage these types of teams before, so do you have any advice on doing it well?

当心！很容易将其视为管理其他软件开发人员的一个小飞跃，但根据我的经验，您需要在这些领域跟踪不同的重要细节，如果您以前从未管理过这些类型的团队，很难知道要关注哪些细节。不幸的是，很容易错过不熟悉领域的问题，直到为时已晚。

Be careful! It’s easy to think of this as a small leap from managing other software developers, but in my experience, you need to track different important details than you’re used to in these areas, and if you’ve never managed these types of teams before, it’s hard to know which details to focus on. Unfortunately, it’s very easy to miss out on problems in unfamiliar areas until it’s too late.

当这种情况变得糟糕时会发生什么？以我个人的经验，这可能是一个大问题。当您在团队中聘请经理做您不太了解的事情时，在您意识到发生了什么之前，该经理很容易在很长一段时间内走错路。当涉及到任何类型的具有很长时间表的项目时，这尤其困难，在这些项目中很容易隐藏缺乏进展。

What happens when this situation goes poorly? In my personal experience, it can be a big problem. When you hire a manager over a team doing things that you don’t deeply understand, it’s easy for that manager to go the wrong way for a very long time before you realize what’s happening. This is particularly difficult when it comes to any sort of projects that have long timelines, where it’s easy to hide a lack of progress.

解决这个问题的一个有趣方法是使用我在谈到指导时建议的相同心态——即非常好奇。请记住，不要仅仅因为您是经理就知道一切。使用它对您有利。请这个人教你她所做的工作。和她坐下来，把她当作你的导师，教你这份工作的诀窍。无论是 QA、设计、产品管理还是技术运营，都可以提出很多问题，但要以开放的方式。让对方清楚你的目标是了解她的所作所为，以便你能够更好地欣赏它。

An interesting way to combat this problem is to use the same mindset that I advised when we talked about mentorship — namely, being very curious. Remember that you’re not expected to know everything just because you’re a manager. Use this to your advantage. Ask the person to teach you about the work she does. Sit down with her and treat her as if she were your mentor, the person to teach you the ropes for this job. Whether it’s QA, design, product management, or technical operations, ask lots of questions, but in an open way. Make it clear to the person that your goal is to understand what she does so that you’re capable of appreciating it better.

这里的另一条建议是，虽然你可能会想把更多的时间花在你最熟悉的领域，但要准备好在你不熟悉的领域投入大量时间，尤其是在一开始的时候。对于想要信任和委派的经理来说，简单地假设人们会做正确的事情并让他们离开是很诱人的，但这很容易导致你在这些领域错过问题太久。更糟糕的是，如果您认为这些领域无趣或不值得您花时间，您可能会发现自己不愿意处理这些团队中的问题，即使人们显然已经引起了他们的注意。你会因为一开始就忽略了这些领域而感到内疚，而你天生的厌恶可能会让你无法面对问题的时间比你原本允许的要长得多。咬紧牙关，腾出时间适应每个区域；花时间了解团队中的经理和员工，并练习询问有关该地区的详细信息，

One other piece of advice here is that, while you may be tempted to spend more of your time in the areas that you are most comfortable with, to be prepared to devote significant time to the areas new to you, especially in the beginning. It’s tempting for managers who want to trust and delegate to simply assume that people will do the right thing and let them go, but this can easily result in you missing problems in these areas for far too long. What’s worse, if you view these areas as uninteresting or unworthy of your time, you may find yourself reluctant to deal with problems in these teams even when people are clearly drawing attention to them. You’ll feel guilty for having ignored the areas in the first place, and your natural aversion may keep you from facing up to issues for far longer than you otherwise would allow. Grit your teeth and make the time to get comfortable with each area; take time to get to know the manager and employees in the team, and practice asking for details about the area, so that you can start to learn and develop a sense for what the people in that team are actually doing.

调试功能失调的组织

Debugging Dysfunctional Organizations

我相信最好的工程经理通常都是出色的调试员。为什么会这样？这两项任务是如何产生如此重叠的技能组合的？

I believe that the best engineering managers are often great debuggers. Why would this be? What is it about these two tasks that produces such an overlapping skill set?

一个优秀的调试器会坚持不懈地寻找错误的“原因”。当我们在应用程序逻辑中寻找错误时，这很简单，但我们都知道错误可以深入很多层，特别是在涉及许多独立部分在延时网络上运行的复杂系统中。一个糟糕的调试器的标志是，当他将日志语句添加到一段并发代码以尝试查找错误并看到无法重现该错误时，假设他已经修复了问题。这是一种懒惰的习惯，但很常见。有时有些问题似乎无法确定，而且许多人没有耐心去挖掘代码层（他们的和其他人的）、日志文件、系统设置以及任何其他需要的东西来找出问题的根源。只发生过一次。我不能责怪他们。

A great debugger is relentless in his pursuit of the “why” for a bug. This is simple when we’re looking for errors in application logic, but we all know that bugs can go many layers deep, particularly in complex systems that involve many separate parts operating over time-delayed networks. A sign of a poor debugger is a person who, when he adds a log statement to a piece of concurrent code to attempt to find an error and sees that the error can’t be reproduced, assumes that he’s fixed the problem. It’s a lazy habit, but a common one. Sometimes there are problems that seem impossible to determine, and many people don’t have the patience to dig through layers of code (theirs and others’), logfiles, system settings, and whatever else is needed to get to the bottom of something that happened only once. I can’t blame them. Obsessive debugging of one-off issues is not always a great use of your time, but it does show a mind that won’t be satisfied with the unknown, especially when that unknown might cause you to be paged at two o’clock in the morning.

这和管理有什么关系？管理团队是一系列与其他复杂黑盒交互的复杂黑盒。这些黑匣子有可以观察到的输入和输出，但是当输出不符合预期时，要弄清楚为什么需要尝试打开它们，看看里面发生了什么。而且，就像有时你没有源代码，或者源代码是你不懂的语言，或者日志文件不可读，团队的黑匣子可能会拒绝屈服于他们的内部工作。

What does this have to do with management? Managing teams is a series of complex black boxes interacting with other complex black boxes. These black boxes have inputs and outputs that can be observed, but when the outputs aren’t as expected, figuring out why requires trying to open them up and see what’s going on inside. And, just as sometimes you don’t have the source code, or the source code is in a language you don’t understand, or the logfiles aren’t readable, the black boxes of teams can resist yielding their inner workings.

让我们通过一个例子来工作。你有一个感觉很慢的团队。您已经听到他们的业务合作伙伴和产品经理抱怨他们行动迟缓，并且您同意该团队似乎缺乏与您其他团队相同的精力。你怎么想出来的？

Let’s work through an example. You have a team that feels slow. You’ve heard complaints from their business partners and product manager that they’re slow, and you agree that the team just seems to lack the same energy as your other teams. How do you figure this out?

有一个假设

Have a Hypothesis

要正确调试系统，您需要一个合理的假设来解释系统如何进入故障状态，最好是您可以重现的假设，以便您可以修复错误。要调试团队，您还需要寻找关于团队为什么会遇到问题的假设。以尽可能微创的方式执行此操作，以防止您的干预掩盖了问题。作为一个额外的挑战，团队问题通常不是单一的失败，而更像是性能问题。系统正在运行，但似乎时不时变慢；机器还可以，只是偶尔会崩溃；人们似乎很高兴，但损耗太高了。

To properly debug a system, you need a reasonable hypothesis that explains how the system got into the failed state, preferably one that you can reproduce, so that you can fix the bug. To debug a team, you also want to look for a hypothesis around why the team is having problems. Do this in as minimally invasive a way as possible, to prevent your meddling from obscuring the problems. As an added challenge, team problems are not generally single failures but are more like performance issues. The system is running, but it seems to slow down from time to time; the machines are OK, except occasionally they crash; people seem happy, but attrition is too high.

检查数据

Check the Data

调试一个团队应该像调试一个严重的系统问题一样严格。当我调试系统问题时，我首先查看的是日志文件和事件发生时的任何其他系统状态记录。当您查看一个工作速度不够快的团队时，请查看记录。查看团队聊天和电子邮件，查看工单，查看存储库代码审查和签入。你看到了什么？是否发生了占用大量时间的生产事件？一群人生病了吗？他们是否在代码审查评论中为编码风格争吵？正在写的票是模糊的，太大了，太小了？团队是否在沟通方式上看起来很乐观，在聊天中分享有趣的事情以及重要的工作，还是他们纯粹是为了生意？看看他们的日历。团队每周在会议上花费很多时间吗？他们的经理不是在做1-1吗？这些事情都不一定是确凿的证据，但它们可能指向一个需要解决的领域。

Debugging a team deserves the same rigor you would apply to debugging a serious systems issue. When I debug a systems issue, the first thing I look at is logfiles and any other record of system state from the time of the incident. When you’re looking at a team that isn’t producing work fast enough, look at the records. Look at the team chats and emails, look at the tickets, look at the repository code reviews and check-ins. What do you see? Are production incidents happening that are taking up lots of time? Are a bunch of people sick? Are they bickering over coding style in their code review comments? Are the tickets that are being written vague, too big, too small? Does the team seem upbeat in their communication style, sharing fun things as well as important work in chat, or are they purely business? Look at their calendars. Is the team spending many hours a week in meetings? Is their manager not doing 1-1s? None of these things are necessarily smoking guns, but they may point to an area to address.

观察团队

Observe the Team

也许所有这些指标看起来一切都很好，但团队仍然没有像你认为的那样表现出色。你知道人才就在那里，团队很高兴，而且他们并没有因为生产支持而负担过重。那么发生了什么？现在是开始进行一些潜在破坏性调查的时候了。参加他们的会议。他们对你来说很无聊吗？团队无聊吗？大部分时间谁在说话？是否与整个团队定期开会，大部分时间都花在听经理或产品负责人的谈话上？

Perhaps everything seems OK in all of these indicators, but the team still just is not performing as well as you believe they should. You know the talent is there, the team is happy, and they’re not being overburdened by production support. So what’s happening? Now is the time to start doing some potentially destructive investigations. Sit in their meetings. Are they boring to you? Is the team bored? Who is speaking most of the time? Are there regular meetings with the whole team where the vast majority of the time is spent listening to the manager or product lead talk?

无聊的会议是一个信号。它们可能是组织者计划效率低下的标志。对于所涵盖的信息，可能会发生太多会议。他们可能表示团队成员认为他们实际上无法帮助确定团队的方向，或者选择将要发生的工作。它们通常表明团队中缺乏健康的冲突。好的会议有大量的讨论元素，意见和想法是从团队中汲取的。如果会议内容过多，以至于无法进行真正的对话，就会扼杀创造性的讨论。如果人们因为害怕处理冲突而害怕不同意或提出问题，或者如果管理者总是在不让分歧浮出水面的情况下平息冲突，这就是不健康的团队文化的表现。

Boring meetings are a sign. They may be a sign of inefficient planning on the part of the organizers. There may be too many meetings happening for the information covered. They may indicate that the team members don’t feel they can actually help set the direction of the team, or choose the work that will happen. They often signal a lack of healthy conflict on a team. Good meetings have a heavy discussion element, where opinions and ideas are drawn out of the team. If the meetings are overscripted, so that no real conversation can take place, it stifles that creative discussion. If people are afraid to disagree or bring up issues for fear of dealing with conflict, or if managers always shut down conflict without letting disagreements air, this is a sign of an unhealthy team culture.

但请注意，虽然团队可以是黑匣子，但它们具有另一个著名的盒子的特征——包含薛定谔猫的盒子。薛定谔实验的目的是表明观察行为会改变结果，或者更确切地说，会导致结果发生。同样，你不能进入一个团队，而不是通过在他们周围、坐在他们的会议上、观看他们的站会来改变该团队的行为。你的出现会改变团队的行为，并可能隐藏你试图发现的问题，就像日志语句可能导致并发问题被神奇地擦除一样，至少在一段时间内。

Be aware, though, that while teams can be black boxes, they share a characteristic of another famous box — the one containing Schrödinger’s cat. The point of Schrödinger’s experiment was to show that the act of observing changes the outcome, or rather, causes an outcome to happen. Likewise, you can’t go into a team and not change the behavior of that team by being around them, sitting in their meetings, and watching their standups. Your presence changes the team’s behavior and may hide the problem you’re trying to find, in the same way that a log statement can cause a concurrency issue to be magically erased, at least for some time.

问问题

Ask Questions

询问团队他们的目标是什么。他们能告诉你吗？他们明白为什么这些是目标吗？如果他们不了解自己的工作目标，那么他们的领导（经理、技术负责人、产品经理）就不能很好地让团队参与工作的目的。在几乎每一种激励模式中，人们都需要感受到对工作目的的理解和联系。他们为谁构建这些系统；对客户、业务和团队的潜在影响是什么？他们是否参与了决定这些目标以及他们为实现这些目标而开展的项目？如果不是，为什么不呢？当您看到一个团队将所有时间都花在工程赞助的项目上而忽略了产品/业务项目时，

Ask the team what their goals are. Can they tell you? Do they understand why those are the goals? If they don’t understand the goals of their work, their leaders (manager, tech lead, product manager) aren’t doing a good job engaging the team in the purpose of the work. In almost every model of motivation, people need to feel an understanding and connection with the purpose of their work. Who are they building these systems for; what is the potential impact on the customer, the business, the team? Did they have any part in deciding these goals, and the projects that they’re doing to achieve them? If not, why not? When you see a team spending all of their time on engineering-sponsored projects and neglecting product/business projects, it’s likely that the team doesn’t appreciate or understand the value of the product/business projects they’re supposed to be working on, and therefore they lack the motivation to tackle them.

检查团队动态

Check the Team Dynamics

最后，您可以看看实际的团队动态。人们互相喜欢吗？他们友好吗？他们是在项目上合作，还是每个人都在独立工作？聊天室里，电子邮件里有玩笑吗？他们与其他相邻部门以及他们的产品经理是否有良好的工作关系？这些都是小事，但即使是非常专业的团体，成员之间也往往会有一定程度的个人联系。一群从不互相交谈并且总是在独立项目上工作的人并不是真正的团队合作。如果团队表现良好，那没有任何问题，但鉴于他们不是，这可能会导致您的问题。

Finally, you might take a look at the actual team dynamics. Do people like each other? Are they friendly? Do they collaborate on projects, or is every person working on something independently? Is there banter in the chat room, in emails? Do they have a good working relationship with other adjacent departments, and with their product managers? These are little things, but even very professional groups tend to have a degree of personal connection between the members. A bunch of people who never talk to each other and are always working on independent projects are not really working as a team. There would be nothing wrong with that if the team were performing well, but given that they’re not, this may be contributing to your problem.

跳进去帮忙

Jump In to Help

有时经理的经理选择处理团队经理只需要解决的问题。毕竟，您根据团队的产出来衡量经理，如果事情进展不顺利，他有责任解决它。这是真的，但正如我有时会介入并帮助调试复杂的系统中断，即使我很少编写代码，也可以介入并帮助调试您看到的团队问题，尤其是当相关经理遇到困难时。这可能是一个教导经理并帮助他成长的机会。它还可以揭示组织的更多基本问题，例如缺乏高级业务领导，即使是最好的经理也无法单独识别或解决。

Sometimes managers of managers choose to approach such problems as something that the team manager just needs to fix. You measure the manager on the output of his team, after all, and it is his responsibility to fix it if things are not going well. This is true, but just as I sometimes jump in and help debug complex system outages even though I rarely write code, it’s OK to jump in and help debug team issues as you see them, particularly when the manager in question is struggling. It can be an opportunity to teach the manager and help him grow. It can also reveal more foundational problems with the organization, such as a lack of senior business leadership that even the best managers can’t identify or resolve alone.

保持好奇心

Be Curious

当涉及到组织问题时，追寻为什么会给你提供匹配的模式，并提供教训。通过经常进行调试，我们可以更好地进行调试，并了解哪些区域往往会首先出现问题，哪些指标对理解问题最有价值。我们通过推动自己和我们的管理团队真正深入了解组织问题，寻找原因，以便我们能够在未来更快地解决此类问题，从而成为更好的领导者。如果没有动力去理解为什么，我们依靠魅力和运气来见证我们的管理生涯，并做出我们的招聘和解雇决定。因此，在真正从错误中吸取教训时，我们有一个巨大的盲点。

The pursuit of why when it comes to organizational problems is the thing that gives you patterns to match on, and lessons to lead with. We get better at debugging by doing it often, and learn which areas tend to break first and which indicators provide the most value for understanding issues. We become better leaders by pushing ourselves and our management teams to really get to the bottom of organizational issues, searching for why so that we can more quickly resolve such issues in the future. Without the drive to understand why, we rely on charm and luck to see us through our management careers and to make our hiring and firing decisions. As a result, we have a huge blindspot when it comes to truly learning from our mistakes.

设定期望并按时交付

Setting Expectations and Delivering on Schedule

工程经理经常被问到的最令人沮丧的问题之一是为什么要花这么长时间。我们以前都被问过这个问题。作为实践工程师、技术主管和小团队的经理，我们被问过这个问题，但是当你管理团队经理时，这个问题的强度会达到一个全新的水平，因为当你没有深深嵌入细节中。

One of the most frustrating questions that engineering managers get asked regularly is why something is taking so long. We’ve all been asked this question before. We’ve been asked it as hands-on engineers, as tech leads, and as managers of small teams, but the question takes on a whole new level of intensity when you’re managing team managers, because answering it is significantly harder when you aren’t embedded deeply in the details.

首先要做的事情是：希望您被问到这个问题，因为某些事情远远超出了计划。那是最有意义的时候，也是你应该尽最大努力理解场景和答案的时候。

First things first: hopefully you’re being asked this question because something is running over plan by a significant margin. That is the time when it makes the most sense to ask, and when you should do your best to understand the scenario and answer.

可悲的是，当事情花费的时间不超过估计时，我们经常被问到这个问题。当我们的领导层出于某种原因不喜欢最初的估计或根本没有要求时，我们经常被问到这个问题，现在他们很沮丧，尽管没有任何问题。

Sadly, we are often asked this question in times when things are not taking any longer than the estimate. We are often asked this question when our leadership, for whatever reason, either didn’t like the original estimate or didn’t ask for it at all, and now they’re upset, despite nothing going wrong.

因此，即使人们不询问，您也必须始终积极地分享估算和估算更新，尤其是当您认为该项目至关重要或可能需要数周以上的时间时。这意味着您必须积极地进行估算，而且众所周知，软件估算是一个非常困难的过程。就你的团队用来估计的过程、在什么时间尺度、什么项目进行谈判，可能是你在这个级别的工作的一部分。

Therefore, you must always be aggressive about sharing estimates and updates to estimates, even when people don’t ask, especially if you believe that the project is critical or likely to take longer than a few weeks. This means you must be aggressive about getting estimates, and as we all know, software estimation is a very difficult process. Negotiating the process that your team uses to estimate, on what timescale, for what projects, may be part of your job at this level.

工程师通常根本不想进行估算，或者估算超出敏捷冲刺的边界（通常是两周）。如果您认为估算必须相当准确、需求未知或会经常变化，并且大部分工作应该与大部分适合一两次冲刺工作的功能绑定，那么这种理念是完全合理的。话虽如此，但很少有这些事情总是正确的。估计通常很有用，即使它们并不完全准确，因为它们有助于将复杂性升级到团队的其他成员。并非每个项目都必然有经常变化的需求，并且可以进行前期工作以大幅减少使软件评估变得困难的未知数。您可能会争辩说，与简单地逐个冲刺项目冲刺相比，前期工作有时会使整个过程花费更长的时间，您可能是对的，但同样，我们在这里讨论的不仅仅是工程团队。我们谈论的是想要计划和了解工作成本的企业。在某种意义上，我们也在谈论目标设定和学习如何更好地理解我们的软件和系统的复杂性。我们无法完美地预测未来，但教我们的团队如何磨练他们对复杂性和机会的直觉是一个有价值的目标。谈论目标设定和学习如何更好地理解我们的软件和系统的复杂性。我们无法完美地预测未来，但教我们的团队如何磨练他们对复杂性和机会的直觉是一个有价值的目标。谈论目标设定和学习如何更好地理解我们的软件和系统的复杂性。我们无法完美地预测未来，但教我们的团队如何磨练他们对复杂性和机会的直觉是一个有价值的目标。

Engineers often don’t want to estimate at all, or estimate beyond the boundary of an agile sprint (generally two weeks). This philosophy is completely reasonable if you believe that estimates must be fairly accurate, that the requirements are unknown or will change frequently, and that most of the work should be bound to features that mostly fit within one or two sprint efforts. With that said, few of these things are always true. Estimates are often useful even if they aren’t perfectly accurate because they help escalate complexity to the rest of the team. Not every project necessarily has requirements that change frequently, and it’s possible to do up-front work to drastically reduce the unknowns that make software estimation difficult. You may argue that the up-front work sometimes makes the overall process take longer than simply looking at the project sprint by sprint, and you may be right, but again, we’re not just talking about engineering teams here. We’re talking about businesses that want to plan and get ideas of costs for effort. We’re also, in some sense, talking about goal setting and learning how to get better at understanding the complexity of our software and systems. We can’t predict the future perfectly, but teaching our teams how to hone their instincts about complexity and opportunity is a worthy goal.

因此，接受您需要进行某种程度的估计的事实。尝试不同的方法，看看哪些方法对你的公司有用，但要让它成为你团队的习惯。

So, accept the fact that you’ll need to do some degree of estimation. Play with different methods, and see what works for your company, but make it a habit across your teams.

敏捷软件开发的另一个核心要素是强调从过去中学习。当估计错误时，我们从未知的复杂性中学到了什么？我们在什么时候了解什么是值得估计的？关于我们如何传达这些估计以及谁对未命中感到失望，我们学到了什么？

Another core element of agile software development is the emphasis on learning from the past. When estimates are wrong, what are we learning about unknown complexity? What are we learning about what is worth estimating, when? What are we learning about how we communicated those estimates and who was disappointed by the miss?

您的工作是尽可能清楚地说明“长”实际上是什么，提供您对项目时间尺度的最佳视图，并在视图发生变化时主动更新该视图，尤其是当它变得更慢时。

It is your job to make it clear, as best you can, what “long” actually is by providing your best view into the timescale of a project, and proactively updating that view when it changes, especially if it gets much slower.

即使你尽了最大的努力，当你已经清楚什么是“长”时，当你实际上并没有花这么长时间时，或者当你完全无法控制的事情出现并导致时，有时你会被问到这个问题沟通良好的延误。发生这种情况时会很糟糕，而且通常是因为有人感到压力或被迫以比您声称能够交付的速度更快的速度交付。这种情况没有简单的答案。有时耐心地提醒对方事情正在尽可能快地进行并且一切都按计划进行是唯一的解决方案。但责备通常不是一种完全理性的行为，也不是在压力下可以完全避免的行为。

Even with your best efforts, sometimes you’ll be asked this question when you’ve been clear about what “long” is, when you’re not actually taking so long, or when things completely outside of your control have come up and caused delays that were well communicated. It sucks when this happens, and it usually happens because someone is feeling stressed or being pushed to deliver faster than you ever claimed to be able to deliver. There’s no easy answer to this situation. Sometimes patiently reminding the other person that things are going as fast as they can and everything is on schedule is the only solution. But blame is not usually a fully rational exercise, or one that can be totally avoided under stress. Showing some empathy for the person providing pressure and being willing to help out in other ways can go a long way to shifting focus from blame to action.

最后，不要害怕与你的经理、技术主管和业务部门合作，在项目结束时缩小范围，以便在重要的最后期限内完成。作为高级经理，您可能需要参与决胜局并决定哪些功能值得削减，哪些功能对项目的成功至关重要。帮助团队注意这些功能，如果对完成更大的项目至关重要，那么愿意放弃削减某人最喜欢的想法。对你愿意付出的东西要聪明。如果你只在技术质量问题上付出，你只会在项目启动后拖慢团队的速度，所以除了技术优势之外，一定要看看产品特性。

Finally, don’t be afraid to work with your managers, tech leads, and the business to cut scope toward the ends of projects in order to make important deadlines. As the senior manager, you may need to play tiebreaker and make decisions about which features are worth cutting, and which features are essential to the project’s success. Help the team look out for these features, and be willing to take the fall for cutting back on someone’s favorite idea if it’s essential to getting the larger project done. Be smart about what you’re willing to give on. If you give only on matters of technical quality, you’ll just slow down the team after the project is launched, so be sure to look at product features in addition to technical nice-to-haves.

具有挑战性的情况：路线图的不确定性

Challenging Situations: Roadmap Uncertainty

各级管理人员面临的一个非常普遍的问题是更改产品和业务路线图的挑战。尤其是在较小的公司中，很难让人们提前一年承诺明年要完成的工作。即使在大公司，市场变化也可能导致战略上的突然转变，导致项目被放弃，计划工作被取消。

A very common problem that managers at all levels face is the challenge of changing product and business roadmaps. Especially in smaller companies, it’s hard to get people to commit a year in advance to the work that will be done for the next year. Even at big companies, changes in the market can lead to sudden-seeming shifts in strategy that cause projects to be abandoned and planned work to be cancelled.

这对于工程经理来说真的很难处理。战略的变化是被困在“中层管理人员”中感觉最不愉快的地方。您可能几乎没有能力推迟从上面对战略进行的更改，即使您已向团队承诺某些项目将会发生，但有时您不得不因意外更改而撤回该承诺。这会让团队不开心，他们会向你抱怨。因为你对此无能为力，你会觉得它让你无能为力，你的团队可能会觉得他们不是被视为人类，而是被视为公司机器中的齿轮。

This is really hard for engineering managers to deal with. Changes in strategy are where being stuck in “middle management” feels the most unpleasant. You may have very little ability to push back on the changes to strategy coming from above, and even when you’ve promised your team that certain projects will happen, you sometimes have to pull back on that promise because of unexpected changes. This makes the team unhappy, and they complain to you. Because you have no ability to do much about it, you can feel like it exposes you as powerless, and your team might feel that they’re being treated not as humans, but as cogs in the corporate machine.

在这里发挥作用的是次要挑战：当似乎没有明确的优先级工作流程时，您如何为您的团队腾出时间来处理技术债务和其他以工程为重点的项目？毕竟，如果你不花时间自己处理技术问题，你的团队做产品功能的能力就会变慢。然而，产品团队在他们的路线图上永远不会有技术债务，因此规划过程通常意味着没有时间分配给这类工作。

Coming into play here is a secondary challenge: how do you make the time for your team to deal with technical debt and other engineering-focused projects when there doesn’t seem to be a clear process for prioritizing that work? After all, if you don’t put any time into dealing with the technical issues themselves, your team’s ability to do product features will slow down. And yet the product team will never have technical debt on their roadmap, so the planning process often means there is no time allotted for this type of work.

处理路线图不确定性的策略

Strategies for Handling Roadmap Uncertainty

我学到了一些关于构建路线图的策略：

There are few strategies I’ve learned about building a roadmap:

  • 考虑到你工作的公司的规模和阶段，对改变计划的可能性保持现实。如果您的初创公司有每年夏天更改年度计划以考虑上半年的业务成果的历史，请为夏天的变化做好准备，并尽量不要向您的团队承诺需要持续超越的事情那一点。
  • 想想如何将大项目分解成一系列较小的可交付成果，这样你就可以取得一些成果，即使你不一定能完成宏伟的愿景。分解技术工作需要您与产品或业务经理密切合作，以确定如何优先考虑细节。你们所有人现在都应该意识到事情会很快发生变化，因此必须反复重新审视一切，着眼于当下最有价值的东西。
  • 不要过度承诺技术项目的未来。不要承诺“稍后”让您的团队激动人心的技术项目，因为尚未编写好以后的产品路线图。这种想法会让人抱有希望，然后会失望。如果该项目很重要，请立即安排 - 或尽可能接近现在。如果项目不是很重要，你可以把它放在待办事项上，但你应该现实一点，一旦“稍后”轮到，就会有来自业务其他部分的一长串竞争优先级。如果你没有花时间阐明这项工作的价值，它就会被推到一边，转而支持更有价值的项目。
  • 奉献 20%将团队的日程安排到“维持工程”。这意味着留出时间进行重构、修复突出的错误、改进工程流程、进行少量清理以及提供持续支持。在每次计划会议中都要考虑到这一点。不幸的是，20% 不足以完成大型项目，因此需要额外的计划来进行重大技术重写或其他重大技术改进。但是如果没有这 20% 的时间，就会产生负面后果，即错过交付目标以及计划外和令人不快的清理工作。
  • 了解各种工程项目的重要性。产品和商业项目通常有某种价值主张来证明它们的合理性。但是，对于技术项目，并不总是采用同样的严格性。当工程师带着她想做的工程项目来找您时，请考虑通过回答以下问题来构建项目：
    • 那个项目有多大？
    • 它有多重要？
    • 你能向任何询问的人阐明该项目的价值吗？
    • 项目的成功完成对团队意味着什么？

    这些问题的价值在于，您开始以与产品计划相同的方式对待大型技术项目。这些项目有倡导者和目标，有时间表，并且像其他大型计划一样进行管理。这是一个可怕的过程，因为有时您“知道”某事很重要，但您不知道如何以业务重视的方式表达它。尤其是考虑到技术项目的复杂性和衡量工程效率等问题的挑战，您有时会被困在试图向非技术合作伙伴解释技术细节时，他们可能不完全了解您要去哪里或为什么。我的建议是尽最大努力收集数据以支持自己，并讨论完成工作后可能发生的事情。如果您查看一个技术项目并意识到您正在为一个很少更改并且不会对您的技术或业务进行核心改进的系统提出大量工作，那么这可能不值得付出努力。不幸的是，你的团队想要做的所有探索性工程、遗留代码清理和技术质量改进都没有足够的时间，而这个过程将帮助你选择你的战斗。

所以，回到我们不确定的路线图。项目变化。团队甚至可能以您不理解或不同意的方式解散或调动。作为一名经理，你能做的最好的事情就是帮助人们感到有能力解决松散的问题，稳定当前正在进行的项目，并以可控的方式轻松地投入到他们的新工作中。这是一个你可以而且应该反击的区域。确保您的团队有足够的时间来完成当前的工作。此外，推动工程部门参与新工作的早期规划，以便人们对他们正在进行的项目感到兴奋。花点时间自己了解迁移的原因，即使您不完全同意，也要尽自己的一份力量帮助您的团队了解这些原因，并帮助他们了解新目标。

So, back to our uncertain roadmap. Projects change. Teams may even be disbanded or moved around in ways that you don’t understand or agree with. As a manager, the best thing you can do is help people feel capable of tying up loose ends, stabilizing the current in-flight projects, and easing into their new work in a controlled fashion. This is an area where you can and should push back. Make sure that your teams get adequate time to finish up current work. Furthermore, push for engineering involvement in the early planning for the new work so that people can get excited about the projects they are moving on to. Take the time yourself to understand the reasons for the move, and even if you don’t totally agree, do your part to help make those reasons clear to your team and help them understand the new goals. The calmer you can be in the face of these changes, and the better you can show (or fake) enthusiasm for the new direction, the easier the transition will be for your whole team.

当你面对海浪时，你可以让它们把你拉下来，或者你可以学习如何冲浪。挂10。

When you are faced with waves, you can let them pull you under or you can learn how to surf. Hang 10.

保持技术相关性

Staying Technically Relevant

我经常从经理那里听到的一个问题是“我如何在技术上保持相关性？” 我们知道，如果不对我们的技术技能进行投资，我们就有可能与该领域脱节并在我们的时代之前过时。但是，技术相关性对您真正有什么作用？要回答这个问题，让我们首先澄清您的技术责任。

One question I hear a lot from managers is “How do I remain technically relevant?” We know that without investment into our technical skills, we run the risk of becoming out of touch with the field and obsolete before our time. But what does technical relevance really do for you? To answer that question, let’s start by clarifying your technical responsibility.

监督技术投资

Oversee Technical Investment

为了向前发展，系统需要不断的技术工作：新的语言、框架、基础设施和特性。只有有限的开发时间和精力可以用于改进这些系统，您有责任确保团队将其技术赌注放在正确的地方。您通过将提议的技术项目和改进与产品的未来或客户需求相匹配来监督这些投资。从整体上查看项目组合，您可以看到最需要或机会最大的领域，并相应地集中团队的努力。

To move forward, systems need constant technical work: new languages, frameworks, infrastructure, and features. There’s only a limited amount of development time and energy that can go into improving these systems, and you’re accountable for making sure the team is placing its technical bets in the right places. You oversee these investments by matching the proposed technical projects and improvements to the future of the product or customer needs. Looking holistically across the portfolio of projects, you can see where the areas of greatest need or opportunity lie, and focus the team’s efforts accordingly.

提出知情的问题

Ask Informed Questions

你不是识别所有技术项目的人。对团队的技术投资负责并不意味着您亲自进行研究以寻找潜在的投资。相反，您通过提问来引导这些投资。目前有哪些项目，他们发现了哪些惊喜或瓶颈？团队如何考虑系统的未来？哪些团队需要更多的工程师，为什么他们认为他们需要更多的人？哪些团队速度较慢但不想增加更多人员来提高他们的吞吐量？他们为什么现在提倡这个特定的项目？您需要对这项工作有足够的了解，才能发现错误的努力并评估拟议的投资。

You’re not the person who identifies all technical projects. Having accountability for the team’s technical investments doesn’t mean that you personally do the research to find potential investments. Instead, you guide these investments by asking questions. What are the current projects, and what surprises or bottlenecks have they uncovered? How is the team thinking about the future of the systems? Which teams are asking for more engineers, and why do they think they need more people? Which teams are slow but don’t want to add more people to improve their throughput? Why are they advocating for this specific project right now? You need to know enough about the work to sniff out misguided efforts and evaluate proposed investments.

分析和解释工程和业务权衡

Analyze and Explain Engineering and Business Tradeoffs

通过了解您的团队对什么感到兴奋以及他们看重什么，您可以围绕产品计划团结他们。当一个功能想法在技术上很困难并且当一个技术想法有不可预见的业务影响时，你知道足以引起关注。您确保工程师在了解业务视角和产品路线图的未来的情况下做出决策。当技术工作需要不确定的研究和开发时，您能够向非技术同行解释为什么存在这种不确定性。了解业务和客户目标后，您可以就哪些技术项目可以在合理的时间范围内实现这些目标提供指导。

By knowing what your teams are excited about and what they value, you can rally them around product initiatives. You know enough to raise concerns when a feature idea is technically difficult and when a technical idea has unforeseen business implications. You ensure that engineers make decisions with an understanding of the business perspective and the future of the product roadmap. When technical work requires uncertain research and development, you’re capable of explaining why that uncertainty exists to your nontechnical counterparts. Understanding the business and customer goals, you offer guidance as to which technical projects can achieve those goals within reasonable time frames.

提出具体要求

Make Specific Requests

作为主管级经理，您仍然需要对组织中的技术有足够的了解，才能提出具体的要求，而不会因问题而分散高级工程师的注意力。通过充分了解您的团队、项目和瓶颈的进展，您可以过滤掉技术上不可行的想法，并将新计划映射到正在进行的项目中。这些特定的要求应该用于保持团队的生产力并平衡技术风险与组织目标。这是一个如何工作的示例：

As a director-level manager, you still need to have enough understanding of the technology in your organization to make specific requests without distracting the senior engineers with questions. By knowing enough about the progress of your teams, the projects, and bottlenecks, you can filter out technically infeasible ideas and map new initiatives onto ongoing projects. These specific requests should be used to keep the teams productive and balance technical risks with organizational goals. Here’s an example of how this works:

您的 VP 告诉您，她希望在下个季度之前改善搜索体验以增加活跃用户，并且她可以为您提供更多工程师来更快地完成工作。您知道团队无法有效地添加工程师来修改搜索，因为它正在被重写。相反，您可以指示他们对工作进行优先级以更早地公开新 API，以便产品团队最终可以运行他们一直要求的一些测试。你向副总裁解释什么是可能的，并确保团队专注于完成可以实现更高级别目标的工作。

没有足够技术的经理有时会发现自己养成了充当高级管理人员和团队中间人的坏习惯。他们没有过滤请求，而是将它们转发给团队，然后将团队的响应转发给管理层。这不是一个增值角色。

Managers who don’t stay technical enough sometimes find themselves in the bad habit of acting as a go-between for senior management and their teams. Instead of filtering requests, they relay them to the team and then relay the team’s response back up to management. This is not a value-add role.

将您的经验用作肠道检查

Use Your Experience as a Gut Check

这是一项高度技术性的工作，不了解和欣赏软件工程和技术的挑战和权衡的人无法完成。如果您的团队没有很好地投入时间，这将反映出您作为他们的领导者没有帮助他们做出更好的决定。依靠你的直觉来指导你将时间和注意力花在哪里，不要仅仅因为你忙于与人和组织挑战而忽视你的技术直觉。

This is a highly technical job that can’t be done by a person who does not understand and appreciate the challenges and tradeoffs of software engineering and technology. If your team invests their time poorly, it will reflect on you as their leader for not helping them come to better decisions. Rely on your instincts to guide where you spend your time and attention, and don’t neglect your technical instincts just because you are busy with people and organizational challenges.

鉴于您的技术责任水平，您应该如何投入时间以保持技术相关性？

Given your level of technical responsibility, how should you invest your time in order to stay technically relevant?

  • 阅读代码。偶尔花时间阅读系统中的一些代码可以帮助提醒您它的外观。有时，它还会向您显示事情变得丑陋且需要注意的地方。查看代码审查和拉取请求可以让您深入了解正在发生的变化。
  • 选择一个未知区域，并请工程师向您解释。花几个小时与一位正在从事您不了解的事情的工程师一起工作，并请他教您有关该领域的知识。去白板或共享屏幕，让他与你配对，只需一点点零钱。
  • 参加尸检。发生停电时，优先考虑参加停电后的汇报。这些会议通常充满了关于编写和部署软件的过程的详细信息，当您不是每天编码时会错过这些细节。您认为显而易见的标准已被忽略或忽略。团队之间缺乏沟通，工具的弊大于利。在失败的时候，你可以最清楚地看到问题出现在哪里，并且你知道哪里需要你的注意力。
  • 保持紧跟软件开发过程中的行业趋势。管理人员的一个主要弱点是与实际开发、测试、部署和监控代码的工具和流程脱节。这些是新想法可以使您的团队显着提高效率的地方。并非每个趋势都值得追求，但要花时间了解其他团队如何交付软件，这样您就可以让您的团队不断发展。
  • 在公司之外培养技术人员网络。最好的故事来自你信任的人。与工程和工程管理领域的同行保持联系，可以让人们就新趋势征求意见。使用这个网络来获得关于新技术的博客文章、演讲和推销背后的真实体验。
  • 绝不停止学习。查找有关技术的文章和博客文章并阅读它们。观看谈话。选择一些你真正好奇的东西并深入挖掘，即使它与你的团队或公司无关。不要害怕向你的团队提问，并寻找机会向他们学习。学习是一种技能，你可以通过练习来保持头脑敏锐。

评估你自己的经历

Assessing Your Own Experience

  • 如何你经常和你的跳级报告交谈吗？您是与他们一对一见面，还是分组见面？您如何主动联系您的团队？你花了多少时间寻找信息，而不是被动地处理你收到的信息？你最后一次参加团队会议是什么时候？
  • 在不查看现有文档的情况下，为向您报告的工程经理写下您对职位描述的看法。
    • 他们负责什么？
    • 你如何评价他们？
    • 您认为哪些领域对成功最重要？
  • 现在，看看贵公司使用的职位描述。与该描述相比，您所写的内容是否存在差异，或者它们是否匹配？鉴于该描述，您在评估它们时可能会忽略哪些内容？
  • 最后，快速回顾一下他们目前的表现。哪些领域需要指导和发展？花时间在你的下一个 1-1 中讨论这个问题。
  • 如果您管理的区域超出了您的技术舒适区，您多久检查一次该区域以确保一切顺利？你有没有花一些时间从那个领域的经理那里学到一些关于成功担任这个角色需要什么？在过去的三个月里，你学到了什么新东西，可以帮助你更好地了解这个团队？
  • 如果您有一个团队显然比其他团队运行更顺畅，您注意到他们的流程有什么不同？他们的互动？他们的经理做事是否与其他经理不同？团队如何与该经理互动，该经理如何与您互动？
  • 你对经理的面试流程是怎样的？您是否花时间谈论他们的个人价值观和管理理念？您是否让团队与他们的潜在经理面谈，或者您是否将他们排除在流程之外？您是否花时间为候选人获取推荐信？
  • 本季度贵组织的目标是什么？今年？您如何将产品目标（如果有）与技术目标结合起来？您的组织是否有团队充分理解的任务？

1Andrew S. Grove，高产出管理（纽约：Vintage Books，1983 年）。

1 Andrew S. Grove, High Output Management (New York: Vintage Books, 1983).

第 8 章大联盟

Chapter 8. The Big Leagues

高级经理的日常工作很大程度上取决于你所在的公司。如果我说我经营一个 70 人的创业工程组织的工作与高级经理的工作相同，那我就傻了。在财富 500 强公司拥有数千名员工的经理。从一般的角度来看，书上书上的书是关于规模公司的高级管理人员的。我在本章末尾列出了一些推荐阅读，以获取通用的高级领导建议。所有这些书都是高级领导者的绝妙且必不可少的指南。

The day-to-day job of a senior manager depends greatly on the company you’re in. It would be silly of me to say that my job running a startup engineering organization of 70 people was the same as the job held by a senior manager who’s over thousands of people at a Fortune 500 company. Books upon books upon books are written about senior management at scaled companies from a general perspective. I’ve listed some recommended reading at the end of this chapter for general-purpose senior leadership advice. All of these books are fantastic and essential guidelines for senior leaders.

但我们不是通用的高级领导者。我们是技术高级领导。这本书是为那些编写了一段时间代码并最终进入管理领域并沿着这条道路成功发展职业的工程师而写的。作为工程师，我们有一些共同的责任，这些责任特定于我们作为技术专家的角色，部分来自我们在这个瞬息万变的世界中工作的成长经历。

But we’re not general-purpose senior leaders. We’re technology senior leadership. This book is for the engineer who wrote code for a while and eventually moved into management, and successfully grew a career up along that path. And as engineers, we share some common responsibilities that are specific to our role as technologists and come partially from our upbringing working in that ever-changing world.

作为技术高级经理，我们为组织带来特殊技能。特别是，我们愿意根据需要接受和推动变革。我们可以质疑我们现在做事的方式，如果我们目前的运营方式不起作用，我们可以尝试不同的事情。我们了解技术发展迅速，我们希望我们的组织不断发展以跟上这些变化。我们有一个独特的角色，但我们仍然需要在我们的一般高级管理角色中取得成功。仅仅成为变革推动者是不够的；我们必须创建一个能够成功贯彻我们想要推动的变革的组织。

As technical senior managers, we bring special skills to an organization. In particular, we bring a willingness to embrace and drive change as needed. We’re able to question the way we do things now, and try different things if our current way of operating isn’t working. We understand that technology evolves quickly, and we want our organizations to evolve to keep up with these changes. We have a unique role, but we still need to succeed in our general senior management roles. It’s not enough to be a change agent; we have to create an organization that can successfully follow through on the changes we want to push.

你的第一份工作是成为领导者。公司向您寻求关于做什么、去哪里、如何行动、如何思考和重视什么的指导。你帮助为互动定下基调。人们加入公司是因为他们相信你，相信你雇佣的人，相信你帮助制定的使命。

Your first job is to be a leader. The company looks to you for guidance on what to do, where to go, how to act, how to think, and what to value. You help set the tone for interactions. People join the company because they believe in you, in the people you hired, and in the mission you helped to craft.

你有能力在没有完美信息的情况下做出艰难的决定，并愿意面对这些决定的后果。

You’re capable of making hard decisions without perfect information and willing to face the consequences of those decisions.

您能够了解您的业务的当前格局，并了解其许多潜在的未来。您知道如何为未来的几个月和几年进行计划，以便您的组织最适合处理这些潜在的未来并在它们出现时抓住机会。

You’re capable of understanding the current landscape of your business, as well as seeing into its many potential futures. You know how to plan for the months and years ahead so that your organization is best suited to handle those potential futures and capture opportunities as they come along.

您了解组织结构以及它如何影响团队的工作。您知道实施加强而不是削弱这种结构的管理的价值。

You understand organizational structure and how it impacts the work of teams. You know the value of putting in place management that strengthens this structure rather than undermining it.

您可以以富有成效的方式参与政治，以推动组织和业务向前发展。您与工程以外的同行合作得很好，并在解决广泛的问题时寻求他们的观点。

You can play politics in a productive way, in order to move the organization and the business forward. You work well with your peers outside of engineering and seek out their perspectives in addressing issues with a wide scope.

即使您不同意，您也了解如何不同意某个决定并承诺兑现该决定。

You understand how to disagree with a decision and commit to deliver on it even though you disagree.

您知道如何让个人和组织对其产出负责。

You know how to hold individuals and organizations accountable for their output.

在他的《高产出管理》一书中，1 Andy Grove 将管理任务分为四大类：

In his book High Output Management,1 Andy Grove breaks down management tasks into four general categories:

信息收集或信息共享
参加会议，阅读和撰写电子邮件，与人一对一交谈，收集观点。强大的高级领导者能够快速综合大量信息，识别该信息的关键要素，并以他们能够理解的方式与适当的第三方共享信息。
轻推
通过提问而不是下达命令来提醒人们他们的承诺。大型团队的领导者很难在任何方向上强行引导该团队，因此应依靠推动团队成员来保持整个组织的正常运行。
做决定
采取相互矛盾的观点和不完整的信息并设定方向，知道错误决定的后果将影响您和整个团队。如果决策容易，那么对管理者和领导者的需求就会少得多。然而，任何花费大量时间管理的人都会告诉你，做决定是工作中最消耗精力和压力的部分之一。
角色建模
向人们展示公司的价值观是什么。显示你的承诺。即使您不喜欢，也要为团队树立最佳榜样。

无论您是首席技术官、副总裁、总经理还是工程主管，您的日子都受到这四项任务的影响。

Whether you’re a CTO, a VP, a general manager, or a head of engineering, your days are shaped by those four tasks.

我的工作是什么？

我从业界喜欢称之为“非传统背景”的地方来到工程学。在与来自更传统 CS 背景的人互动时，我遭受（遭受？）强烈的冒名顶替综合症。当领导我认为比我更有技术的人时，这尤其困难。

I came to engineering from what the industry likes to call a “nontraditional background.” I suffered (suffer?) a strong sense of impostor syndrome when interacting with folks from more traditional CS backgrounds. This was especially difficult when leading folks whom I perceived to be more technical than I.

这种背景，加上被视为聪明和“正确”的强烈愿望，有时会导致一些关于技术方向的低效对话。我发现自己纯粹基于技术优点来争论语言选择或技术的优点。当这件事发生时，我成了另一个工程师，在一群工程师中争论不休。

This background, combined with a strong desire to be seen as smart and “right,” sometimes led to some less-than-productive conversations about technology directions. I’d find myself arguing the merits of a language choice or technology purely based on the technical merits. When this happened I became another engineer arguing in a group of engineers.

我花了很长时间才意识到我的工作不是成为房间里最聪明的人。这不是“正确的”。相反，我的职责是帮助团队做出最佳决策，并帮助他们以可持续和有效的方式实施这些决策。

It took me a long time to realize that my job wasn’t to be the smartest person in the room. It wasn’t to be “right.” Rather, my role was to help the team make the best possible decisions and help them implement them in a sustainable and efficient way.

我关心技术——这是我们作为一个团队做出的每一个决定的一个因素——但仅靠技术并不能打造一个富有成效和快乐的团队。一个好的领导者会塑造技术讨论以注入战略目标并考虑技术决策的非技术影响。这与成为首席工程师、追逐最新的语言或框架或拥有最闪亮的技术无关。这是关于建立一个拥有工具和属性的团队，为我们的客户构建最好的产品。

I care about technology — it’s a factor in every decision we make as a team — but technology alone doesn’t make a productive and happy team. A good leader shapes technology discussions to inject the strategic objectives and take into consideration the nontechnical implications of a technical decision. It’s not about being the lead engineer, chasing the latest language or framework, or having the shiniest technology. It’s about building a team with the tools and attributes to build the best possible product for our customers.

詹姆斯·特恩布尔

James Turnbull

思考技术高级领导的模型

Models for Thinking About Tech Senior Leadership

我对 CTO 的工作有非常固执的看法，尤其是当它适用于以产品为中心的初创公司时。我支持它，但我意识到这并不是所有公司 CTO 的通用模型。我也知道高层管理人员有很多混乱。工程副总裁在哪里适合？首席信息官呢？这是我们需要填补的角色吗？产品团队呢？

I have a very opinionated view of the job of the CTO, especially as it applies to product-focused startups. I stand by it, but I realize that it’s not the universal model for CTOs at all companies. I also know that there’s a great deal of muddiness in senior levels of management. Where does the VP of Engineering fit in? How about the Chief Information Officer? Is that a role we need to fill? What about the product team?

我不会试图涵盖高级领导层的所有角色变体，而是首先解释高级管理层可以扮演的一些最常见的角色，以及这些角色如何组合在一起。这些描述可能对您的公司有意义，也可能没有。有的人会玩几个部分，有的人只会玩一两个，有的公司甚至不需要人来玩所有这些部分。所有这些都在足够大的公司中分解，此时您通常必须逐个部门地查看这些角色。但通过介绍分类法，我希望能帮助您考虑在各种高级领导职位上取得成功所需的可能技能。常见的角色包括：

Instead of trying to cover all of the variants of roles in senior leadership, I’m going to start by explaining some of the most common roles that senior management can play, and how those roles can fit together. These descriptions may make sense for your company, and they may not. Some people will be able to play several parts, some people will be able to play only one or two, and some companies won’t even need people to play all of these parts. All of them break down at large-enough companies, at which point you often have to look at these roles division by division. But by presenting a taxonomy, I hope to help you consider the possible skills you’ll need to be successful in various senior leadership positions. The common roles include:

研发（R&D）
一些公司专注于扩展技术的前沿，因此可能在技术组织中拥有一位专注于实验、研究和新技术生成的高级领导。这个角色可能拥有技术战略，或者它可能纯粹是一个寻找新想法的角色。
技术战略/有远见
技术战略满足产品开发。此人通常还管理产品组织。他专注于如何使用技术来发展业务，并致力于预测技术在应用于公司行业时的演变。这与研发的不同之处在于，有远见的人通常不关注研究潜力。他利用业务和技术趋势来指导他的决策。
组织
组织经理指导组织中的结构和人员。她拥有为团队配备人员的计划以及组织结构，以确保相应地为项目配备人员。这个角色通常与“执行”配对，接下来会讨论。
执行
通常与“组织”配对，此人确保事情真正完成。他帮助调整路线图、计划工作并协调大量工作。他确保项目得到优先考虑。他打破障碍，解决冲突并做出决定，以使团队前进。
面对技术，外部
当一家公司向其他公司销售基于软件的产品时，通常期望其中一位高级技术领导者参与这个销售周期。她可能会参加客户会议并在会议上发言以鼓励使用该产品。为招聘目的而投资建立工程品牌的公司可能还需要一位高级领导者通过在会议和招聘活动中发言来发挥这一作用。
基础设施和技术运营经理
这是负责所有技术基础设施和基础设施运营的人。根据公司和发展阶段的不同，这个角色可能关注成本、关注安全或关注扩展。
企业主管
这是一个首先关注业务本身的人。此人了解行业并高度了解业务的其他基本功能。他平衡了内部发展需求和业务增长需求，并拥有高水平的项目优先级。

以下是我个人和远距离观察到的这些角色的一些组合：

Here are some combinations of these roles that I’ve observed personally and from a distance:

  • 业务主管、技术战略、组织和执行：CTO 或工程主管 (VP/SVP)
  • 研发、技术战略、技术的外部面貌：CTO、首席科学家、首席架构师，有时是首席产品官，通常用于销售基于软件的产品的公司
  • 组织、执行、业务执行：工程副总裁、总经理
  • 基础架构经理、组织和执行：CTO/CIO，可能是技术运营副总裁
  • 技术战略、业务执行和执行：产品负责人（或首席产品官），有时是 CTO
  • 研发、业务主管：CTO或首席科学家、联合创始人
  • 组织和执行：工程副总裁，有时是参谋长

如您所见，组织可以根据业务需求以不同的方式混合、匹配和定义这些角色。CTO 的角色尤其会根据公司的不同而极大地改变其关注点，尽管大多数强大的 CTO 都在他们的指挥下拥有战略职能，无论是专注于业务，还是技术战略，或两者兼而有之。

As you can see, organizations can mix and match and define these roles in different ways depending on business needs. The CTO role in particular changes its focus wildly depending on the company, although most strong CTOs have a strategic function under their command, whether it’s business-focused, technology strategy, or both.

什么是工程副总裁？

What’s a VP of Engineering?

在 CTO 是所有工程的执行经理、负责战略领导和监督的组织中，工程副总裁做什么？优秀的工程副总裁是什么样的？

In an organization where the CTO is the executive manager of all of engineering, responsible for strategic leadership and oversight, what does the VP of Engineering do? What does a great VP of Engineering look like?

根据组织的需要，工程副总裁的角色与首席技术官的角色一样多变。但是，VP 角色与 CTO 角色有一个明显的区别。副总裁通常处于工程师管理职业阶梯的顶端。这通常意味着副总裁应该是一个经验丰富的人员、项目、团队和部门经理。

The VP of Engineering role varies just as much as the CTO role does, based on the needs of the organization. However, the VP role has one obvious difference from the CTO role. The VP is usually at the top of the management career ladder for engineers. This generally means that the VP is expected to be an experienced manager of people, projects, teams, and departments.

随着公司的发展，副总裁级别的角色从以组织为中心的工作转变为业务战略职位是很常见的。这些人经常充当部门的迷你 CTO，平衡战略和管理。您最终可能会有多人担任“工程副总裁”角色，他们负责部分工程团队。随着时间的推移，他们的角色变得更加注重战略，而组织管理职责更多地落在他们的副手或高级主管级别。让我们把大公司的复杂性放在一边，专注于你最有可能在只有一个人担任这个角色的公司中遇到的工程副总裁。

As companies grow, it’s common for the VP-level role to change from an organizationally focused job to a business strategy position. These people often act as mini-CTOs for divisions, balancing strategy and management. You may end up with multiple people in “VP of Engineering” roles who are responsible for portions of the engineering team. Their roles become more strategy-focused over time, while the organizational management duties fall more to their deputies at the director or senior director level. Let’s put the complexities of large companies aside and focus on the VP of Engineering that you’ll most likely encounter in a company that has a single person in this role.

作为团队日常运营的负责人，一个好的工程副总裁对流程和细节都有扎实的把握。她能够一次跟踪多个飞行中的计划并确保它们一切顺利。通常，优秀的工程副总裁被描述为拥有出色的“地面游戏”。这个人能够深入细节并使事情在低水平上发生。虽然一些 CTO 会这样做，但如果同时有 CTO 和工程副总裁，VP 通常是推动想法执行的人，而 CTO 则专注于更大的战略和公司内的技术地位。

As the person in charge of the day-to-day operations of the team, a good VP of Engineering has a solid handle on processes and details. She’s capable of tracking several in-flight initiatives at once and making sure they’re all going well. Often a great VP of Engineering is described as having a good “ground game.” This person is capable of dropping into the details and making things happen at a low level. While some CTOs will do this, if there’s both a CTO and a VP of Engineering, the VP is usually the one pushing the execution of ideas, while the CTO focuses on larger strategy and the position of technology within the company.

工程副总裁还承担着大量的管理职责。她将开发路线图与招聘计划保持一致，规划团队需要如何发展，以便在团队预期增长的情况下有意义。她可能会与招聘部门密切合作并运行招聘流程，以确保简历筛选和面试顺利进行。她应该成为工程管理团队的教练，识别和改进现有人才，并与 HR 合作为这些领导者提供培训和发展资源。

The VP of Engineering also handles a significant amount of management responsibility. She aligns the development roadmap to the hiring plan, planning out how teams need to evolve in order to make sense given the expected growth in the team. She may work closely with recruiting and run the hiring process, ensuring that résumé screening and interviewing are going smoothly. She should be a coach to the engineering management team, identifying and improving existing talent and working with HR to provide training and development resources for those leaders.

工程副总裁的工作既是一项大工作，也是一项注重细节的工作。这是招聘如此困难的原因之一，尽管大多数公司都需要从外部招聘这个角色。这个人必须善于快速了解组织中正在发生的事情。她必须能够获得人们的信任，并在管理和领导方面表现出智慧。不幸的是，大多数工程师不愿意信任没有技术信誉的人，但许多处于这种资历级别的经理不会有兴趣通过艰苦的技术面试过程来承担主要关注组织管理的角色。

The VP of Engineering job is both a big one and a detail-oriented one. This is one of the reasons it’s such a hard job to hire for, even though most companies will need to hire this role in from outside. This person has to be good at quickly understanding what’s going on in an organization. She must be able to gain people’s trust and show wisdom in management and leadership. Unfortunately, most engineers are reluctant to trust people without technical credibility, but many managers at this level of seniority won’t be interested in going through a hard technical interview process only to take on a role that’s mostly focused on organizational management.

工程副总裁也需要在组织战略中占有一席之地，而且通常她完全拥有这个战略。她将大量参与帮助团队设定目标以实现业务可交付成果，这意味着她需要与产品团队密切配合。她必须确保路线图切合实际，并将业务目标转化为技术组织可实现的目标。她应该有很强的业务和产品直觉，以及让团队交付大型项目的记录，包括谈判交付成果的能力。

The VP of Engineering also needs to have some stake in organizational strategy, and often she owns this strategy entirely. She’ll be heavily involved in helping teams set goals to achieve business deliverables, and that means she’ll need to be closely aligned with the product team. She must ensure that the roadmap is realistic and that the business goals are translated into achievable goals for the technology organization. She should have a strong business and product instinct and a track record of getting teams to deliver big projects, including the ability to negotiate deliverables.

我认识的在这个职位上表现出色的人都是有能力的工程师，他们非常关心他们的团队，并且更愿意远离聚光灯，支持创建高绩效组织。他们对让人们有效合作的复杂性感兴趣。他们希望自己的团队快乐，但他们知道将快乐与成就感联系起来很重要。他们向其他高级领导代表团队的健康，并培养健康的协作文化。他们非常乐于识别流程中的差距并管理高度复杂、详细的工作，而不会不知所措。

The people I know who excel in this role are capable engineers who care deeply about their teams and prefer to stay out of the spotlight in favor of creating high-performing organizations. They’re interested in the complexities of getting people to work together effectively. They want their teams to be happy, but they know that it’s important to tie that happiness to a sense of accomplishment. They represent the health of the team to the other senior leaders, and cultivate a healthy, collaborative culture. They are very comfortable identifying gaps in processes and managing highly complex, detailed work without getting overwhelmed.

什么是首席技术官？

What’s a CTO?

在小型公司或初创公司，“高级管理人员”通常意味着您的头衔是 CTO。然而，CTO 工作是技术领域中定义最不明确的角色之一。如果你是 CTO，你应该做什么？如果你想成为 CTO，你需要做什么才能到达那里？

At a small company or startup, “senior management” often implies that your title is CTO. And yet the CTO job is one of the least well-defined roles in the technical world. If you’re a CTO, what are you supposed to be doing? If you want to become a CTO, what do you need to do to get there?

让我们先谈谈 CTO 不是什么。CTO 不是工程角色。CTO 不是技术阶梯的顶端，也不是工程师在其职业生涯中应该努力实现的自然进步。这不是大多数喜欢编码、架构和深度技术设计的人喜欢做的角色。因此，CTO 不一定是公司中最好的工程师。

Let’s start by talking about what a CTO is not. CTO is not an engineering role. CTO is not the top of the technical ladder, and it is not the natural progression engineers should strive to achieve over the course of their careers. It’s not a role most people who love coding, architecture, and deep technical design would enjoy doing. It follows that the CTO is not necessarily the best engineer in the company.

现在，顺便说一句：如果不是最好的代码编写者和工程阶梯的自然巅峰，CTO 是什么？

Now, with that out of the way: what is a CTO, if not the best writer of code and the natural pinnacle of the engineering ladder?

定义 CTO 角色的挑战在于，如果您查看拥有该头衔的人，您会看到许多不同的表现形式。有些是技术联合创始人。其他人是早期工程师中最好的。有些人是从公司开始的，而其他人（比如我自己）是随着时间的推移而被提拔的。有些人在担任工程副总裁后成为首席技术官。有些专注于工程、招聘和招聘的人员和流程。其他人则专注于技术架构或产品路线图。一些 CTO 是公司面向外部技术世界的面孔。一些 CTO 没有直接下属，而另一些则管理整个工程组织。

The challenge in defining the role of the CTO is that if you look at the folks who hold that title, you’ll see many different manifestations. Some are the technical cofounders. Others were the best of the early engineers. Some started at the company with the title, while others (such as myself) were promoted into it over time. Some became CTO after being the VP of Engineering. Some focus on the people and processes of engineering, hiring, and recruiting. Others focus on the technical architecture or the product roadmap. Some CTOs are the face of the company to the external technical world. Some CTOs have no direct reports, while others manage the entire engineering organization.

在看了所有这些不同的例子之后，我能给你的最好的定义是，CTO 是公司当前发展阶段的技术领导者。对我来说，这个定义相当不令人满意，并且错过了工作中最困难的部分。为了扩展，CTO 应该是公司当前发展阶段所需的战略技术主管。

After looking at all these different examples, the best definition I can give you is that the CTO is the technical leader at the company’s current stage of evolution. To me, that definition is rather unsatisfying, and misses the hardest part of the job. To expand, the CTO should be the strategic technical executive the company needs in its current stage of evolution.

我所说的“战略”是什么意思？CTO 着眼长远，并帮助规划业务的未来以及使之成为可能的要素。

What do I mean by “strategic”? The CTO thinks about the long term, and helps to plan the future of the business and the elements that make that possible.

我所说的“行政”是什么意思？CTO 采用这种战略思维，并通过分解问题并指导人们针对它执行来帮助使其成为现实和可操作的。

What do I mean by “executive”? The CTO takes that strategic thinking and helps to make it real and operational by breaking down the problem and directing people to execute against it.

那么，CTO 实际上是做什么的呢？

So, what does a CTO actually do?

首先，CTO 必须关心和了解业务，并且能够从技术的角度塑造业务战略。他首先是执行官，其次是技术专家。如果 CTO 在高管席上没有一席之地，并且不了解公司面临的业务挑战，那么他就无法指导技术解决这些挑战。首席技术官可以确定可以使用技术为公司创建新的或更大的业务线以符合公司整体战略的领域。或者他可以简单地确保技术始终在不断发展，以预测和实现业务和产品路线图的潜在未来。

First and foremost, a CTO must care about and understand the business, and be able to shape business strategy through the lens of technology. He is an executive first, a technologist second. If the CTO doesn’t have a seat at the executive table and doesn’t understand the business challenges the company faces, there’s no way he can guide the technology to solve those challenges. The CTO may identify areas where technology can be used to create new or bigger lines of business for the company that align with the overall company strategies. Or he may simply ensure that the technology is always evolving to anticipate and enable the potential futures of the business and product roadmap.

无论如何，CTO 必须了解企业最大的技术机会和风险在哪里，并专注于利用它们。如果他专注于招聘、保留、流程和人员管理，那是因为这是当时技术团队最关注的事情。我提出这个想法与 CTO 作为“首席书呆子”应该专注于纯技术问题的想法形成鲜明对比。

No matter what, the CTO must understand where the biggest technical opportunities and risks for the business are and focus on capitalizing on them. If he is focused on recruiting, retention, process, and people management, that’s because it’s the most important thing for the technology team to focus on at the time. I present this idea in contrast to the notion that the CTO should focus on purely technical issues, as the “chief nerd.”

强大的 CTO 还具有重要的管理责任和影响力。这并不总是意味着他们深入参与日常管理，但保持您塑造业务方向和业务战略的能力的一部分是让人们支持解决您认为会影响业务的问题. 其他高管将对技术有想法和需求。CTO 必须保护技术团队不成为一个纯粹的想法执行部门，而不倾向于自己的需求和自己的想法。

Strong CTOs also have significant management responsibility and influence. This doesn’t always mean they’re deeply involved in the day-to-day management, but part of maintaining your ability to shape the direction of the business and the business strategy is putting people behind solving the problems you believe will impact the business. Other executives will have ideas and needs for technology. The CTO must protect the technology team from becoming a pure execution arm for ideas without tending to its own needs and its own ideas.

当团队变得非常庞大时，事情变得很棘手，CTO 开始聘请 VP 来管理所有人。许多 CTO 将所有的管理职责都交给了 VP，有时甚至不让 VP 向他们汇报。作为一个没有报告权的高管，要保持影响力和有效性是非常困难的。

Things get tricky when the team grows to be very large, and the CTO starts to hire VPs to manage all the people. Many CTOs give up all of their management responsibilities to their VPs, sometimes going so far as to not even have the VPs reporting to them. It’s incredibly difficult to maintain influence and effectiveness as an executive with no reporting power.

我在以前的雇主那里清楚地看到了这一点，大型业务领域的技术人员中最资深的成员通常会担任该领域的 CTO。这些人总是备受尊重，技术精湛。他们了解业务及其技术挑战，并经常被要求帮助激励工程团队并帮助招聘。然而，他们很难取得成功，因为他们往往缺乏对任何团队的直接管理监督，而且由于技术经常被视为执行部门，他们没有太大的战略影响力。

I saw this clearly at a previous employer, where the most senior members of the technical staff in large business areas would often hold the title of CTO for that area. These people were always highly respected and technically capable. They understood the business and its technical challenges, and were often called on to help inspire the engineering team and help with recruiting. Yet they had trouble being successful because they often lacked the direct management oversight of any teams, and because technology was frequently viewed as an execution arm, they didn’t have much strategic influence.

如果你是一个领导者，对业务战略没有权力，也没有能力将人员分配给重要任务，那么你充其量只能受制于其他高管和经理的影响力，最坏的情况是一个傀儡。你不能放弃管理的责任而不放弃随之而来的权力。

If you’re a leader with no power over business strategy and no ability to allocate people to important tasks, you’re at best at the mercy of your influence with other executives and managers, and at worst a figurehead. You can’t give up the responsibility of management without giving up the power that comes with it.

没有管理权限的 CTO 必须能够纯粹通过影响组织来完成工作。如果经理们实际上不给人们和时间在 CTO 认为重要的领域上工作，他实际上就会变得无能为力。如果你放弃管理，你就放弃了你曾经拥有的对商业战略最重要的权力，你实际上只有你的组织善意和你自己的两只手。

The CTO who doesn’t also have the authority of management must be able to get things done purely by influencing the organization. If the managers won’t actually give people and time to work on the areas that the CTO believes are important, he is rendered effectively powerless. If you give up management, you’re giving up the most important power you ever had over the business strategy, and you effectively have nothing but your organizational goodwill and your own two hands.

我对有抱负的 CTO 的建议是要记住，这首先是一项业务战略工作。这也是一项管理工作。如果你不关心公司正在经营的业务——如果你不愿意为让一大群人有效地攻击该业务而承担最终责任——那么 CTO 不适合你。

My advice for aspiring CTOs is to remember that it’s a business strategy job first and foremost. It’s also a management job. If you don’t care about the business your company is running — if you’re not willing to take ultimate responsibility for having a large team of people effectively attacking that business — then CTO is not the job for you.

问 CTO：我适合哪里？

我对工程领导中的各种头衔感到非常困惑。首席技术官、工程副总裁——有什么区别？我怎么知道我想担任这些角色中的哪一个？

I’m so confused by the various titles in engineering leadership. CTO, VP of Engineering — what’s the difference? How do I know which of these roles I want to hold?

我理解混乱。有许多关于这些角色之间区别的流行文章，因为除了“取决于情况”之外，很难给出关于它们的细节。当然，这两项工作有很多不同的方法。

I understand the confusion. There are numerous popular articles out there on the difference between these roles because it’s hard to give specifics about them beyond “it depends.” Of course, there are many different ways to do these two jobs.

要决定你想要哪份工作，你可以问自己几个问题。你认为有一天你可能会共同创办一家公司吗？您想帮助监督技术架构并建立流程和指导方针来发展它吗？您是否也愿意深入了解事物的业务方面，以便为公司的发展奠定技术架构的基础？您是否愿意做外部活动、演讲、向客户销售以及招聘高级管理人员和工程师？您愿意管理和指导高级个人贡献者吗？你可能是一个优秀的 CTO。

To decide which job you want, you may ask yourself a few questions. Do you think you might cofound a company someday? Do you want to help oversee technical architecture and set up processes and guidelines for evolving it? Are you also willing to go deep into understanding the business side of things in order to ground that technical architecture in the company’s growth? Are you willing to do external events, speaking, selling to customers, and recruiting senior managers and engineers? Are you willing to deal with managing and mentoring senior individual contributors? You might be a good CTO.

管理呢？你喜欢管理人吗？您喜欢提高工程流程的效率吗？您是否喜欢对团队正在完成的工作有一个广泛的看法，并参与确定该工作的优先级？你对组织结构着迷吗？你擅长与产品经理合作吗？您是否愿意将深度关注换成技术细节，以关注整个团队的有效性？你宁愿参加路线图规划会议而不是架构审查吗？您可能对遵循工程副总裁路径更感兴趣。

How about management? Do you enjoy managing people? Do you enjoy making engineering processes more efficient? Do you like to have a broad view of the work being done by a team and a hand in prioritizing that work? Are you fascinated by organizational structure? Are you good at partnering with product managers? Are you willing to exchange depth of focus into technology details for focus on the effectiveness of the overall team? Would you rather sit in a roadmap-planning meeting than an architecture review? You’re probably more interested in following the VP of Engineering path.

有些人会有各种各样的答案。我曾两次通过升职担任工程副总裁和首席技术官。我一直在考虑技术架构，但当我的工作需要时，我很乐意专注于组织。然而，对我来说，仅仅关注组织并不足以让我保持动力。我喜欢考虑组织结构，但我对流程和路线图规划的细节感到厌烦，需要进行一些技术和业务战略监督才能参与。

Some people will have a mix of answers. I’ve been a VP of Engineering and a CTO, both times via promotion. I was always thinking about the technical architecture, but when my job required it I was happy to focus on the organization. For me, though, having only an organizational focus is not enough to keep me motivated. I like to think about organizational structure, but I get bored with the details of process and roadmap planning, and need to have some technical and business strategy oversight to be engaged.

成为 CTO 的最快途径是成为技术联合创始人，但这只有在你和初创公司共同成长的情况下才能保证你的工作。成为工程副总裁的最快途径是在更大的组织中获得管理经验，然后加入成长中的初创公司。

The fastest route to becoming a CTO is to be a technical cofounder, but that guarantees you the job only so long as you and the startup grow together. The fastest route to being a VP of Engineering is to get management experience at a larger organization and then join a growing startup.

我将给你一些我自己的工程副总裁曾经给我的建议：“想成为 CTO（或工程副总裁）就像想结婚一样。请记住，重要的不仅仅是头衔，还有公司和人员。” 头衔绝对不是一切。

I’ll leave you with some advice my own VP of Engineering once gave me: “Wanting to be a CTO (or VP of Engineering) is like wanting to be married. Remember that it’s not just the title, it’s also the company and the people that matter.” Titles are definitely not everything.

改变优先级

Changing Priorities

一天早上，CEO 醒来，在清新的晨光中，她有了一个启示。她看到了公司开发新产品线的机会，可以将业务推向新的增长阶段。她花了一些时间勾勒出这一愿景，并将其呈现给高级领导团队的其他成员。随着这一变化，他们开始采取必要的行动，使愿景成为现实。但这不会很快发生。有一些飞行中的项目需要担心。有些事情已经差不多完成了，在完成之前取消它们将是一种耻辱。所有这些担忧都意味着团队合作起来很慢，直到突然间问题来了：那么，你为什么不把工作放在最优先的位置上呢？

One morning, the CEO wakes up and in the fresh morning light, she has a revelation. She sees an opportunity for the company to develop a new product line that can push the business to a new stage of growth. She spends some time sketching out this vision and presents it to the rest of the senior leadership team. On board with this change, they begin to make the moves needed to make the vision a reality. But it doesn’t happen quickly. There are in-flight projects to worry about. Some things are almost complete, and it would be a shame to cancel them before they got finished. All of these concerns mean that the teams are slow to come together to work on the initiative, until suddenly the question comes down: so, why aren’t you working on the top priority?

高级管理层的优先级变更有时会在没有警告的情况下发生。从团队的日常日程中移除的领导者可能会忘记，团队有很长的优先级列表，这些列表可能是几周或几个月前制定的，可能需要几周或几个月才能完成。因此，当这些领导者看到机会或觉得组织的优先事项需要改变时，他们通常期望改变立即发生，而不考虑当前事态的现实。

Priority changes from senior management can sometimes happen without warning. Leaders who are removed from the day-to-day schedules of the teams can forget that teams have long priority lists that may have been mapped out weeks or months ago and may take weeks or months to complete. So when these leaders see an opportunity or feel that the priorities of the organization need to change, they often expect that change to happen immediately, without consideration for the reality of the current state of affairs.

这个问题可能会被问到各个级别的经理，但最常见的是来自高级管理层。期待从你的老板那里得到这个问题。当你觉得有必要向你自己的团队询问时，问问自己为什么他们不明白优先级是什么，以及他们应该削减什么来解决这些问题。

This question may be asked of managers at every level, but most often originates from senior management. Expect to get this question from your boss. When you feel the need to ask it of your own teams, ask yourself why they don’t understand what the priorities are and what they should be cutting to address them.

你知道什么是首要任务吗？你的团队知道它是什么吗？这些团队的开发人员知道它是什么吗？有时，这个问题的答案只是一个沟通问题。你不知道什么是重中之重，或者你没有清楚和紧急地与你的管理团队沟通，他们也没有清楚和紧急地与他们的开发团队沟通。你没有明确地检查飞行中的事情清单并终止或推迟工作以便为这个优先级腾出空间。如果真的很紧急，你需要这样做。说某事是重中之重是一回事，但在时间表上做出实际权衡以让人们继续前进是完全不同的。

Do you know what the top priority is? Do your teams know what it is? Do the developers on those teams know what it is? Sometimes the answer to this question is simply a matter of communication. You don’t know what the top priority is, or you didn’t communicate it clearly and urgently to your management team, and they didn’t communicate it clearly and urgently to their development teams. You didn’t explicitly go through the list of things in flight and kill or postpone work in order to make room for this priority. You need to do that, if it’s truly urgent. Saying something is top priority is one thing, but making the actual tradeoffs on the schedule to get people moving on it is completely different.

我们忘记了我们之上或不同组织中的人对我们的团队目前正在做什么以及为什么做的没有相同的详细了解。我认为没有必要为您的大型组织中的每个团队不断地向同事和您的经理提供详细信息。然而，当你因为没有把重点放在正确的优先事项上而受到责备时，这表明你和 CEO 对现实的理解不一致，你需要达成一致。您的团队可能正忙于稳定导致频繁中断的系统，或者在一个已经进行了很长时间的重大项目的最后推动中。如果你认为团队需要在转移到新的首要任务之前完成他们当前的工作，你必须清楚地传达这一点。

We forget that the people above us or in different organizations don’t have the same detailed understanding of what our teams are currently doing, and why. I don’t believe it’s necessary to constantly provide minute details to peers and your manager for every team in your large organization. However, when you’re taken to task for not focusing on the right priority, it’s a sign that you and the CEO have a misaligned understanding of reality, and you need to get on the same page. Your team may be crunching to stabilize a system that’s causing frequent outages, or in the last push of a major project that has been ongoing for a long time. If you think that the team needs to finish their current work before shifting to the new top priority, you must communicate that clearly.

准备好上下推动以保持或改变焦点。如果您认为一个大项目应该在投入新工作之前完成，请尽可能详细地了解该项目的价值、当前状态和预期时间表。现实点。如果你上面的某个人如此迫切地改变了业务重点，以至于他愿意进行这次谈话，那么你可能需要在当前正在进行的工作上做出妥协，并缩短一些部分或让一些人离开它。您的团队可能对更改不满意。人们通常不喜欢因为一个新的主管突发奇想而放弃他们正在做的事情，尤其是如果他们认为他们目前的工作很重要。

Be prepared to push both up and down to maintain or change focus. If you think a big project should be finished before slotting in new work, get as many details as possible about the value of that project, its current status, and the expected timeline. Be realistic. If someone above you has changed business focus so urgently that he’s willing to have this conversation, expect that you’ll probably need to compromise on the current work in progress and cut some parts short or move some people off of it. Your team may not be happy with the change. People generally don’t enjoy being pulled off of what they’re working on for a new executive whim, especially if they believe their current work is important.

您在公司担任的管理和领导职位越高级，工作就越能确保组织朝着它需要的方向前进，这包括在需要时改变方向。为此，您可以向团队清楚地传达方向，并确保他们理解并采取必要的步骤来改变方向。向您的团队询问更改将影响的项目列表，以便您可以向上传达。这将迫使您的管理团队真正考虑新计划并开始计划。向其发起人询问该计划的目标，并了解如何将这些目标与正在进行的工作结合起来。

The more senior the management and leadership position you take in a company, the more the job becomes making sure that the organization moves in the direction it needs to move in, and that includes changing direction when needed. You do this by clearly communicating the direction to your teams, and making sure they understand it and are taking the necessary steps to change course. Ask your teams for the list of projects the change will impact, so that you can communicate it upward. This will force your management team to actually think about the new initiative and start to plan for it. Ask for the goals of the initiative from its originator, and see how you can combine those goals with work already in flight.

最后，永远不要低估某件事需要说多少次和多少种方式才能深入人心。大型组织中的沟通是困难的。根据我的经验，大多数人需要至少听三遍才能真正理解。你要告诉你自己的高级管理和领导团队。你将举行全体会议。您可能还需要发送一些详细说明更改的电子邮件。在这种情况下，一点点沟通计划可以大有帮助。尝试预测您可能会遇到的问题并为这些问题准备答案。尽可能清楚要更改的项目或结构，以免混淆。并且不要忘记将此更改作为一件好事出售！

Finally, never underestimate how many times and how many ways something needs to be said before it sinks in. Communication in a large organization is hard. In my experience, most people need to hear something at least three times before it really sinks in. You’re going to tell your own senior management and leadership team. You’ll hold an all hands meeting. You may need to send some email detailing the changes as well. A little bit of communication planning can go a long way in such situations. Try to anticipate the questions you might get and prepare answers for those questions. Be as clear as possible about the projects or structure to be changed, so there’s little room for confusion. And don’t forget to sell this change as a good thing!

当您进行交流时，您还需要重复信息。当你想让你的老板对某事采取行动时，你需要把同样的事情告诉他三遍，他才会真正听进去。前两次，问题可能仍然会自行解决，但第三次，这表明需要发生更大的事情。您可能会惊讶地发现，您开始以同样的方式对待您的团队。很多问题会向你提出，然后自己解决，所以你可能会决定在介入之前你的团队需要一定程度的持续斗争。我不建议你采用“三遍法则”作为一项政策，但它确实会发生，无论您是否计划。

You’ll also need to repeat information when you’re communicating up. When you want your boss to act on something, expect that you’ll need to tell him the same thing three times before he actually listens. The first two times, the issue may still resolve itself, but the third time, it’s a sign that something bigger needs to happen. You may be surprised to find that you start acting the same way toward your team. Many problems will get raised to you and then resolved on their own, so you may decide you need a degree of sustained struggle from your team before it’s time to step in. I’m not recommending that you adopt the “three-times rule” as a policy, but it does tend to happen, whether you plan for it or not.

组织越大，就越难快速改变优先级。如果你正在为一家成长中的初创公司工作，并有一位创始人 CEO，那么这种缓慢会让他感到沮丧。管理这种情况的最好办法是主动让 CEO 了解正在发生的事情和原因。尽你最大的努力表明你理解他的优先事项，并告诉他你为满足这些优先事项而采取的具体步骤。

The larger the organization, the harder it’ll be to change priorities quickly. If you’re working for a growing startup with a founder CEO, this slowness will frustrate him. The best thing you can do to manage this situation is to proactively keep the CEO informed about what’s happening and why. Do your best to show that you understand his priorities and tell him about the concrete steps you’re taking to meet those priorities.

制定战略

Setting the Strategy

2014 年夏天，作为 Rent the Runway 的工程高级副总裁，我面临着巨大的挑战。我的 CEO 告诉我，她想在下次董事会会议上让我升职为 CTO，但作为升职的一部分，我会被要求向董事会介绍技术战略。然后她返回了我为给她这个策略所做的每一次尝试，直到我最终创造出符合她标准的东西。而其余的，正如他们所说，是历史。

In the summer of 2014, as the SVP of Engineering at Rent the Runway, I had a big challenge ahead of me. My CEO told me that she wanted to put me up for promotion to CTO at the next board meeting, but that as part of that promotion, I’d be asked to present the technology strategy to the board. She then returned every attempt I made at giving her this strategy until I finally created something that met her standards. And the rest, as they say, is history.

我怀疑她不必让我通过这个练习来提升我。董事会对我扩大团队并将技术开发到稳定和高功能吞吐量的事实感到非常高兴。然而，我非常感谢她确实推动我完成了这个练习。在这个过程中，我从对制定战略的意义只有一个模糊的概念，转变为拥有一个具体的、具有前瞻性的战略，包括一种思考技术架构和工程团队结构的方式，这反过来又最终影响了公司自己考虑了它的整体结构。

I suspect she didn’t have to put me through this exercise to promote me. The board was very happy with the fact that I had grown the team and developed the technology to a point of stability and high feature throughput. I’m incredibly grateful that she did push me through this exercise, however. During that process, I went from having only a vague idea of what setting strategy meant to having a concrete, forward-thinking strategy encompassing a way to think about both the technical architecture and the engineering team’s structure, which in turn ultimately influenced the way the company itself thought about its overall structure.

当我谈到高层领导时，我强调战略是一个关键因素。在高层制定战略时，大多数人甚至不知道从哪里开始。我知道我没有。我得到了来自 CEO 和与我一起工作的执行 CTO 教练的指导。我向执行团队的同行征求意见。我向工程团队的高级成员提出了理论问题，并用它们来帮助我了解一些细节问题。我当然不是一个人做的。那么，考虑到这一点，制定技术战略是什么样的？

When I talk about senior leadership, I emphasize strategy as a critical element. Most people don’t even really know where to begin when it comes to setting strategy at the senior level. I know I didn’t. I had coaching, from the CEO and from an executive CTO coach that I was working with. I solicited input from my peers on the executive team. I posed theoretical questions to the senior members of the engineering team and used them to help me see some of the detailed problems. I certainly didn’t do it alone. So, with that in mind, what does setting technology strategy look like?

做很多研究

Do a Lot of Research

我首先考虑了团队、我们目前建立的技术和公司。我问工程团队他们的痛点在哪里。我询问了不同领域的几位高管，他们预计未来增长的来源。然后，我问了自己几个问题。我考虑了扩展挑战现在在哪里，以及它们将来可能在哪里。我检查了工程团队，发现了它的生产力瓶颈。我研究了技术领域，想知道它在不久的将来会发生怎样的变化，尤其是与个性化和移动开发相关的领域。

I started by considering the team, the technology we had currently built, and the company. I asked the engineering team where their pain points were. I asked several executives in various areas where they expected growth to come from in the future. Then, I asked myself several questions. I considered where the scaling challenges were now, and where they might be in the future. I examined the engineering team and found its productivity bottlenecks. I studied the technology landscape and wondered how it might change in the near future, especially as it pertained to personalization and mobile development.

结合你的研究和你的想法

Combine Your Research and Your Ideas

凭借我对现有系统、团队和瓶颈的结论，并想象我们可以在哪些地方提高效率、扩展功能或改进业务，我利用这些数据为可能的未来提出了一个粗略的想法. 我花了一些时间独自坐在一个房间里，拿着白板或纸，画出我们公司现有的系统，根据各种共同属性对系统和团队进行切片和切块。例如，我研究了面向客户的系统与面向内部运营的系统（如仓库和客户服务工具）；我查看了后端与前端。因为我们的技术必须对大部分业务数据进行建模才能运行，所以我意识到我对数据流动和变化的方式以及可能的演化轴有独特的洞察力。

Armed with my conclusions about the existing systems, teams, and bottlenecks, and having imagined the places where we could make things more efficient, expand features, or improve the business, I used the data to come up with a rough idea for a possible future. I spent some time sitting alone in a room with a whiteboard or paper and drawing out the systems in place at our company, slicing and dicing the systems and teams across various common attributes. For example, I looked at systems that were customer-facing versus systems that were internal operations–facing (such as warehouse and customer service tools); I looked at backend versus frontend. Because our technology had to model most of the business data to operate, I realized I had a unique insight into the way that data flowed and changed, and possible axes for evolution.

制定战略

Draft a Strategy

一旦我映射了这些数据，我就可以计划出可行的想法来提高运营效率、扩展功能和发展业务。我考虑了我们可能希望限制或扩展系统之间信息共享的地方。我们是否想要始终尝试对世界的实时状态进行操作的个性化系统，还是想要更像对数据子集进行视图调整的个性化系统？我们如何在部分数据流中使用各种产品和运营属性来为我们的客户体验提供运营和个性化的输入？所有这些想法都迫使我考虑业务结构、客户的需求——内部和外部——以及未来可能的演变。通过这项研究和推测，

Once I had that data mapped, I could plan out actionable ideas to improve operational efficiency, expand features, and grow the business. I considered the places we would want to potentially limit or expand information sharing between systems. Did we want personalization systems that tried to operate on the real-time state of the world at all times, or did we want personalization systems that acted more like a view adjustment on subsets of the data? How could we use various product and operational attributes in parts of the data flow to have operational as well as personalized input into what our customers experience? All of this thinking forced me to consider the structure of the business, the needs of the customer — both internal and external — and possible future evolutions. By doing this research and speculation, I was able to design a technology strategy that supported these factors into the future.

考虑董事会的沟通方式

Consider Your Board’s Communication Style

我之前说过，首席执行官发回了我完成这项工作的许多尝试。真的，她拒绝了两件事。第一个是不完善的战略计划，几乎完全是关于系统和架构细节的，并且在接下来的 6 到 12 个月之后几乎没有提供前瞻性的想法。它当然没有试图解决对团队成功至关重要的业务驱动因素。第二个是我的幻灯片。作为演讲者，我接受过制作稀疏幻灯片的培训，以支持仔细聆听的听众。这块板需要一个信息非常密集的甲板。公司董事会在会议前通读幻灯片的情况并不少见，这样会议就可以更多地关注细节而不是演示。当时没看懂这个 所以我浪费了很多精力试图制作一些在纸上没有信息的东西。学过的知识。

I said earlier that the CEO sent back many of my attempts to get this work done. Really, she rejected two things. The first was an underdeveloped strategic plan that was almost entirely about system and architectural details and offered very few forward-thinking ideas beyond the next 6 to 12 months. It certainly did not attempt to address the business drivers that were critical to the team’s success. The second was my slide deck. As a speaker, I’ve been trained to make slide decks that are sparse, in support of an audience that listens closely. This board needed a deck that was very dense with information. It’s not uncommon for company boards to read through the slide deck before a meeting, so that the meetings can be focused more on details than on presentations. I didn’t understand this at the time, so I wasted a lot of energy trying to make something that wasn’t informative on paper. Lesson learned.

正如您从这个故事中看到的那样，这里好的技术战略意味着几件事。这意味着技术架构，是的。这也意味着团队结构。这意味着了解业务的基础及其发展方向。我喜欢将专注于产品的公司的技术战略描述为“能够实现业务的许多潜在未来”。它不仅仅是一份试图解释当前问题的反应性文件，而且它预测并实现了未来的增长。如果您从事以产品为中心的业务，这是您技术战略的核心。这不是关于实际决定产品的方向，而是关于使更大的路线图能够成功实施。

As you can see from this tale, good technology strategy here meant several things. It meant technology architecture, yes. It also meant team structure. It meant understanding the underpinnings of the business and the directions in which it was headed. I like to describe technology strategy for product-focused companies as something that “enables the many potential futures of the business.” It’s not just a reactive document that tries to account for current problems, but it anticipates and enables future growth. If you’re in a product-focused business, this is the heart of your technology strategy. It’s not about actually deciding the product’s direction, but about enabling the larger roadmap to play out successfully.

在许多方面，最困难的部分是开始。第二难的部分是通过高度不完美的信息对未来进行猜测。通过这个练习，我能够以被动方式领导、审视已知环境并制定适应环境的计划，以及以前瞻性思维方式领导的能力之间的区别。现在我有了一个关于我们需要去哪里的想法，作为一个架构，作为一个团队，作为一个公司。

The hardest part, in many ways, was getting started. The second-hardest part was getting comfortable making a guess about the future with highly imperfect information. Going through this exercise was the difference between my ability to lead in a reactive fashion, looking at the known environment and making plans to accommodate it, and my ability to lead in a forward-thinking fashion. Now I had an idea about where we needed to go, as an architecture, as a team, and as a company.

在我为自己阐明了这个架构之后，领导在许多方面变得容易多了。我可以向工程团队展示我们作为技术平台的发展方向，而不仅仅是产品路线图的样子。我对我们可以做的事情有一些想法，这些事情可以直接推动公司向前发展，而不仅仅是让技术发挥作用。架构主导了技术的组织战略，最终主导了公司的一些组织战略——我为能够影响这一点而感到自豪。

After I clarified this architecture for myself, leading became in many ways much easier. I could show the engineering team a vision of where we would go as a technology platform, not just what the product roadmap looked like. I had ideas about things we could work on that would directly move the company forward, beyond making the technology work. The architecture led the technology’s organizational strategy, which ended up leading some of the company’s organizational strategy — something I was quite proud of being able to influence.

具有挑战性的情况：传递坏消息

Challenging Situations: Delivering Bad News

我们都有不得不向我们的团队传达坏消息的时候。也许公司正在裁员。可能是为了给其他项目更多的支持而解散了团队，大家都被分散到其他团队了。也许有一个你知道会不受欢迎的政策变化。我们刚才谈到的那些路线图变化有时也属于这一类。你，经理，必须成为信使并传递这个消息，但你知道团队不会高兴。

We all have times when we have to deliver bad news to our teams. Maybe the company is having layoffs. Maybe the team is being disbanded in order to give more support to other projects, and everyone is being scattered onto other teams. Perhaps there’s a policy change that you know will be unpopular. Those roadmap changes we just talked about sometimes fall into this category as well. You, the manager, have to be the messenger and deliver this news, but you know the team isn’t going to be happy.

在这种情况下你会怎么做？嗯，沟通是关键。作为高级领导层的人，您需要擅长与大型团体交流敏感信息。以下是一些注意事项：

What do you do in this situation? Well, communication is key. As a person in senior leadership, you’ll need to excel at communicating sensitive information to large groups. Here are a few dos and don’ts:

  • 不要向一大群人发送非个人的信息。传达坏消息的最糟糕方式是通过电子邮件和聊天等非个人媒介，尤其是具有评论能力的媒介。您的团队应该直接从您的嘴里听到信息，如果没有您引导信息，您可能会出现一些误解和冒泡的敌意。话虽如此，传递此信息的第二个最糟糕的方式，尤其是向一个你知道不会开心的大群体，是同时与他们一起在一个房间里。你可能会认为试图立即向每个人传达坏消息是防止它在每个人都听到之前传播的最好方法，但结果仍然是非个人的。很难看到每个人的反应，一两个非常不高兴的成员会在消息有机会深入人心之前迅速激怒整个团队。
  • 尽可能多地与个人交谈。与其进行客观的或基于群体的交流，不如尽量与人们单独谈论新闻。想想那些反应最强烈的人，并尝试为他们量身定制新闻。给他们一对一的空间来做出反应，提出问题，直接从你那里得到答案。如有必要，请明确说明这些是行军命令，您需要您的员工参与这些变化，即使他们不喜欢这些变化。如果您需要将信息传达给整个组织，请先与您的经理交谈，为他们提供谈话要点，然后让他们与团队分享，然后再将整个团队聚集在一起。
  • 不要强迫自己传达你​​无法支持的信息。你可能很难传达这个消息，因为你自己不喜欢它。也许您强烈反对政策变化。也许您讨厌团队被拆分的事实。如果你绝对不能以不会暴露你强烈分歧的方式传递消息，你可能需要让其他人帮助你传递消息。也许您要求另一位高管介入，或者可能是人力资源部的某个人。根据您团队的规模，您可以将信息传递给值得信赖的副手，并让该人帮助分享信息。作为高层领导，你必须学会​​如何成熟地处理你不同意的决定，但这并不意味着你必须独自行动。
  • 对可能的结果要诚实。你越能坚持自己新闻所指定的方向，这就越容易。如果有裁员，请承认这个过程并不有趣，但每个人都需要公司生存。如果团队正在解散，请随时指出团队到目前为止的成就以及使这成为正确前进道路的变化，并强调现在有许多新的学习和成长机会。对人直率会帮助他们更加信任你，并使他们更有可能很好地容忍不愉快的消息。
  • 请考虑一下您希望如何被告知。某天你可能不得不传递的一条消息是你离开的消息。事实上，您可能已经有过辞职或从一个团队转到另一个团队的经历。你是如何传达这个消息的？你发备忘录了吗？好吧，也许是对 HR，但对团队的其他成员来说，如果你认为他们想在公开之前知道的话，你可能会把他们拉到一边面对面地告诉他们。你可能参加了一个告别派对，写了一封告别信，或者给团队做了最后一次演讲，讲述了你在公司期间学到的东西。在某些情况下庆祝这些悲伤的变化是可以的，只要你能优雅地做到这一点。所有这些课程都适用于向您的团队提供硬新闻。
问 CTO：我有一个非技术型的老板

这是我第一次遇到一个不懂技术的老板，而且结果真的很难。我如何有效地管理这种关系？
